Sec 14-101 Definitions
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_14_BUILDINGS_AND_BUILDING_REGULATIONS 25/33
Cover crop: Grasses, small grains, or other close growing vegetation not grown for harvest.
Department: City of North Branch Building/Zoning.
EPA: Environmental protection agency.
Feed crops: Crops produced primarily for consumption by animals.
Food crops: Crops consumed by humans.
Grease trap waste: Septage removed from a grease retention device serving an other
establishment. Does not include petroleum product grease traps.
Incorporation: The mixing of septage with the topsoil such as discing, moldboard plowing or chisel
plowing to a minimum depth of six inches.
Injection: The direct flow of septage from the injector tank or injector vehicle into the soil below the
surface.
Intermittent stream: A drainage channel that provides for runoff flow to any surface water during
snow melt or rainfall events.
Maintainer: A person or business licensed by the MPCA as a Maintainer in accordance with MN
Rules Chapter 7083.
MPCA: Minnesota Pollution Control Agency.
Non-public contact site: Land with a low potential for contact with the public, including, but not
limited to agricultural land, forest, and remote areas.
Pathogens: Organisms that are capable of producing an infection or disease on a susceptible host.
Public contact site: Land with a high potential for contact by the public, including, but not limited to
public parks, recreation areas, and golf courses.
Restrictive layer: The point in depth in the soil were anaerobic conditions exist in the profile,
indicated by redoximorphic features, bedrock, water or other evidence of saturation.
Seasonal high water table: The highest level the water table reaches during a given year.
Septage: Solids and liquids removed during the periodic maintenance of a SSTS, or solids and
liquids that are removed from toilet waste treatment devices.
Shoreland district: Land located within 1,000 feet from the ordinary high water mark of a lake, pond
or flowage; 300 feet from a river or stream, or the landward extent of a floodplain on such a river or
stream, whichever is greater.
Vectors: Organisms such as flies, mosquitoes, and rats that have the potential to carry diseases.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-102 Scope And Jurisdiction
This section shall regulate the application of all septage that is applied to any land within North Branch.
This section shall regulate land suitability, establish methods and procedures required, and establish
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_14_BUILDINGS_AND_BUILDING_REGULATIONS 26/33
limits for land application of septage within North Branch.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-103 General Provisions
(a) It is unlawful to discharge septage to any surface water or well, or on any land within North
Branch that has not been issued a valid land application permit.
(b) Maintainers license required. Land application of septage must be conducted by a maintainer
licensed by the MPCA.
(c) Permit required. Septage shall be disposed of at a licensed municipal sewage treatment facility
or land applied on land which has been issued a valid permit.
(d) Specified method of application. Land application of septage may only be applied in the manner,
method, and amount; and under the conditions which are specified in the permit.
(e) Application prohibited. No person shall dispose of septage in a manner that:
1. Contaminates the ground water, or surface water in any way.
2. Results in pathogens or other contaminates coming into contact with humans through
direct contact, vectors, or through the food chain.
3. Is dangerous, or a hazard to humans or animals, both wild and domestic.
4. That restricts or inhibits the soils ability to support viable plant growth.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-104 Permit
A permit is required for each parcel of land to which septage is applied.
(a) Permit application. An application for a permit to land apply septage on a specific parcel of land
shall be made to the city on forms provided by the city. At a minimum the application must
contain the following information:
1. The legal description and the parcel identification number for the proposed receiving site.
2. The name and address of the landowner, and a signed copy of the agreement with the
landowner for land application on the specified parcel of land.
3. The exact location within the parcel where land application is proposed to take place.
4. Information regarding the nutrient suitability for land application of the proposed site,
including current soil nutrient levels and proposed nutrient loading rates.
5. Information regarding the drainage, slope, absorption rates, and separation distance from
the water table or restrictive layer of the proposed site. A soil test may be required to
verify the appropriateness of a questionable soil type for septage application purposes.
6. The location and depth of any tile lines and drainage patterns.
7. The proposed application rates, method of application, incorporation, time period in which
application may take place, and limiting conditions to application.
8. The cover crop and/or proposed cropping information.
9. A description of the pathogen and vector control methods to be used.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_14_BUILDINGS_AND_BUILDING_REGULATIONS 27/33
10. A description of how public access to the site will be controlled.
11. Parcel identification numbers and addresses of the properties that are the sources of the
septage proposed to be land applied.
(b) Duration of permit. A permit shall be valid for five years from the date of issue.
(c) Exemption. A farm, as defined by the state, is exempt only from the permitting requirements of
this section for the land application of their own septage on land farmed by them per Minn. Stats.
§ 115-56(2)(b)(3).
(d) Septage may be disposed of at a municipal wastewater treatment facility with permission of the
municipality, and after obtaining a permit from the city, if required.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-105 Requirements For Land Application Sites
To be approved as a land application site the following minimum requirements shall be met:
(a) The site shall:
1. Be a non-public contact site;
2. Not be within any shoreland district;
3. Be located in the rural residential or agricultural zoning districts;
4. Contain soils suitable for land application that have 24 inches of separation from the
application depth to the highest known restrictive layer, and are not rapidly permeable;
5. Be free of flooding hazards and not be located in a flood way or flood plain; and
6. Not contain slopes greater than 12 percent.
(b) No septage shall be applied to fractured bedrock, caves, sinkholes or wetlands.
(c) Injection or incorporation may be required methods of land application depending on the site
conditions.
(d) The minimum setback for each site and the method of incorporation listed in Table 3 must be
maintained.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-106 Required Land Application Methods
(a) Land application methods must comply with EPA 40 CFR Part 503 Rules and Regulations for
pathogen reduction, vector attraction reduction, and for maximum volume of septage that may be
applied to any site during a 365-day period.
1. Three options for required vector attraction reduction. One of the vector attraction
reduction requirements in items 1. through 3. must be met when septage is land applied.
a. Injection. Septage may be injected into the soil. No significant amount of septage
can be present on the soil surface within one hour after injection has taken place.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_14_BUILDINGS_AND_BUILDING_REGULATIONS 28/33
b. Immediate incorporation. Septage may be incorporated by tillage within six hours
after surface application. No significant amount of septage can be present on the
soil surface within one hour after incorporation has taken place.
c. Lime stabilization. The pH of the septage must be raised to 12.0 or greater by
alkali addition, and that level maintained for 30 minutes without further addition of
alkali.
(b) Septage application rates must not supply more available nitrogen in the cropping year than
allowed in EPA 40 CFR Part 503.
(c) The boundaries of land application sites must be identified and marked during septage
application, unless the boundaries are apparent such as roads, fences, tree or vegetation lines,
or steep slopes.
(d) Land application shall be performed in a manner so as to provide uniform application and timing.
Rates and methods of application shall ensure that the septage remains where it was applied.
(e) Septage shall not be applied by spraying from a public road or across road rights-of-way.
(f) The application vehicle must be moving at all times during application.
(g) A distribution device such as a splash plate or a spreader shall be used to evenly distribute the
septage.
(h) The application shall be screened to remove large objects which must be removed and disposed
of properly.
(i) Soils must dry between applications.
(j) Soils wetter than the plastic limit shall not be driven on.
(k) When soils are snow covered or frozen, the application rate is limited to 10,000 gallons per acre
or less, and application is only allowed on slopes of two percent or less. Each area of the site
may be covered only once. No further application is allowed until the previous application has
infiltrated the soil.
(l) Septage must not be applied on areas with ponding water or septage.
(m) Slope restrictions. Land application methods shall be determined by percentage of slope and are
listed in Table 2.
TABLE 2
Slope (percent) Surface Application Incorporation within 6 hours or Injection
0 - 6 Allowed Allowed
>6 - 12 Not allowed Allowed
>12 Not allowed Not allowed
Septage my only be applied on areas with a slope of 2% or less when the soil is snow covered
or frozen.

Sec 14-107 Grease Trap Wastes
Land application of grease trap waste or grease trap wastes mixed with non-grease trap septage, must
follow the most restrictive provision as follows:
(a) Grease trap waste must be incorporated into the soil within six hours of surface application. The
application rate shall not exceed 15,000 gallons per acre per year.
(b) Grease trap waste must be injected into the soil and is limited to an application rate of 15,000
gallons per acre per year.
(c) Grease trap waste from a tank designed for the purpose of removing fats, oils and greases from
effluent before discharge to an SSTS must be mixed with domestic septage prior to land
application. The quantity of grease trap waste mixed with septage cannot exceed 25 percent of
the mixture by volume. Maximum application rates of this mixture are limited to 60,000 gallons
per acre per year.
(d) When no separate grease trap is in place to collect greases, fats and oils, the septic tank that
receives effluent shall be considered the grease trap. The grease trap waste from this first septic
tank must be combined with domestic septage and mixed prior to land application. The quantity
of grease trap waste mixed with septage cannot exceed 50 percent of the mixture by volume.
The source of the septage used for diluting the grease trap waste can be from the other tanks in
series with this first tank or from tanks from another SSTS. Maximum application rates of this
mixture are limited to 30,000 gallons per acre per year.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-108 Record Keeping And Reporting
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_14_BUILDINGS_AND_BUILDING_REGULATIONS 31/33
In addition to EPA recording keeping requirements, the maintainer shall develop a record keeping
system that provides the information required by this section and retain such records for a minimum of
five years. The reporting year will run from September 1 of each year through August 31 of the following
year. Such report shall be submitted to the city no later than November 1 of each year. The following
information is required to be reported:
(a) Daily land application activities including:
1. Each site where septage was applied, the date of application, permit number for the site,
and parcel identification number.
2. The exact location on the site septage was applied, and the number of acres to receive
septage.
3. The quantity of septage applied.
4. The method of application.
5. Vector attraction reduction and pathogen reduction method used. If alkali addition is used,
records must indicate the pH of each load.
6. A description of any additional management practices and site restrictions that were used.
7. Grease trap waste methods of disposal and incorporation.
(b) Any other analysis of information as required the department.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
ARTICLE VI ENFORCEMENT AND VIOLATIONS
Sec 14-121 Access
Sec 14-122 Stop Work Orders
Sec 14-123 Violation
Sec 14-124 Civil And Other Action
Sec 14-121 Access
No person shall hinder or otherwise interfere with the city's employees in the performance of their duties
and responsibilities pursuant to this article.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-122 Stop Work Orders
Stop work orders may be issued when the city has probable cause to believe that an activity regulated
by this or any other city ordinance is being or has been undertaken without a permit, or in violation of the
provisions of a permit. When work has been stopped by a red tag, the permit shall be suspended and
the work shall not resume until the reason for the work stoppage has been completely satisfied, any
administrative fees paid, the stop work order lifted, and the permit reinstated.
To continue work or resume work is in effect is a violation of this article and a separate violation from the
violation which caused the stop work order.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-123 Violation
Any person, firm, agent, corporation, or government subdivision that violates any of the provisions of this
article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day that a violation exists shall constitute a separate
offense, which may result in a citation.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_14_BUILDINGS_AND_BUILDING_REGULATIONS 32/33
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-124 Civil And Other Action
In the event of a violation or imminent violation of this article, the city may, in addition to other remedies,
initiate appropriate civil action or proceedings to prevent, prosecute, restrain, correct or abate such
violations or imminent violations. The city attorney shall have authority to commence such civil action.
The city and city attorney may take such actions as may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this
article.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
ARTICLE VII COSTS AND REIMBURSEMENTS
If the city is required to remove or abate an imminent threat to public health or safety, the city may
recover all costs incurred in removal or abatement in a civil action, including legal fees, at the discretion
of the city council.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
ARTICLE VIII ADMINISTRATION
Sec 14-131 Fees
Sec 14-132 Interpretation
Sec 14-133 Variances And Appeals
Sec 14-134 Severability
Sec 14-135 Abrogation And Greater Restrictions
Sec 14-131 Fees
The city council shall adopt a fee schedule for activities undertaken by the city pursuant to this article.
Fees shall be due and payable at a time and in a manner to be determined by the city.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-132 Interpretation
In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this article shall be held to be minimum
requirements and shall be liberally construed in favor of the city and shall not be deemed a limitation or
repeal of any other powers granted by Minnesota Statutes.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-133 Variances And Appeals
(a) Variance requests. An owner may request a variance from the standards specified in this article
pursuant to the zoning ordinance, article II, division 2.
(b) Appeals. An owner may make an administrative appeal from a decision made by the city,
pursuant to the zoning ordinance, article II, division 2.
(c) Board of adjustment. The board of adjustment shall not have the authority to consider variances
from technical standards, system sizing, or vertical separation as specified by Minnesota Rules,
Chapters 7080, 7081, 7082, and 7083.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-134 Severability
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_14_BUILDINGS_AND_BUILDING_REGULATIONS 33/33
Sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and phrases of this article are severable. If any phrase,
clause, sentence, paragraph of section of this article shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid, or
unenforceable, such unconstitutionality, invalidity, or unenforceability shall not affect the validity of the
remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this article.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)
Sec 14-135 Abrogation And Greater Restrictions
It is not intended by this article to repeal, abrogate, or impair any other existing city ordinance,
easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. However, where this article imposes greater restrictions, the
provisions of this article shall prevail. All other ordinances inconsistent with this article are hereby
repealed to the extent of the inconsistency only.
(Ord. No. 178-12, § 2, 2-27-2012)

Sec 18-19 Licenses; Not Transferable
No license issued by the city may be transferred from one person to another without permission of the city
council.
(Code 1996, § 5.04.010)
Sec 18-20 Same; Revocation
Any license may be revoked by the city council for a violation of the section or article under which it is
issued. However, the revocation must follow any procedure provided in the section or article in question.
(Code 1996, § 5.04.020)
Sec 18-21 Same; Appeal
Any person who has made application which has been denied or not acted upon within 30 days after the
application, may apply directly to the city council for a license. The application to the city council shall contain
the same information required in the original application, plus any additional information that the city council
may require or that the applicant may feel is pertinent. The city council may grant the license after hearing if
the requirements of this Code are substantially complied with, and in the opinion of the city council granting
of the license would be in the best interest of the public.
(Code 1996, § 5.04.030)

Sec 18-46 Provisions Of State Law Adopted
The provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 340A, are adopted by reference and made part of this article as if fully set
out in this article, except as modified within this article.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.010)
Sec 18-47 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them
in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Alcoholic beverage means any beverage containing more than one-half of one percent alcohol by
volume.
Distilled spirits means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, spirits of wine, whiskey, rum, brandy, gin,
and other distilled spirits, including all dilutions and mixtures thereof, for nonindustrial use.
Hotel means any establishment where food and lodging are regularly furnished to transients and which
has:
(a) A dining room serving the general public at tables and having facilities for seating at least 30 gu
at one time; and
(b) Guest rooms in the minimum number of 10.
Intoxicating liquor means any and all ethyl alcohol, distilled, fermented, spirituous, vinous and malt
beverages containing in excess of 3.2 percent of alcohol by weight.
Low alcohol malt liquor means any fermented malt beverage containing two percent or less of alcohol by
weight. Notwithstanding any law or rule to the contrary, if either:
(a) The term "low alcohol" appears on the label of the beverage container; or
(b) A brewer has provided written certification to the state department of public safety establishing
alcoholic content of two percent or less by weight.
No further label shall be required on that container.
Malt liquor means any beer, ale, or other beverage made from malt by fermentation and containing not
less than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume.
Manufacturer means every person who, by any process of manufacturing, fermenting, brewing, distilling,
refining, rectifying, blending or by the combination of different materials, prepares or produces
intoxicating liquors for sale.
Off-sale means the sale of alcoholic beverages in original packages for consumption off the licensed
premises where sold only.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 3/49
On-sale means the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the licensed premises only.
Restaurant means any establishment, other than a hotel, under the control of a single proprietor or
manager, where meals are regularly prepared on the premises and served at tables to the general
public. Such establishment shall have facilities for seating not less than 60 guests at one time.
Sale, sell or sold means all barters and all manners or means of furnishing intoxicating or nonintoxicating
liquor including such furnishing in violation of any statute, ordinance or regulation.
3.2 percent malt liquor means any malt liquor containing not less than one-half of one percent alcohol by
volume nor more than 3.2 percent alcohol by weight.
Wholesaler means any person who sells alcoholic beverages to persons to whom sale is permitted
under Minn. Stats. § 340A.310 from a stock maintained in a warehouse in the state.
Wine means the product made from the normal alcoholic fermentation of grapes, including still wine,
sparkling and carbonated wine, wine made from condensed grape must, wine made from agricultural
products other than sound, ripe grapes, imitation wine, compounds sold as wine, vermouth, cider, perry
and sake, in each instance containing not less than one-half of one percent nor more than 24 percent
alcohol by volume for nonindustrial use. Wine does not include distilled spirits as defined in this section.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.020)
State Law reference — Definitions, Minn. Stats. § 340A.101
Sec 18-48 Establishment And Location Of Municipal Liquor Dispensaries
There is established a municipal dispensary for off-sale of intoxicating liquor. The dispensaries shall be
located at such suitable places as the city council may determine. Such premises shall be leased or owned
by the municipality. No premises shall be leased for the operation of a municipal liquor dispensary, and no
license shall be granted or renewed for premises upon which the taxes or other special levies are delinquent,
unless by special action of the city council upon good cause shown.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.030)
State Law reference — Authority to establish municipal liquor stores, Minn. Stats. § 340A.601
Sec 18-49 Municipal Liquor Dispensaries; Manager; Responsibilities
(a) Immediate charge. The dispensary shall be in immediate charge of the manager. The manager shall
be selected by the city council and shall be paid such compensation as determined by the city
council.
(b) Duties. The manager shall have full charge of the operation of such dispensary and have authority to
purchase supplies as necessary. The manager shall be responsible to the city administrator and the
city council.
(c) Bond. At the option of the city administrator or city council the manager and/or assistant manager
shall furnish a surety bond to the city in such terms as the city council or administrator shall specify,
conditioned on the faithful discharge of his duties. The premiums shall be paid by the city.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.040)
Sec 18-50 Hours And Rules Of Operations For Municipal Liquor Dispensaries
(a) Establish hours. The dispensary manager, by and with consent of the city administrator, shall
establish the hours of operation in keeping with state law and efficiency of operation.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 4/49
(b) Conditions of operation. No other business other than off-sale purchases, state lottery, associated
food and snack purchases, and related miscellaneous merchandise such as bar supplies shall be
carried on by the dispensary operations or employees. Loitering shall not be permitted.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.050; Ord. No. 133-09, 4-27-2009)
State Law reference — Hours of sale, Minn. Stats. § 340A.504.
Sec 18-51 License Required
No person except wholesalers and manufacturers to the extent authorized by law, and except the municipal
liquor dispensaries, shall directly or indirectly deal in, sell, or offer for sale, any alcoholic beverage within the
city; nor directly or indirectly, in any private club or public place or upon any pretense or by any device, allow
the consumption or display of intoxicating liquor for the purpose of mixing with intoxicating liquor, except as
provided in this article without first having received a license and paid a fee as provided in this article.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.060)
Sec 18-52 Types Of Licenses And Fees
In accordance with state law and city ordinances, the following types of annual licenses may be issued with
fees being set from time to time by city council ordinance:
(a) 3.2 percent malt liquor, off-sale;
(b) 3.2 percent malt liquor, on-sale;
(c) Intoxicating liquor, clubs on-sale as defined in Minn. Stats. § 340A.408:
1. Clubs with membership of 200 or less;
2. Clubs with membership of 201 to 500;
3. Clubs with membership of greater than 500.
(d) Intoxicating liquor, on-sale for hotels and restaurants, as defined by Minn. Stats. § 340.07 and as
modified by section 18-64;
(e) Consumption and display (set up) permit as defined in Minn. Stats. § 340A.414;
(f) Wine, on-sale, for restaurants as defined in Minn. Stats. 340A.404 and as modified by section 18-64;
(g) Sunday liquor on-sale, for restaurants, as defined in Minn. Stats. § 340A.504 and modified by section
18-64;
(h) Intoxicating liquor, off-sale, as defined by Minn. Stats. § 340A.408.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.070)
State Law reference — Licenses, Minn. Stats. §§ 340A.401—340A.415.
Sec 18-53 Temporary Licenses
In addition to the annual license referred to in section 18-52, the city council may issue temporary on-sale
licenses for the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor, subject to the following:
(a) License shall be issued for specific dates and places, maximum of three days;
(b) License fee shall be set by city council;
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 5/49
(c) A nonprofit organization which sponsors community-wide activities in excess of five events may
receive an annual license upon application to city council with all dates specified in advance. The city
council shall determine which organizations qualify for these licenses. The license fee shall be set by
city council.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.080; Ord. No. 78(amd.), 4-14-2003
State Law reference — Temporary licenses, Minn. Stats. §§ 340A.404, subd. 10, 340A.410, subd. 10.
Sec 18-54 Temporary Sunday Licenses
In addition to the above temporary licenses for the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor, a temporary Sunday liquor
license may be received, subject to the following:
(a) License shall be for one-day period and applicant must be authorized for the sale of intoxicating
liquors;
(b) License fee shall be set by city council.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.090)
State Law reference — Sunday licenses, Minn. Stats. § 340A.504, subd. 3.
Sec 18-55 Combination Licenses
A restaurant that is the holder of a wine license as well as a 3.2 percent malt liquor license with gross
receipts of at least 60 percent attributable to the sale of food can sell intoxicating malt liquor (strong beer)
without another license.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.100)
State Law reference — Combination licenses, Minn. Stats. § 340A.406.
Sec 18-56 License Fees; Generally
(a) The license fee shall be paid in full before the application for a license is accepted. All fees shall be
paid into the general fund of the city. Upon rejection of any application for a license or upon
withdrawal of the application for a license before approval by the city council, the fee shall be
refunded to the applicant, less any costs for processing.
(b) When the license is for premises where the building is not ready for occupancy, the time fixed for
computation of the license fee for the initial license period shall be 90 days after approval of the
license by the city council or upon the date the building is ready for occupancy, whichever is sooner.
(c) When an application is received for a license outside of the normal application cycle a pro rata share
shall be charged if the remaining period is less than nine months.
(d) No part of the fee paid for any license issued under this article shall be refunded except in the
following instances upon application to the city council within 30 days from the happening of the
conditions described below. The city council may refund a pro rata portion of the fee for the unexpired
period of a license in excess of 25 percent. Refunded fee shall be computed on a monthly basis
when the operation of the business closes because of:
1. Destruction or damage of the licensed premises by fire or other catastrophe.
2. The licensee's death.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.110)
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 6/49
Sec 18-57 Applications For Licenses
Applications for licenses provided in this article shall be made to the city administrator on such forms as the
city administrator may from time to time provide. In addition to such information as the city administrator may
require, the application shall also include:
(a) Whether the applicant is a natural person, corporation, partnership, or other form of organization;
(b) If other than a natural person, the names, residences, and dates of birth of those owners holding
more than a five percent interest in the applicant;
(c) The business name and location;
(d) Whether or not the owner or any of its members was ever convicted of a crime relating to the sale of
intoxicating or nonintoxicating beverages; and if so, the nature thereof;
(e) Whether or not the applicant has ever applied for or held, in other communities, a license to sell or
permit the consumption on its premises of beer or intoxicating liquor, and if a license has been
revoked by another community, the reason therefor;
(f) Fee as set by city council;
(g) Whether or not all real estate, special assessments, personal property taxes for the premises to be
licensed which are due and payable have been paid and if not paid, the years and amounts which are
unpaid;
(h) Seating capacity of the structure both in actual seats and building limitations as defined under the
uniform building code;
(i) Investigation fee for original applications;
(j) Application shall be executed as follows: If the application is by a natural person, it shall be signed
and sworn to by such person. If by a corporation, by an officer thereof and if by a partnership by one
of the partners. If the application is by an unincorporated association, it shall be signed and sworn to
by the manager or managing officer thereof. If the applicant is a partnership, the application, license
bond and insurance policy shall be made and issued in the name of all partners;
(k) Certificate of insurance for coverage as provided in section 18-63.
It is unlawful to make any false or misleading statements in an application. All applications shall be
made to the city administrator.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.120)
State Law reference — Licenses, Minn. Stats. §§ 340A.401—340A.414.
Sec 18-58 Renewal Application
Applications for the renewal of an existing license shall be made at least 60 days prior to the date of the
expiration of the license and shall be made in such abbreviated form as the city council may approve. If, in
the judgment of the city council, good and sufficient cause is shown by an applicant for his failure to file for a
renewal within the time provided, the city council may, if the other provisions of this article are complied with,
grant the application.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.130)
Sec 18-59 Investigation Of Applicants And Fees
(a) The city administrator shall cause to investigate all facts set out in the application, including a
consideration of the building with regard to building and zoning codes and proximity to schools and
churches. A hearing regarding the granting or denial of an application shall be considered upon
written request for such stating the reasons for or against such application. After such investigation
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 7/49
and hearing, a written recommendation shall be made to city council. The city council may order or
conduct such additional investigation as it deems appropriate. The city council shall grant or deny the
license in accordance with state law and the provisions of this article.
(b) The fee for such investigation shall be set by city council. The investigation fee for 3.2 percent malt
liquor on sale licenses for temporary licenses as defined under section 18-60 shall be waived.
Investigation fees are not refundable.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.070)
Sec 18-60 Persons Ineligible For License
Persons ineligible for licenses are as follows:
(a) Persons under 21 years of age;
(b) Persons who have been convicted of a felony, or of violating the National Prohibition Act or any law
of this state or local ordinance relating to the manufacture or transportation of intoxicating liquors
who, within five years of the license application, have been convicted of a felony or a willful violation
of a federal or state law or local ordinance governing the manufacture, sale, distribution, or
possession for sale or distribution of an alcoholic beverage;
(c) Persons who have a direct or indirect interest in a manufacturer, brewer, or wholesaler;
(d) Persons who, if a corporation, does not have a manager who is eligible pursuant to the provisions of
this section;
(e) Persons who are the spouse of a person ineligible for a license, pursuant to the provisions of this
section or who, in the judgment of the city council are not the real party in interest of beneficial owner
of the business operated, or to be operated, under the license;
(f) Persons who already own or has a direct or indirect interest in a license provided for in this article;
provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply to temporary nonintoxicating malt liquor
licenses, or off-sale nonintoxicating licenses;
(g) Persons not of good moral character and repute.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.150)
State Law reference — Persons eligible, Minn. Stats. § 340A.402.
Sec 18-61 Places Ineligible For A License
(a) No license shall be granted or renewed for operation on any premises on which taxes, assessments,
or other financial claims of the city or of the state are due, delinquent, or unpaid, unless an action
pursuant to Minn. Stats. ch. 278, is pending.
(b) No license shall be granted for the sale of alcoholic beverages on any premises where a licensee has
been convicted of a violation of this article or applicable state statutes or where any license
hereunder has been revoked for cause, until six months have elapsed after such conviction or
revocation.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.160)
Sec 18-62 Conditions Of License
(a) Every license shall be granted subject to the conditions of this article, this Code, and state law.
(b) All licensed premises shall have the licenses posted in a conspicuous place at all times.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 8/49
(c) No gambling or gambling device shall be permitted on any licensed premises except as authorized
under state law.
(d) Any police officer, chief building official, or any other employee so designated by the city
administrator shall have the unqualified right to enter, inspect, and search the premises of the license
during normal business hours without a warrant.
(e) Every licensee shall be responsible for the conduct of his place of business and the conditions of
sobriety and order in the place of business and on the premises.
(f) All sales shall be made in full view of the public.
(g) No alcoholic beverage shall be sold or furnished or delivered to any obviously intoxicated person,
habitual drunkard, person under the age of 21 years or to any person to whom sale is prohibited by
state law, nor shall any of the above persons be allowed to consume alcoholic beverages on the
licensed premises.
(h) Each license shall be issued to the applicant only and shall not be transferable to another holder.
Each license shall be issued only for the premises described in the application. No license may be
transferred to another place without the approval of the city council.
(i) It shall be the duty of each licensee to notify the city administrator of any change in legal ownership
or beneficial interest in such licensee. Any change of beneficial interest in stock entitled to vote which
results in a change in voting control of the licensee shall be deemed equivalent to transfer of the
license to such corporation and any such license shall be revoked 30 days after any such change of
ownership or beneficial interest of shares unless the city council shall have been notified of such
change in writing and shall have approved the change. If a question arises as to compliance with this
subsection, the stock transfer record and minute book of any corporate licensee shall be available for
inspection by the city administrator or other duly authorized representative of the city at all
reasonable times.
(j) No licensee shall knowingly permit the licensed premises or any room in those premises or any
adjoining building directly or indirectly under his control to be used as a resort for prostitutes or other
disorderly persons.
(k) The holder of an on-sale license for the sale of intoxicating liquor or 3.2 percent malt liquor shall
maintain a current list of all employees of the licensee. Such list shall be maintained by the licensee
within the licensed premises in such place as to be immediately accessible to any peace officer upon
demand. The peace officer shall be entitled to demand the list whenever he is engaged in the
investigation of a possible violation of the provisions of this article. The failure of any licensee to
maintain such list or to produce such list to a peace officer, upon appropriate demand, shall be
subject to disciplinary action by the city council, including the suspension or revocation of the license
issued under this article.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.170)
Sec 18-63 Insurance; Required
(a) Every person licensed to sell retail intoxicating liquor or 3.2 percent malt liquor at on-sale shall
demonstrate proof of liability insurance as a condition of his license.
(b) An exception is provided under state law for establishments with on-sale wine licenses and 3.2
percent malt liquor licenses with total gross sales of less than $25,000.00 for the preceding year.
Documentation showing annual gross sales and a notarized statement certifying to the correctness of
such documentation is required. The statement does not release owners of liability under the
Minnesota Dram Shop Act, Minn. Stats. § 340A.801.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 9/49
(c) The liability insurance shall provide for coverage as follows:
1. Fifty thousand dollars bodily injury coverage for one person, $100,000.00 coverage for more
than one person and in the amount of $10,000.00 because of injury to or destruction of
property of others in any one occurrence;
2. One hundred thousand dollars for loss of means of support of any one person in any one
occurrence, and, subject to the limit for one person for loss of means of support of two or
more persons in any one occurrence.
(d) Such liability insurance policy shall further provide that no cancellation for any cause, except for
nonpayment of premium, by either the insured or the insurer unless the canceling party has first given
30 days' notice in writing to the issuing authority of intent to cancel the policy; and nonpayment of
premium unless the canceling party has first given ten days notice in writing to the city administrator
of intent to cancel the policy. Further, it shall provide that no payment of any claim by the insurance
company shall in any manner decrease the coverage provided for in respect to any other claim or
claims brought against the insured or company thereafter. Such policy shall be conditioned that the
insurer shall pay to the extent of the principal amount of the policy any damages for death or injury
caused by or resulting from the violation of any law relating to the business for which such license
has been granted. The licensee and the city shall be named as joint insured on the liability insurance
policy.
(e) In lieu of providing an insurance policy with the coverage aforesaid, the applicant may provide a bond
of a surety company or a certificate of the state commissioner of finance that the applicant has
deposited cash or securities which may legally be purchased by savings banks or for trust funds
having a market value of $100,000.00 all in the amount of the coverage set forth above as authorized
by Minn. Stats. § 340A.409.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.180)
State Law reference — Insurance requirements, Minn. Stats. § 340A.409.
Sec 18-64 Liquor License Establishments
(a) Minors. No persons under 18 years of age shall be employed in any rooms constituting the place in
which intoxicating or 3.2 percent malt liquors are sold at retail on-sale, except that persons under 18
years of age may be employed as musicians or to perform the duties of bus boy or dishwashing
services in an establishment defined in Minn. Stats. § 340A.101 as a restaurant or a hotel or a motel
serving food in rooms in which intoxicating or 3.2 percent malt liquors are sold at retail on sale.
(b) Minimum seating capacity.
1. To be eligible for an intoxicating liquor license on-sale, any restaurant or the dining area of
any hotel or motel must have a minimum seating capacity of 60 persons.
2. To be eligible for a wine license on-sale any restaurant must have a minimum seating
capacity of 30 persons.
(c) Health safety regulations. All establishments licensed under this article shall meet all requirements of
state, county, and local regulations pertaining to health and safety.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.190)
Sec 18-65 Establishments; Days And Hours
(a) Closing. Except as otherwise provided in this article, all on-sale establishments, bottle clubs, and
public drinking places shall be closed to the public not later than one-half hour after the required time
for stopping sales, until the time provided in this article as permissible for sales, consumption, or
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 10/49
display. No persons other than employees shall be permitted within such establishments during the
closed periods. All such on-sale licensees may keep licensed premises open at times when the sale
of intoxicating and 3.2 percent malt liquor is prohibited for sale of food or recreational activity,
provided such licensee shall lock, or in another manner secure, all facilities or equipment for the
serving of such liquor starting not later than 1:00 a.m., Sunday through Saturday without a permit
from the State of Minnesota Alcohol and Gambling Division or 2:00 a.m. on Friday through Saturday
if the licensee obtains a permit from the State of Minnesota Alcohol and Gambling Division, until the
time provided in this article as permissible for sales, consumption, or display. All public entrances to
premises open after 1:00 a.m. shall remain open and unlocked during all times when said premises
have customers therein. No licensee who elects to remain open after 1:00 a.m. shall permit any
person to consume or display any liquor in any container, including glasses, in the premises after
1:30 a.m. or 2:30 a.m. on Friday and Saturday with a permit from the State of Minnesota Alcohol and
Gambling Division and until the time in this article provided as permissible for sales, consumption, or
display.
(b) Intoxicating liquor establishments. No licensee nor other person shall sell, consume, or display, or
allow the sale, consumption, or display of intoxicating liquor between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00
a.m. on Monday through Saturday. With a permit from the State of Minnesota Alcohol and Gambling
Division, no licensee nor other person shall sell, consume or display, or allow the sale consumption
or display of intoxicating liquor between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on Friday through
Saturday. No sale shall be made after 1:00 a.m. on Sundays, except as provided by Minn. Stats. §
304A.504, subd. 3.
(c) 3.2 percent malt liquor establishments. No licensee nor other person shall sell, consume, or display,
or allow the sale, consumption or display of 3.2 percent malt liquor between the hours of 1:00 a.m.
and 8:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday inclusive. With a permit from the State of Minnesota Alcohol
and Gambling Division, no licensee nor other person shall sell, consume or display, or allow the sale
consumption or display of intoxicating liquor between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on Friday
through Saturday. No sale of such liquor should be made on any Sunday between the hours of 1:00
a.m. and 12:00 noon.
(d) Others. No person shall sell, consume, or display, or allow the sale, consumption, or display of any
liquor on any other licensed premises between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on any day.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.200; Ord. No. 179-12, § 1, 2-13-2012)
State Law reference — Authority to be more restrictive, Minn. Stats. § 304A.504.
Sec 18-66 Revocation, Suspension And Nonrenewal
(a) The city council may suspend or revoke any license for the sale of intoxicating liquor for the violation
of any provision or condition of this article or of any state law or federal law regulating the sale of
intoxicating liquor or the violation of any provision or condition of this article or of any state law or
federal law regulating the sale of intoxicating liquor, and shall revoke such license for any willful
violation which, under the laws of the state, is grounds for mandatory revocation, and shall revoke for
failure to keep the insurance required by this article in full force and effect.
(b) Except in the case of a suspension pending a hearing on revocation, suspension by the city council
shall be preceded by written notice to the licensee and a public hearing. No suspension or revocation
takes effect until the license or permit holder has been given an opportunity for a hearing under Minn.
Stats. §§ 14.57— 14.69 of the Administrative Procedure Act. This section does not require the city to
conduct the hearing before an employee of the state office of administrative hearings. The city
council may, without any notice, suspend any license pending a hearing on revocation for a period
not exceeding 30 days. The notice may be served upon the licensee personally or by leaving the
same at the licensed premises with the person in charge thereof.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 11/49
(Code 1996, § 5.08.210)
State Law reference — License revocation or suspension, Minn. Stats. § 340A.415.
Sec 18-67 Prohibited Actions
(a) It is unlawful for any licensee to employ, or to encourage or permit upon or within the licensed
premises:
1. Any person who is unclothed or whose clothing exposes to view any portion of the female
breast below the top of the areola; any pubic hair; or the anus, vulva or genitals;
2. Films, still pictures, electronic reproductions or other visual reproductions exposing those
parts of the body prohibited in subsection (a)(1).
(b) A violation of this section shall constitute grounds for the revocation or the suspension of the license,
irregardless of the charging, conviction or acquittal of the licensee. The city council shall consider the
nature of the violation; the circumstances under which the violation occurred; whether the violation
was beyond the control of the licensee; whether the licensee timely took control of and stopped the
violation; and prior violations, if any, of the licensee.
(Code 1996, § 5.08.230)
ARTICLE IV BINGO, GAMBLING DEVICES AND RAFFLES

Sec 18-93 Purpose
The purpose of this article is to closely regulate and control the conduct of the game of bingo, gambling
devices and raffles and to prohibit commercialization.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.010)
Sec 18-94 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them
in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 12/49
Active member means a member who has paid all dues to the organization, who is 18 years of age or
older, who has equal voting rights with all other members, who has equal opportunity to be an elected
officer, who has equal right and responsibilities of attendance at the regularly scheduled meetings of the
organization, whose name and membership origination date appear with the member's knowledge and
consent on a list of members of the organization, and who has been a member of the organization for at
least six months.
Affiliate means any person or entity directly or indirectly controlling, controlled by, or under common
control or ownership with a licensee of the state gambling control board or any officer or director of a
licensee of the state gambling control board.
Allowable expense means the percentage of the total cost incurred by the organization in the purchase
of any good, service, or other item which corresponds to the proportion of the total actual use of the
good, service, or other item that is directly related to conduct of lawful gambling. Allowable expense
includes the advertising of the conduct of lawful gambling, provided that the amount expended does not
exceed five percent of the annual gross profits of the organization or $5,000.00 per year per
organization, whichever is less. The state gambling control board may adopt rules to regulate the
content of the advertising to ensure that the content is consistent with the public welfare.
Bar operation means a method of selling and redeeming gambling equipment within a leased premises
which is licensed for the on-sale of alcoholic beverages where such sales and redemptions are made by
an employee of the lessor from a common area where food and beverages are also sold.
Bingo means a game where each player has a bingo hard card or bingo paper sheet, for which a
consideration has been paid, and played in accordance with this article and with rules of the state
gambling control board for the conduct of bingo. "Bingo" also includes a linked bingo game.
Bingo occasion means a single gathering or session at which a series of one or more successive bingo
games is played.
Eligible organization means any fraternal, religious, veterans or other nonprofit organization covered by
Minn. Stats. § 290.05, subd. l, clause (i) or (k), which organization has been in existence for at least
three years and has at least 30 active members.
Gambling equipment means: bingo hard cards or paper sheets, linked bingo paper sheets, devices for
selecting bingo numbers, pull-tabs, jar tickets, paddlewheels, paddlewheel tables, paddle tickets, paddle
ticket cards, tipboards, tipboard tickets, and pull-tab dispensing devices.
Paddlewheel means a wheel marked off into sections containing one or more numbers, and which, after
being turned or spun, uses a pointer or marker to indicate winning chances.
Profit means the gross receipts collected from one or more bingo occasions or the operation of gambling
devices or the conduct of raffles less reasonable sums necessary and actually expended for supplies
and equipment, prizes, rent and city license fees.
Raffle means a game in which a participant buys a ticket for a chance at a prize with the winner
determined by a random drawing to take place at a location and date printed upon the ticket.
Tipboard means a board placard or other device in which each section contains a hidden number of
numbers, or other symbol, which determines the winning chances.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.020)
State Law reference — Definitions, Minn. Stats. § 349.12.
Sec 18-95 License Required
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 13/49
(a) No bingo occasion may be conducted, raffle held or gambling device used except by an eligible
organization which has secured a license for that purpose, as provided, in this article. Separate
licenses shall be required for raffles, bingo and gambling devices.
(b) No license under this article shall be issued until at least 30 days after the date of application and
shall be deemed granted if not denied within 180 days from the date of the application.
(c) No license issued may be transferred to any other person or organization. No license shall be
transferred to any location other than the location specified in the license, without prior approval by
the city council.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.030)
State Law reference — License required, Minn. Stats. § 349.155.
Sec 18-96 License Applications
Every application for a license shall be made to the city administrator on a form supplied by the city and
containing such information as the city administrator or city council may require. No person shall make a
false statement in an application. Copies of each application shall be referred to the city's chief law
enforcement officer, fire chief, building inspector and other necessary staff persons for their
recommendations.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.040)
State Law reference — License application, Minn. Stats. § 349.155.
Sec 18-97 Suspension And Revocation
The city council may suspend or revoke any license for a violation of any provision of Minn. Stats. ch. 349 or
this article. No license shall be suspended or revoked until an opportunity for a hearing has been granted
upon notice personally served or delivered by certified mail at least ten days prior to the hearing, which
notice shall state the time and place of the hearing and the nature of the charges against the licensee.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.050)
State Law reference — Denial, suspension, revocation of license, Minn. Stats. § 349.155, subd. 4.
Sec 18-98 Appointment Of Gambling Manager
(a) All lawful gambling conducted by a licensed organization must be under the supervision of a
gambling manager. A gambling manager designated by an organization to supervise lawful gambling
is responsible for the gross receipts of the organization and for its conduct in compliance with all laws
and rules. A person designated as a gambling manager shall maintain a fidelity bond in the sum of
$10,000.00 in favor of the organization conditioned on the faithful performance of the manager's
duties. The terms of the bond must provide that notice be given to the state gambling control board in
writing not less than 30 days before its cancellation.
(b) A person may not act as a gambling manager for more than one organization.
(c) An organization may not conduct lawful gambling without having a gambling manager.
(d) An organization may not have more than one gambling manager at any time.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.060)
State Law reference — Gambling manager required, Minn. Stats. § 349.167.
Sec 18-99 Conduct Of Bingo
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 14/49
(a) Bingo occasions. Not more than ten bingo occasions each week may be conducted by an
organization. At least 15 bingo games must be held at each occasion and a bingo occasion must
continue for at least 1½ hours but not more than four consecutive hours.
(b) Bingo. During any bingo occasion conducted by an organization, the organization is directly
responsible for the:
1. Staffing of the bingo occasion;
2. Conducting of lawful gambling during the bingo occasion;
3. Acquiring, storage, inventory control, and reporting of all gambling equipment used by the
organization;
4. Receipt, accounting, and all expenditures of gross receipts from lawful gambling; and
5. Preparation of the bingo packets.
(c) Winners. Each bingo winner must be determined and every prize shall be awarded and delivered the
same day on which the bingo occasion is conducted, except that prizes won in a linked bingo game
must be delivered within three business days of the day on which the occasion was conducted.
(d) Checkers. One or more checkers must be engaged for each bingo occasion when bingo is conducted
using bingo hard cards. The checker or checkers must record, on a form the state gambling control
board provides, the number of hard cards played in each game and the prizes awarded to recorded
hard cards. The form must provide for the inclusion of the face number of each winning hard card and
must include a checker's certification that the figures recorded are correct to the best of the checker's
knowledge.
(e) Bingo cards and sheets.
1. The state gambling control board shall by rule require that all licensed organizations:
a. Conduct bingo only using liquid daubers on bingo paper sheets that bear an individual
number recorded by the distributor; and
b. Use each bingo paper sheet for no more than one bingo occasion.
In lieu of the requirements of subsection (e)(1) b., a licensed organization may
electronically record the sale of each bingo hard card or paper sheet at each bingo
occasion using an electronic recording system approved by the state gambling control
board.
2. The requirements of subsection (e)(1) shall only apply to a licensed organization that received
gross receipts from bingo in excess of $150,000.00 in the organization's last fiscal year.
(f) Conduct of bingo.
1. Each bingo hard card and paper sheets must have five horizontal rows of spaces with each
row except one having five numbers. The center row must have four numbers and the center
space marked "free." Each column must have one of the letters B-I-N-G-O in order at the top.
Bingo paper sheets may also have numbers that are not preprinted but are filled in by players.
2. A game of bingo begins with the first letter and number called. Each player must cover or
mark with a liquid dauber the numbers when bingo balls, similarly numbered, are randomly
drawn, announced, and displayed to the players, either manually or with a flashboard and
monitor. The game is won when a player has covered or marked a previously designated
arrangement of numbers on the card or sheet and declared bingo. The game is completed
when a winning card or sheet is verified and a prize awarded, except that prizes won in linked
bingo games may be awarded pursuant to subsection (c).
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 15/49
(g) Linked bingo games. A licensed organization may conduct or participate in a linked bingo game in
association with one or more other licensed organizations.
(h) Contribution to each prize awarded. Each participating licensed organization shall contribute to each
prize awarded in a linked bingo game in an amount not to exceed $300.00 per occasion.
(i) Adoption of rules. The state gambling control board may adopt rules to:
1. Specify the manner in which a linked bingo game must be played and how the linked bingo
prizes must be awarded;
2. Specify the records to be maintained by a linked bingo game provider;
3. Require the submission of periodic reports by the linked bingo game provider and specify the
content of the reports;
4. Establish the qualifications required to be licensed as a linked bingo game provider; and
5. Any other matter involving the operation of a linked bingo game.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.070)
State Law reference — Similar provisions, Minn. Stats. § 349.17.
Sec 18-100 Conduct Of Bingo
Raffle tickets at a minimum must list the three most expensive prizes to be awarded. If additional prizes will
be awarded that are not contained on the raffle ticket, the raffle ticket must contain the statement "A
complete list of additional prizes is available upon request." Notwithstanding Minn. Stats. § 349.12, subd. 33,
raffles conducted under the exemptions in Minn. Stats. § 349.166 may use tickets that contain only the
sequential number of the raffle ticket and no other information if the organization makes a list of prizes and a
statement of other relevant information required by rule available to persons purchasing tickets and if tickets
are only sold at the event and on the date when the tickets are drawn.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.080)
State Law reference — Conduct of raffles, Minn. Stats. § 349.173.
Sec 18-101 Operation Of Gambling Devices Generally
(a) No compensation shall be paid to any person in connection with the operation of a gambling device
or the conduct of a raffle by a licensed organization. No person who is not an active member of an
organization, or its auxiliary, or the spouse or surviving spouse of an active member may participate
in the organization's operation of a gambling device or conduct of a raffle.
(b) Each organization licensed to operate gambling devices shall keep records of its gross receipts,
expenses and profits for each single gathering or occasion at which gambling devices are operated
or a raffle is conducted. All deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall
be documented with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the purchased
item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient. The distribution of profits shall be
itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date of payment.
(c) Gross receipts from the operation of gambling devices and the conduct of raffles shall be segregated
from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross receipts, and placed in a separate
account. Each organization shall have separate records of its gambling operations. The person who
accounts for gross receipts, expenses and profits from the operation of gambling devices or the
conduct of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for other revenues of the organization,
except that such person may be the same person who accounts for bingo gross receipts, expenses
and profits.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 16/49
(d) Each organization licensed to operate gambling devices or to conduct raffles shall report monthly to
its membership, and to the city its gross receipts, expenses and profits from gambling devices or
raffles, and the itemized distribution of profits.
(e) Records required by this section shall be preserved for three years, and organizations shall make
available their records relating to operation of gambling devices and the conduct of raffles for public
inspection at reasonable times and places.
(f) Gambling devices shall be operated and raffles conducted by a licensed organization only upon
premises which it owns or leases except that tickets for raffles conducted in accordance with this
section may be sold off the premises. Leases shall be for a period of not less than one year and shall
be in writing. The leases shall be for one location for the entire licensed year unless otherwise
authorized by the city. No license shall provide that rental payments shall be based on a percentage
of the receipts or profits from gambling devices or raffles. Copies of all leases shall be provided to the
city.
(g) Total prize from the operation of paddlewheels and tipboards awarded in any single day in which they
are operated shall not exceed $500.00. Total prizes resulting from any single spin of a paddlewheel,
or from any single tipboard, shall not exceed $100.00. Total prizes awarded in any calendar year by
any organization from the operation of paddlewheels and tipboards and the conduct of raffles shall
not exceed $15,000.00. Merchandise prizes shall be valued at fair market retail value.
(h) Nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize any use, possession or operation of:
1. Any gambling device which is activated by the insertion of a coin or token; or
2. Any gambling game or device in which the winning numbers, tickets or chances are in any
way determined by the outcome of any athletic contest or sporting event.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.080)
State Law reference — Gambling devices, Minn. Stats. § 349.
Sec 18-102 Filing Requirements For Bingo License
At the time of making its first application for a bingo license under this article, and on an annual basis
thereafter, each licensed organization shall file with the city council copies of the following:
(a) The most recently filed U.S. Department of the Treasury, Internal Revenue Service, Return of
Organization Exempt from Income Tax Form 990, or a comparable form with the Department of the
Treasury.
(b) The most recently filed Department of the Treasury, Internal Revenue Service, Exempt Organization
Business Income Tax Form 990-T, or a comparable form if the organization is required to file the form
with the Department of the Treasury.
(c) The most recently filed annual report required of charitable organization by Minn. Stats. § 309.53.
(d) The most recently filed state department of revenue statement of bingo operations. All information
contained in the statement shall be true, correct, and complete to the best of the knowledge of the
person or persons signing the statement.
(e) Any lease agreements required by this act, executed by the organization in regard to premises
leased for the conduct of bingo.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.090)
State Law reference — Annual reports, Minn. Stats. § 309.53; reports and records, Minn. Stats. § 349.19.
Sec 18-103 Inspection And Investigation Of Records
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 17/49
The city administrator or any peace officer acting under the direction of the city administrator or city council
may inspect and examine the records of any licensed organization which relate to bingo, raffles, or the
operation of gambling devices at any reasonable time without notice.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.100)
Sec 18-104 Use Of Receipts
No expense shall be incurred or amounts paid in connection with the conduct of bingo, raffles or the
operation of gambling devices, except those reasonably expended for supplies and equipment, prizes, rent,
city license fees, and compensation to persons lawfully hired to conduct or assist in conducting a bingo
occasion. Provided that no more than 70 percent of the gross profit less the tax imposed under Minn. Stats.
§ 297E.02, subd. 1, from bingo, and no more than 55 percent of the gross profit from other forms of lawful
gambling, may be expended for allowable expenses related to lawful gambling.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.110)
State Law reference — Use of gross receipts, Minn. Stats. § 349.15.
Sec 18-105 Use Of Profits
(a) Disaster relief. An organization may expend net profits from lawful gambling to relieve the effects of a
disaster as defined in Minn. Stats. § 12.03, subd. 2, without the prior approval of its membership if:
1. The contribution is a lawful purpose under Minn. Stats. § 349.12, subd. 25;
2. The contribution is authorized by the organization's chief executive officer and gambling
manager; and
3. The contribution is approved by the membership of the organization at its next regularly
scheduled monthly meeting.
If the contribution is not approved by the membership of the organization at its next regularly
scheduled monthly meeting, the organization shall reimburse its gambling account in the
amount of the contribution.
(b) Cash shortages. In computing gross profit to determine maximum amounts which may be expended
for allowable expenses under subdivision 1, an organization may not reduce its gross receipts by any
cash shortages. An organization may report cash shortages to the state gambling control board only
as an allowable expense. An organization may not report cash shortages in any fiscal year beginning
on July 1, 2004, that in total exceed three-tenths of one percent of the organization's gross receipts
from lawful gambling at each permitted premises where the organization conducts lawful gambling.
(c) Refunds and credits. For purposes of this section "gross profit" does not include any refund or credit
received under Minn. Stats. § 297.02, subd. 4, paragraph (d).
(d) Alternative premises payment. An organization eligible to expend gross profits on real estate taxes
and assessments under Minn. Stats. § 349.12, subd. 25, paragraph (a), clause (9), may in the
alternative, elect on a calendar year basis to pay itself up to $1,000.00 per month for the use of its
premises for lawful gambling. Any payments made under this subsection shall be considered an
allowable expense.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.120)
State Law reference — Use of gross receipts, Minn. Stats. § 349.15.
Sec 18-106 Exemptions
(a) Bingo, with the exception of linked bingo games, may be conducted by any fraternal, religious,
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_18_BUSINESSES 18/49
veterans or other nonprofit organization without obtaining the license required by section 18-95(a)
and without complying with the provisions of section 18-99(d) through (h) if conducted:
1. In connection with the county fair conducted by the county agricultural society or in connection
with a civic celebration recognized by resolution of the city council, provided that bingo shall
not be conducted for more than 12 consecutive days during any one county fair or recognized
civic celebration and is limited to no more than four separate applications for activities applied
for and approved in a calendar year; or
2. By an organization that conducts four or fewer bingo occasions in a calendar year.
An organization that holds a license to conduct lawful gambling under this article may not
conduct bingo under this subsection.
(b) Bingo may be conducted within a nursing home or a senior citizen housing project or by a senior
citizen organization if the prizes for a single bingo game do not exceed $10.00, total prizes awarded
at a single bingo occasion do not exceed $200.00, no more than two bingo occasions are held by the
organization or at the facility each week, only members of the organization or residents of the nursing
home or housing project are allowed to play in a bingo game, no compensation is paid for any
persons who conduct the bingo, and a manager is appointed to supervise the bingo. Bingo conducted
under this subsection is exempt from Minn. Stats. §§ 349.11—349.23, and the city may not require
an organization that conducts bingo under this subsection, or the manager who supervises the bingo,
to register or file a report with the city. The gross receipts from bingo conducted under the limitations
of this article are exempt from taxation under Minn. Stats. ch. 297A.
(Code 1996, § 5.12.130)
State Law reference — Exemptions and exclusions, Minn. Stats. § 349.166, subd. 1.
