Sec 30-158 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them
in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Abandoned motor vehicles.
(a) A motor vehicle shall be deemed to have been abandoned for the purposes of this article in
following circumstances:
1. It has been left unattended upon a street or highway in violation of a statutory law
ordinance regulating or prohibiting parking for a period of 24 hours;
2. It is left unaccompanied on property owned or operated by the city or on any street or high
for a period of not less than 48 hours or more than four hours on that property when
properly posted; or
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 13/25
3. It is left on private property:
a. That is single-family or duplex residential property which may be remo
immediately;
b. That is private, nonresidential property, properly posted which may be remo
immediately;
c. That is private, nonresidential property, not posted for 24 hours;
d. That is private, nonresidential property of an operator of an establishment for
servicing, repair, or maintenance of motor vehicles, five business days after notif
the vehicle owner by certified mail, return receipt requested, of the property own
intention to have the vehicle removed from the property; or
e. That is any residential property, properly posted which may be removed immedia
without the consent of the person in control of the property; and lacks vital compon
parts or is in an inoperable condition such that it has no substantial potential for fur
use consistent with its usual functions, unless it is kept in an enclosed garage
storage building.
(b) A classic car or pioneer car, as defined in Minn. Stats. § 168.10, is not considered an abando
vehicle.
(c) Vehicles on the premises of junkyards and automobile graveyards that are defined, maintained,
licensed in accordance with Minn. Stats. § 161.242, or that are licensed and maintained
accordance with local laws and zoning regulations, are not considered abandoned vehicles.
Derelict vehicle means a motor vehicle shall be deemed derelict for the purposes of this article if the
vehicle is inoperable, partially or wholly dismantled, wrecked, junked, or of similar condition for a period
exceeding 30 days.
Junked motor vehicle means a vehicle that:
(a) Is three years old or older;
(b) Is extensively damaged, with the damage including such things as broken or missing wheels, mo
drive train, or transmission;
(c) Is apparently inoperable;
(d) Does not have a valid, current registration plate; and
(e) Has an approximate fair market value equal only to the approximate value of the scrap in it.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 14/25
Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by
electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires except an electric personal assistive mobility device
or vehicles moved solely by human power.
Occupant means any person or legal entity owning or otherwise having control over any real property
within the city. For any real property which is vacant or otherwise not under the constant and obvious
control of any person or legal entity, the occupant shall be the person or legal entity named as the owner
of the real property on the records of the county treasurer. In the event the records of the county
treasurer cite more than one person and/or entity as owner of the real property, any or all of the persons
or entities cited shall be deemed the occupant in the absence of written evidence or documents verifying
a lack of control.
Vital component parts means those parts of a motor vehicle that are essential to the mechanical
functioning of the vehicle including but not limited to the motor, drive train and wheels and all
components thereof.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.010)
State Law reference — Definitions, Minn. Stats. § 169.01.
Sec 30-159 Declared A Health Hazard
For the purposes of this article, the city council authorizes the city administrator or his assigns, to declare
any abandoned, junked or derelict motor vehicle as defined in this article remaining on private property a
health hazard.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.020)
Sec 30-160 Duty Of Owner To Remove From Private Property
No person in charge or control of any property within the city whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or
otherwise, shall allow any abandoned, wrecked, junked, discarded, partially dismantled inoperable motor
vehicle to remain on such property. This section shall not apply to a vehicle in an enclosed building or
garage; a vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner, when
necessary to the operation of such business enterprise or a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or
depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.030)
Sec 30-161 Duty Of Owner To Remove From Public Property
If a motor vehicle is abandoned, junked or derelict on a public street or highway, or property owned or
maintained by the city, it shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner of such motor vehicle to cause the
removal thereof immediately.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.040)
Sec 30-162 Notification Of Violation
Upon receipt of a complaint concerning abandoned, junked or derelict vehicles, as defined in this article, the
city administrator or his assign shall investigate said complaint. If in his judgment a violation has occurred,
the city administrator or his assign shall cause the vehicle to be removed in the time periods stated in section
30-143 and cause to be delivered or mailed within five days to the owner and to all readily identifiable
lienholders of record of the motor vehicle and the owner of the property upon which the conditions exist a
notice stating the reasons why the conditions constitute a violation and that a hearing will be held before the
city administrator at a place therein fixed, not less than ten nor more than 30 days after the delivery or
mailing of the notice. The owner or any party in interest shall have the right to file an answer to the notice
and to appear in person, or otherwise, and give evidence at the place and time fixed in the notice. Any
person desiring to do so may attend such hearing and give evidence relevant to the matter being heard. The
rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in such hearings.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 15/25
(Code 1996, § 4.05.050)
Sec 30-163 Removal By City From Private Property
The chief of police or city administrator or their assigns, upon notice of violation, may cause a written notice
of such violation to be served upon the owner, tenant, occupant, lessee and/or owner of the motor vehicle as
per section 30-147, that such motor vehicle shall be removed after receipt of notice. Any motor vehicle not
removed after such notice shall be removed from such land to an impounding area heretofore designated by
the city and therein impounded.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.060)
Sec 30-164 Removal By City From Public Property
Whenever any motor vehicle is abandoned on a public street or highway, or on property owned or operated
by the city, any such vehicle may be removed and impounded under the direction of the chief of police or his
assigns after 48 hours to a storage garage or area as designated by the city council.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.070)
Sec 30-165 Reclamation
Upon notification by the police department, the owner of an impounded motor vehicle may, upon furnishing
satisfactory evidence of his identity and of his ownership of the vehicle, obtain a release from the police
department, and upon payment of towing and storing charges, and any fines or penalties, remove such
motor vehicle from the impounding area.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.080)
Sec 30-166 Sale Of Impounded Vehicles
(a) An impounded vehicle is eligible for disposal or sale under Minn. Stats. § 168B.08, 15 days after
notice to the owner, if the vehicle is determined to be:
1. A junk vehicle, except that it may have a valid, current registration plate and still be eligible for
disposal or sale under this division; or
2. An abandoned vehicle.
(b) If the owner of an impounded motor vehicle fails or refuses to pay the costs above mentioned or
should the identity or whereabouts of such owner be unknown and unascertainable after a diligent
search, and after written notice to him at his last known address if his identity is known, and to the
holder of any lien on record in the office of the state department of motor vehicles against such
vehicle, the chief of police or his assign may, after holding such vehicle for 30 days and after having
the value thereof and after giving 20 days notice to the state department of motor vehicles, such
notice to include all information which can be reasonably ascertained to identify such vehicle, dispose
of the same by private or public sale and shall forward the proceeds of such sale to the city treasurer.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.090)
Sec 30-167 Disposition Of Unsold Vehicles
Whenever any motor vehicle which has been removed pursuant to this division shall remain unsold for a
period of 60 days from and including the day of its removal, such vehicle may be destroyed or otherwise
disposed of by the city official charged with its safekeeping. Notice of any such destruction or disposition
shall be given to the state department of motor vehicles, such notice to include all information on which can
be reasonably ascertained to identify such vehicle.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.100)
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 16/25
Sec 30-168 Proceeds Of Sale
The proceeds of the sale of a motor vehicle covered in this article, after all costs of removal, storage,
investigation, and sale; and satisfaction of any liens of record on the vehicle have been paid; shall be held by
the city treasurer for up to 30 days and paid to the registered owner, after providing satisfactory evidence of
his identity upon demand. If the owner does not appear to claim the remainder of the proceeds within 30
days after disposal of the vehicle, the funds shall be deposited into the city general fund and the owner's
rights therein shall be forever extinguished.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.120)
Sec 30-169 Unlicensed Motor Vehicles
No person shall park, store, or leave or permit the parking or storage of any unlicensed motor vehicle of any
kind, for a period in excess of 48 hours, whether attended or not, upon any private property within the city,
unless the vehicle is enclosed within a building or garage, or further, is connected with and essential to the
operation of a business enterprise conducted in a lawful place and manner and properly licensed. The chief
of police, upon notice of a violation, may cause either personal or written notice of such violation to be
served upon the owner, tenant, occupant, lessee and/or the owner of the motor vehicle.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.130)
Sec 30-170 Trailers
The provisions of this article shall be applicable to trailers or wagons in a wrecked, junked, discarded,
abandoned, partially dismantled, inoperable, or otherwise derelict condition.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.140)
Sec 30-171 Immunity
Neither the city nor any person shall be held to answer in any civil or criminal action to any owner or other
person legally entitled to the possession of any abandoned, lost, or stolen vehicle for disposing of such
vehicle as contemplated by this section, so long as the city complies with the requirements of Minnesota
Statutes.
(Code 1996, § 4.05.160)
DIVISION 3 ABANDONED PROPERTY
Sec 30-187 Scope
Sec 30-188 Definitions
Sec 30-189 Administrative Procedures Authorized
Sec 30-190 Claims By Owner
Sec 30-191 Claim By Finder
Sec 30-192 Transfer Of Unclaimed Moneys To General Fund
Sec 30-193 Transfer To Disposal Of Dangerous Weapons

Sec 30-187 Scope
This division applies to all money and abandoned property that comes into the possession of the city in the
course of its municipal operations. This division does not apply to motor vehicles or animals.
(Ord. No. 103, § 1(3.14.010), 11-14-2005)
Sec 30-188 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 17/25
Abandoned property means tangible property, other than motor vehicles, that has come into the
possession of the city in the course of governmental operations or having been turned over to the city by
a person after being found on public or private property.
Dangerous Weapons means any firearm, whether loaded or unloaded, or any device designed as a
weapon and capable of producing death or great bodily harm, any combustible or flammable liquid or
other device or instrumentality that, in the manner it is used or intended to be used, is calculated or likely
to produce death or great bodily harm, or any fire that is used to produce death or great bodily harm.
(Ord. No. 103, § 1(3.14.020), 11-14-2005)
Sec 30-189 Administrative Procedures Authorized
The chief of police or his designee shall establish administrative provisions for receiving and safekeeping
money and abandoned property coming into possession of the city in the course of its municipal operations.
A receipt shall be issued to any person finding such abandoned property or money and causing it to be
delivered to the custody of the city. Such abandoned property shall be stored in a safe place and such
money deposited with the chief of police or his designee for a period of 60 days unless claimed by the true
owner. Upon expiration of the 60 day period, the unclaimed property or money shall be subject to disposal
under this chapter as abandoned property or money.
(Ord. No. 103, § 1(3.14.030), 11-14-2005)
Sec 30-190 Claims By Owner
During the 60 day period referred to in section 30-189, the chief of police or his designee shall deliver such
abandoned property or order such money paid to the true owner thereof upon satisfactory proof of
ownership, after ten days notice by mail to other persons who may have asserted a claim of true ownership.
In the event ownership cannot be determined to the satisfaction of the chief of police or his designee, he
may refuse to deliver such abandoned property or order the payment of such money to any person until
ordered to do so by a court.
(Ord. No. 103, § 1(3.14.040), 11-14-2005)
Sec 30-191 Claim By Finder
If the true owner does not claim the abandoned property or money during the 60 day period referred to in
section 30-189, the chief of police or his designee may in his sole discretion, release such abandoned
property or order such unclaimed money to be paid to the person who found same, if at the time of delivery
to the city such finder indicated in writing that he wished to assert a claim to the abandoned property or
money as a finder.
(Ord. No. 103, § 1(3.14.050), 11-14-2005)
Sec 30-192 Transfer Of Unclaimed Moneys To General Fund
If any money is not claimed by the true owner or transferred to the finder within the 60 day period referred to
in section 30-189, the chief of police or his designee, in his sole discretion, shall cause such money to be
transferred to the general fund.
(Ord. No. 103, § 1(3.14.060), 11-14-2005)
Sec 30-193 Transfer To Disposal Of Dangerous Weapons
If any dangerous weapon is not claimed by the true owner within the 60 day period referred to in section 30-
189, the chief of police or his designee, in his sole discretion, shall cause such dangerous weapon to:
(a) Be appropriated for utilization by the city's police department;
(b) Be sold or utilized by the Bureau of criminal apprehension or other law enforcement agency; or
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 18/25
(c) Be disposed of in such manner as the chief or police or his designee directs.
(Ord. No. 103, § 1(3.14.070), 11-14-2005)
Sec 30-194 Public Sale
(a) Upon expiration of the 60 day period referred to in section 30-189, abandoned property remaining in
the possession of the city shall in the sole discretion of the chief of police or his designee:
1. Be appropriated for the city's use;
2. Be determined to be of no value and disposed of in such manner as the chief or police or his
designee directs; or
3. Shall be sold at public sale by the chief of police or his designee.
The chief of police or his designee shall cause one week published notice of the public sale in
the official newspaper, describing therein the article to be sold and the date, time and place of
sale. Any abandoned property offered for public sale but not sold, and not suitable for
appropriation for city use, shall be deemed to be of no value and shall be summarily disposed
of according to the provisions of section 30-195.
(b) Upon completion of a public sale of abandoned property, the chief of police or his designee shall
cause the proceeds therefrom to be deposited in the city's general fund.
(Ord. No. 103, § 1(3.14.080), 11-14-2005)
Sec 30-195 Claim By Former Owner After Public Sale
The former true owner of abandoned property sold at public sale according to the provisions of section 30-
193, upon application to the chief of police or his designee within six months of the date of public sale and
upon furnishing satisfactory proof of former ownership, be paid the respective sale price proceeds from the
city's general fund. After such six month period, no such payments shall be made.
(Ord. No. 103, § 1(3.14.090), 11-14-2005)
Sec 30-196 Summary Disposal
The chief of police or his designee may, without notice and in such manner as he determines to be in the
public interest, dispose summarily of any property coming into his possession that he determines to be
dangerous or perishable. He shall make a record of the pertinent facts of the receipt and disposal of such
property.
(Ord. No. 103, § 1(3.14.100), 11-14-2005)
ARTICLE VII DUTCH ELM AND OAK WILT DISEASES
Sec 30-213 Declaration Of Policy
Sec 30-214 Forester Powers And Duties
Sec 30-215 Disease Program
Sec 30-216 Nuisance Declared
Sec 30-217 Inspection And Investigation
Sec 30-218 Abatement Of Diseases Creating Nuisances
Sec 30-219 Procedure For Removal Of Infected Trees And Wood
Sec 30-220 Spraying Trees; Notice Provisions
Sec 30-221 Transporting Of Elm Wood And Oak Wood; Prohibited
Sec 30-222 Interference; Prohibited
Sec 30-213 Declaration Of Policy
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 19/25
(a) It has been determined that the health and existence of the oak and elm trees within this city are
threatened by Dutch elm disease and oak wilt disease. It has further been determined that the loss of
elm trees and oak trees growing upon public and private property would substantially depreciate the
value of the property and impair the safety, good order, general welfare and convenience of the
public.
(b) It is declared to be the intention of the city council to control and prevent the spread of these
diseases, and this article is enacted for that purpose.
(Code 1996, § 8.08.010)
Sec 30-214 Forester Powers And Duties
(a) The position of forester is created and the powers and duties set forth in this article are made
attendant thereto.
(b) It is the duty of the forester to coordinate under the direction and control of the city council, all
activities of the municipality relating to the control and prevention of Dutch elm disease and oak wilt
disease. He shall recommend to the city council the details of a program for the control of Dutch elm
disease and oak wilt disease, and perform the duties incident to such a program adopted by the
county.
(Code 1996, § 8.08.020)
Sec 30-215 Disease Program
A program shall be conducted for the control of plant pests pursuant to the authority granted by Minn. Stats.
§ 18.022. This program is directed specifically at the control and elimination of Dutch elm disease fungus,
elm bark beetles, and oak wilt fungus and is undertaken at the recommendation of the commissioner of
agriculture and the city council in the conduct of this program.
(Code 1996, § 8.08.030)
Sec 30-216 Nuisance Declared
(a) The following things are public nuisances whenever they may be found within this jurisdiction:
1. Any living or standing elm tree or part thereof infected to any degree with the Dutch elm
disease fungus Ceratocystis Ulmi (Busiman) Moreau or which harbors any of the elm bark
beetles Scolytus Multistriatus (Eichh), or Hylungopinus Rufipes (Marsh).
2. Any dead elm tree or part thereof, including legs, branches, stumps, firewood or other elm
material from which the bark has not been removed and burned or sprayed with an effective
elm bark beetle insecticide.
3. Any living or standing oak tree or part thereof infected to any degree with the oak wilt disease
fungus Ceratocystis Fagacearum.
4. Any dead oak tree or part thereof, including legs, branches, stumps, firewood or other oak
material from which the fungus has not been removed and burned or sprayed with an
effective oak wilt eradicator.
(b) It is unlawful for any person to permit any public nuisance as defined in this section to remain on any
premises owned or controlled by him within this jurisdiction. Such nuisance may be abated in the
manner prescribed by this section.
(Code 1996, § 8.08.040)
Sec 30-217 Inspection And Investigation
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 20/25
(a) The forester shall inspect, by order of the city council, all premises and places within this jurisdiction
as often as practicable to determine whether any condition described in section 30-216 exists in this
jurisdiction. He shall investigate all reported incidents of infestation by Dutch elm fungus, elm bark
beetles, or oak wilt fungus.
(b) The forester or his duly authorized agent may enter upon private premises at any reasonable time for
the purpose of carrying out any of the duties assigned him under this section.
(c) The forester shall, upon finding conditions indicating Dutch elm infestation or oak wilt infestation,
immediately send appropriate specimens or samples to the commissioner of agriculture for analysis,
or take such other steps for diagnosis as may be recommended by the commissioner. Except as
provided in section 30-220 no action to remove infected trees or wood shall be taken until positive
diagnosis of the disease has been made.
(Code 1996, § 8.08.050)
Sec 30-218 Abatement Of Diseases Creating Nuisances
In abating the nuisances defined in section 30-216 the forester shall cause the infected tree or wood to be
sprayed, removed, burned or otherwise effectively treated so as to destroy and prevent as fully as possible
the spread of Dutch elm disease fungus, elm bark beetles, and oak wilt fungus. Such abatement procedures
shall be carried out in accordance with current technical and expert opinions and plans as may be
designated by the commissioner of agriculture.
(Code 1996, § 8.08.060)
Sec 30-219 Procedure For Removal Of Infected Trees And Wood
(a) Whenever the forester finds with reasonable certainty that the infestation defined in section 30-216
exists in any tree or wood in any public or private place in this jurisdiction, he shall proceed as
follows:
1. If the forester finds that the danger of infestation of other trees is not imminent because of
dormancy, he shall make a written report of his findings to the city council which shall proceed
by:
a. Abating the nuisance as a public improvement under Minn. Stats. ch. 429; or
b. Abating the nuisance as provided in subsection (a)(2) of this section.
2. If the forester finds that danger of infestation of other trees is imminent, he shall notify the
abutting property owner by certified mail that the nuisance shall be abated within a specified
time, not less than five days from the date of mailing of such notice. The forester shall
immediately report such action to the city council, and after the expiration of the time limited
by the notice he may abate the nuisance.
(b) Upon receipt of the forester's report required by subsection (a)(1) of this section, the city council shall
by resolution order the nuisance abated. Before action is taken on such resolution, the city council
shall publish notice of its intention to meet to consider taking action to abate the nuisance. This notice
shall be mailed to affected property owners and published once no less than one week prior to such
meeting. The notice shall state the time and place of the meeting, the streets affected, action
proposed, the estimated cost of abatement, and the proposed basis of assessment, if any, of costs.
At such hearing or adjournment thereof, the city council shall hear property owners with reference to
the scope and desirability of the proposed project. The city council shall thereafter adopt a resolution
confirming the original resolution with such modifications as it considers desirable and provide for the
doing of work by day labor or by contract.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 21/25
(c) The forester shall keep a record of the costs of abatements done under this section and shall report
monthly to the city administrator all work done for which assessments are to be made stating and
certifying the description of the land, lots, parcels involved and the amount chargeable to each.
(d) On or before September 1 of each year the city administrator shall list the total unpaid charges for
each abatement against each separate lot or parcel to which they are attributable under this section.
The city council may then spread the charges or any portion thereof against the property involved as
a special assessment under Minn. Stats. § 429.101 and other pertinent statutes for certification and
collection the following year along with current taxes.
(Code 1996, § 8.08.070)
Sec 30-220 Spraying Trees; Notice Provisions
(a) Whenever the forester determines that any elm or elm wood within this jurisdiction is infected with
Dutch elm fungus, he may spray all nearby high value elm trees, with an effective elm bark beetle
destroying concentrate. Spraying activities authorized by this section shall be conducted in
accordance with technical and expert opinions and plans of the commissioner of agriculture and
under the supervision of the commissioner and his agent whenever possible. This section shall
include the spraying of oak trees if appropriate under current technical practices.
(b) The notice provisions of section 30-220(a) apply to spraying operations conducted under this section.
(Code 1996, § 8.08.080)
Sec 30-221 Transporting Of Elm Wood And Oak Wood; Prohibited
It is unlawful for any person to transport within this jurisdiction any bark bearing elm wood or oak wood
without having obtained a permit from the forester. The forester shall grant such permits only when the
purposes of this article will be served thereby.
(Code 1996, § 8.08.090)
Sec 30-222 Interference; Prohibited
It is unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the forester or his agents while they engage in
the performance of duties imposed by this article.
(Code 1996, § 8.08.100)
ARTICLE VIII SHADE TREE PEST ORDINANCE: SHADE TREE PEST CONTROL

Sec 30-250 Declaration Of Policy
The health of the trees in the city is threatened by shade tree pests, and the loss or ill health of trees growing
upon public and private property substantially depreciates the value of property within the city and impairs
the safety, good order, general welfare and convenience of the public. In addition to and in accordance with
Minn. Stats. §§ 89.001, 89.01 and 89.51 through 89.64, the provisions of this section are adopted to attempt
to control and prevent the spread of these shade tree pests.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-251 Jurisdiction
The city shall have control of all street trees, shrubs, and other plantings now or hereafter in any street, park,
public right-of-way or easement, or other public place within the city limits, and shall have the power to plant,
care for, maintain, remove, and replace such trees, shrubs and other plantings.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-252 Declaration Of A Shade Tree Pest
The council may by resolution declare any vertebrate or invertebrate animal, plant pathogen, or plant
threatening to cause significant damage to a shade tree or community forest in the community, to be a
shade tree pest and prescribe control measures to effectively eradicate, control or manage the shade tree
pest including necessary time limits.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-253 Public Nuisances Declared
A shade tree pest declared by council occurring within a declared control zone is a public nuisance.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-254 Shade Tree Pest Nuisances Are Unlawful
It is unlawful for any person to permit any public nuisance as defined in this section to remain on any
premises the person owns or controls within the city. The nuisance may be abated as provided in this
section.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-255 Definition Of Control Areas
Upon declaring a shade tree pest, the council may by resolution define one or more locations within the
geographic boundaries of the city to be within a shade tree pest control area, provided such locations are
characterized by biologic, composition, environmental and size factors favorable to successful application of
the control measures prescribed by council.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-256 Tree Inspector
The council may appoint a tree inspector to coordinate the activities of the city relating to the control and
prevention of damage by shade tree pests. The tree inspector will recommend to the council the details of
any program for the declaration, control and prevention of shade tree pests. The tree inspector is authorized
to enforce or cause to be enforced the duties incident to such a program adopted by the council. The term
"tree inspector" includes any person designated by council or the tree inspector to carry out activities
authorized in this section.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-257 Abatement Of Shade Tree Pest Nuisances
(a) In abating a nuisance declared by resolution under sections 30-252 and 30-253, the organism,
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 23/25
condition or plant and any tree, wood or material identified as injurious to the health of shade trees
shall be removed or effectively treated so as to destroy and prevent as fully as possible the spread of
the shade tree pest. Such abatement procedures shall be carried out in accordance with the control
measures and areas prescribed by resolution according to sections 30-252 and 30-260 and 30-264.
(b) In addition, should the appropriate abatement procedure be removal and the tree(s) and/or hedge(s)
be within the limits of a highway under the city's jurisdiction, Minn. Stats. § 160.22 shall be complied
with as necessary.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-258 Reporting Discovery Of A Shade Tree Pest
Any owner or occupier of land or any person engaged in tree trimming or removal who becomes aware of
the existence of public nuisance caused by a shade tree pest as defined under section 30-252 shall report
the same to the city.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-259 Registration Of Tree Care Firms
Any person, firm or corporation that provides tree care, tree trimming or removal of trees, limbs, branches,
brush, or shrubs for hire must be registered with the Minnesota Commissioner of Agriculture under Minn.
Stats. § 18G.07.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-260 Inspection And Application Of Control Measures
(a) The tree inspector is authorized to cause premises and places within the city to be inspected to
determine whether shade tree pests exist thereon and to investigate all reported incidents of shade
tree pests. The tree inspector shall have the power to take all reasonable precautions to prevent the
maintenance of public nuisances and may enforce the provisions relating to abatement in this
section. Diagnosis of shade tree pests may be by the presence of commonly recognized symptoms
or by tests as may be recommended by the Commissioner of the Minnesota Department of
Agriculture or the Commissioner of the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources.
(b) Except in situations of imminent danger to human life and safety, the tree inspector shall not enter
private property for the purpose of inspecting or preventing maintenance of public nuisances without
the permission of the owner, resident or other person in control of the property, unless the tree
inspector has obtained a warrant or order from a court of competent jurisdiction authorizing the entry.
(c) No person, firm, or corporation shall interfere with the tree inspector acting under his authority while
engaged in activities authorized by this section.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-261 Standard Abatement Procedure
(a) Whenever a tree inspector determines with reasonable certainty that a public nuisance as described
by this section is being maintained or exists on premises in the city, the tree inspector shall notify in
writing the owner of record or occupant of the premises of such fact and order that the nuisance be
terminated or abated. A copy of the notice shall be filed with the city clerk.
(b) The notice of abatement shall state that unless the owner thereof shall cause the abatement of the
public nuisance, the public nuisance shall be abated by the city at the expense of the owner. The
notice shall specify the steps to be taken to abate the nuisance, provide 30 days to abate the
nuisance, and state the appeal procedure provided in section 30-262.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 24/25
(c) The notice must also state that within the 30 days allotted after the posting or mailing of the notice to
abate the nuisance, the owner, agent of the owner, or individual in possession of the affected
property shall remove and abate such nuisance or show that no nuisance in fact exists. Such
showing shall be in writing and filed with the city clerk.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-262 Appeal Procedure
The owner or occupant served with the notice to abate the nuisance may, within seven calendar days after
receipt of such notice, make a written demand to the city clerk for a hearing on the question of whether a
tree pest in fact exists. The hearing shall be held within seven calendar days following receipt by the clerk of
the written demand. At least three days' notice shall be given to the individual who made the written demand
for the hearing. The council may modify the notice or extend the time by which abatement must be
completed. Each owner, agent of the owner, occupant and lienholder, if any, of the subject property or
properties shall be given the opportunity to present evidence at the hearing.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-263 Abatement By City
If the notice of abatement and its prescribed control measures are not complied with within the time provided
by the notice of abatement or any additional time granted, the tree inspector or designated person shall have
the authority to obtain an administrative search warrant, enter the property and carry out abatement in
accordance with council's declared control measures and the notice of abatement.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-264 Abatement Procedure In Event Of Imminent Danger; Summary Enforcement
If the tree inspector determines that the danger of infestation to other shade trees is imminent and delay in
control measures may put public health, safety or welfare in immediate danger, the tree inspector may
proceed according to this section.
(a) The tree inspector shall determine all trees to be affected by any appropriate control measures and
notify by certified mail any reasonably knowable owner and occupant of property or properties on
whose land every such tree is located.
(b) The notice shall state that a public nuisance exists or is being maintained on premises in the city and
that delay in abatement of the nuisance will unreasonably endanger public health, safety or welfare.
The notice shall state the nuisance found, the control measure required, provide the nuisance must
be abated within a specified time, not less than five calendar days from the day of mailing such
notice, and the time and place of the city council meeting to consider the question of summary
enforcement. The notice and proposed action shall be reported in writing to the council.
(c) The city council shall determine whether or not the condition identified in the notice to the owner or
occupant is a nuisance, whether public health, safety or welfare will be unreasonably endangered by
delay in abatement required to complete the procedure set forth in section 30-262, and may order
that the nuisance be immediately terminated or abated. If the nuisance is not immediately terminated
or abated, the city council may abate the nuisance. After the expiration of the time provided on the
original mailing, the nuisance may be abated.
(d) Immediate abatement. Nothing in this section shall prevent the city, without notice or other process,
from immediately abating any condition which poses an imminent and serious hazard to human life or
safety.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-265 Recovery Of Cost Of Abatement; Liability And Assessment
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_30_ENVIRONMENT 25/25
(a) The owner of premises on which a nuisance has been abated by the city shall be personally liable for
the cost to the city of the abatement, including administrative costs. As soon as the work has been
completed and the cost determined, the city clerk or other official shall prepare a bill for the cost and
mail it to the owner. Thereupon the amount shall be immediately due and payable at the office of the
city clerk.
(b) After notice and hearing as provided in Minn. Stats. § 429.061, as it may be amended from time to
time, the city clerk shall, on or before September 1 next following abatement of the nuisance, list the
total unpaid charges along with all other charges as well as other charges for current services to be
assessed under Minn. Stats. § 429.101 against each separate lot or parcel to which the charges are
attributable. The city council may then certify the charges against the property under that statute and
other pertinent statutes to the county auditor for collection along with current taxes the following year
or in annual installments as the city council may determine in each case.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)
Sec 30-266 Penalty
(a) Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be
guilty of a misdemeanor. The penalty which may be imposed for any crime which is a misdemeanor
under this section, including Minnesota Statutes specifically adopted by reference, shall be a
sentence of not more than 90 days or a fine of not more than $1,000.00, or both.
(b) Upon conviction of a misdemeanor, the costs of prosecution may be added. A separate offense shall
be deemed committed upon each day during which a violation occurs or continues.
(c) The failure of any officer or employee of the city to perform any official duty imposed by this section
shall not subject the officer or employee to the penalty imposed for a violation.
(d) In addition to any penalties provided for in this section, if any person, firm or corporation fails to
comply with any provision of this section, the city council or any official designated by it, may institute
appropriate proceedings at law or at equity to restrain, correct or abate the violation.
(Ord. No. 138-09, 5-26-2009)

Chapter 34 FINANCE AND TAXATION

Sec 34-19 Authority And Purpose
The city divides all lands lying within the municipal boundaries of the city into two districts: an urban
service district and a rural service district, constituting separate taxing districts for the purpose of all
municipal property taxes excepting those taxes levied for the payment of bonds and/or judgments and
any interest accruing on either, pursuant to the provisions of Minn. Stats. § 272.67.
(Code 1996, § 3.04.010)
State Law reference — Authority to create, Minn. Stats. § 272.67.
Sec 34-20 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Lot means an area of land separately described in or on a plat.
Parcel means an unplatted area of land having a separate legal description on record in the office of
the county recorder of Chisago County, Minnesota.
Plat or platted means all lands included within a plat which have been approved and recorded
pursuant to the Minn. Stats. ch. 505.
Special assessments means assessments that get levied against land by the city for municipal
improvements pursuant to the Minn. Stats. ch. 429.
Unavailable to water or sewer means any parcel or lot so situated that it cannot be connected to
either the municipal water or sewer system unless the city physically extends those systems.
(Code 1996, § 3.04.020)
Sec 34-21 Urban Service District
The urban service district shall include and consist of all lands now or hereafter lying within the municipal
boundaries of said city, except those lands described or otherwise included in section 34-22.
(Code 1996, § 3.04.030)
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_34_FINANCE_AND_TAXATION 2/4
State Law reference — Urban service districts, Minn. Stats. § 272.67, subd. 2.
Sec 34-22 Rural Service District
(a) The rural service district includes those lands which, in the judgment of the city council, are rural
in character and are not developed for commercial, industrial or urban residential purposes and
for these reasons are not benefited to the same degree as other lands by municipal services
financed by general taxation.
(b) The rural service district need not be contiguous but may consist of isolated parcels, or groups of
parcels, which qualify for inclusion in the district.
(c) Lands situated and meeting the following characteristics may be included in the rural service
district:
1. Any parcel which:
a. Is not less than six acres in area;
b. Is not subject to any special assessments;
c. Is unavailable to water and sewer; and
d. Otherwise meets one of the following categories:
i. Is vacant and is not used for any commercial or industrial purpose;
ii. Has located thereon not more than one residential dwelling (including other
buildings incidental thereto) and is used exclusively for residential
purposes;
iii. Has located thereon farm dwellings and farm buildings and is utilized
exclusively for agricultural purposes.
2. Any lands which were platted within two years prior to their annexation to the city and
which:
a. Contain no permanent improvements;
b. Are not subject to special assessments; and
c. Are unavailable to water and sewer provided that any lands qualifying for this
category shall be converted and transferred to the urban service district three
years following the date said lands were annexed to the city or pursuant to section
34-23, whichever occurs first.
(d) No lands included within the municipal boundaries of the city upon the date of adoption of the
ordinances codified in this chapter shall qualify for the rural service district.
(e) The following described lands are included in the rural service district: Those lands described in
schedule B which is on file in the office of the city administrator.
(f) Schedule B, which is on file in the office of the city administrator, may be amended only in writing
by resolution of the city council.
(Code 1996, § 3.04.040)
State Law reference — Rural service districts, Minn. Stats. § 272.67, subd. 2.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_34_FINANCE_AND_TAXATION 3/4
Sec 34-23 Conversion Of Lands
Lands included in the rural service district shall be transferred to the urban service district upon the
happening or occurrence of any of the following events:
(a) When any lot in a qualifying plat:
1. Is developed by the construction, erection or placement of a permanent structure;
2. Is subject to special assessments;
3. Is available to the municipal water and/or sewer systems;
4. Is utilized for any commercial or industrial purpose.
Upon the happening of any one of the cited events or occurrences, the entire plat shall be
transferred to the urban service district;
(b) When any qualifying parcel ceases to comply with each and every requirement of the category in
which it is included;
(c) When any lot or parcel has been the subject of a conditional use permit or a variance granted
under the provisions of the city zoning and/or subdivision ordinances.
(Code 1996, § 3.04.050)
Sec 34-24 Annexed Land
(a) Any and all lands hereafter annexed to or otherwise included within the municipal boundaries of
the city shall be deemed to be included in the urban service district except such lands as are
described in an amendment to schedule B attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter and
on file in the office of the city administrator.
(b) The city council may, at its discretion, and where deemed appropriate, make a preliminary
determination as to the classification of any land or lands for which annexation is contemplated
so as to permit the owners of such land to know how the lands will be classified if annexed;
however, after annexation, such lands shall be thereafter classified in accordance with the terms
of this article.
(Code 1996, § 3.04.060)
Sec 34-25 Taxing Ratio
(a) The lands in the rural services district shall be hereafter taxed at 70 percent of the tax imposed
upon lands in the urban service district, except as to those taxes levied for the payment of bonds
and/or judgments and interest accruing thereon.
(b) Following published notice and a hearing, the city council may adjust the percentage by which
lands in the rural service district are taxed compared to lands in the urban service district. Any
such adjustment shall constitute an amendment of this chapter.
(Code 1996, § 3.04.070)
Sec 34-26 Threshold Requirements For Credits Or Beneficial Tax Classification; Urban Service
District
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_34_FINANCE_AND_TAXATION 4/4
Hereafter no lands contained in the urban service district shall be construed as qualifying for any credit,
e.g., wetlands credit (Minn. Stats. § 273.115) or native prairie credit (Minn. Stats. § 273.111) or private
outdoor recreational tracts (Minn. Stats. § 273.112) nor for any preferential classification, e.g.,
agricultural property tax (Minn. Stats. § 273.111) or private outdoor recreational tracts unless each
parcel so qualifying consists of or is contained within a single legal description separately assessed for
tax purposes, each meeting or exceeding the minimum size or acreage requirements as to each such
parcel.
(Code 1996, § 3.04.080)

Sec 34-56 Annual Audit
There shall be an annual audit of the city's financial affairs by the state auditor or a public accountant in
accordance with minimum auditing procedures prescribed by the state auditor.
(Code 1996, § 3.12.010)
State Law reference — Annual audit, Minn. Stats. § 6.55.
Sec 34-57 Fee Schedule
(a) In accordance with state statutes and regulations, the city will adopt a fee schedule that outlines
the fees for various permits, licenses and services. The fees are established to cover the cost of
investigation, issuance and enforcement of required licenses, permits or services provided by the
city.
(b) The fee schedule for various permits, licenses and services rendered by the city will be adopted
by ordinance and will be on file in the city clerk's office. The fee schedule will be reviewed on an
annual basis.
(Code 1996, §§ 3.14.010, 3.14.020)

Chapter 38 FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION

Sec 38-1 Rules And Fire Code Adopted By Reference

reference and made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth at this point.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.110)
State Law reference — Minnesota Uniform Fire Code, Minn. Stats. § 299F.011; Wildfire Act, Minn.

ARTICLE II OPEN BURNING
Sec 38-21 Purpose

Sec 38-21 Purpose
The purpose of this article is to establish permitted categories of open burn events for the residences
and farms within the city and provide for a permitting process for residential and agricultural open
burning, except when such open burning is defined as a "camp or recreational fire" as prescribed in this
article.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.010)
Sec 38-22 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_38_FIRE_PREVENTION_AND_PROTECTION 2/8
Camp fire means a fire set for cooking, warming, or ceremonial purposes, which is not more than
three feet in diameter by three feet high, and has had the ground five feet from the base of the fire
cleared of all combustible material.
Open fire or open burning means a fire burning in matter, whether concentrated or dispersed, which
is not contained within a fully enclosed fire box, structure or vehicle, and from which the products of
combustion are emitted directly to the open atmosphere without passing through a stack, duct, or
chimney.
Recreation fire same definition as "camp fire."
Starter fuels means dry, untreated, unpainted wood or charcoal fire starter. Paraffin candles and
alcohols are permitted as starter fuels and as aids to ignition only. Propane gas torches or other
clean gas burning devices causing minimal pollution must be used to start an open fire.
Wood means dry, clean fuel only such as twigs, branches, limbs, "presto logs," charcoal, cordwood,
or untreated dimensional lumber. "Wood" does not include wood that is green, with leaves or
needles, rotten, wet, oil soaked, or treated with paint, fuel or preservatives.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.020)
Sec 38-23 Recreation Fires
(a) Recreation fire site requirements. The site requirements for a recreation fire is an area of no
more than a three foot in diameter circle (measured from the inside of the fire ring or border)
completely surrounded by noncombustible and nonsmoke or odor producing material, either of
natural rock, cement, brick, tile or block of ferrous metal only and which area is depressed below
ground, on the ground, or on a raised bed. Included are permanent outdoor wood burning fire
places. Recreation fire sites shall not be located closer than 50 feet to any structure other than
structures owned by the individual burning. Burners are not a recreational fire site as defined
herein.
(b) Recreation fire burn requirements. When a camp fire is used for recreation purposes, it must be
ignited with an approved starter fluid using dry, clean wood; producing little detectable smoke,
odor, or soot beyond the property line; conducted with an adult tending the fire at all times;
extinguished completely before quitting the occasion; and respecting weather conditions,
neighbors, burning bans, and air quality so that nuisance, health, or safety hazards will not be
created. Mobile cooking devices such as manufactured hibachis, charcoal grills, wood smokers,
and propane or natural gas devices are not defined as camp or recreation fires.
(c) Other recreation fire fuels. Clean pallets may be used for recreation fires when cut into three-foot
lengths.
(Code 1996, §8.20.020)
Sec 38-24 Prohibited Materials
(a) No person shall conduct, cause, or permit open burning of oils, petro fuels, rubber, plastics,
chemically treated materials, or other materials which produce excessive or noxious smoke such
as tires, railroad ties, treated, painted or glued wood, composite shingles, tar paper, insulation,
composition board, sheetrock, wiring paint, or paint fillers.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_38_FIRE_PREVENTION_AND_PROTECTION 3/8
(b) No person shall conduct, cause, or permit open burning of hazardous waste or salvage
operations, or open burning of solid waste generated from an industrial or manufacturing process
or from a service or commercial establishment or building material generated from demolition of
commercial or institutional structures.
(c) No person shall conduct, cause, or permit open burning of discarded material resulting from the
handling, processing, storage, preparation, serving, or consumption of food.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.030)
Sec 38-25 Permit Required For Open Burning
No person shall start or allow any open burning on any property in the city without first having obtained
an open burn permit, except that a permit is not required for any fire which is a camp or recreation fire as
defined herein.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.040)
Sec 38-26 Guidelines For Open Burning
It is not the intent of this chapter to promote open burning. Alternative methods such as composting and
recycling must always be given consideration.
(a) If alternative methods of disposal are not available, burning, with a permit, is allowed for:
1. Disposal of vegetative matter for managing forest, prairie, or wildlife habitat, and in the
development and maintenance of land and rights-of-way where chipping, composting,
land spreading or other alternative methods are not practical.
2. Disposal of diseased trees generated on site, diseased or infected nursery stock,
diseased beehives, and approved agricultural practices.
3. Ground thawing for utility repair and construction.
4. Disposal of unpainted, untreated, nonglued lumber and wood shakes where recycling,
reuse, removal, or other alternative disposal methods are not practical.
(b) Fire training and permanent burn site permits can only be issued by the state department of
natural resources (DNR) forest officers.
(c) No fire may be allowed to smolder.
(d) Burning is not allowed within 300 feet of any structure. Permits within 300 feet of any structure
may be given consideration by the fire chief if written consent of all structure owners is presented
at the time of application.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.050)
Sec 38-27 Permit Application For Open Burning
Open burning permits shall be obtained by making application on a form prescribed by the DNR and
adopted by the city. The permit application shall be presented to the city staff person designated by the
city administrator for reviewing and processing said application.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.060)
Sec 38-28 Permit Holder Responsibility
(a) Prior to starting an open burn, the permit holder shall be responsible for confirming that no
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_38_FIRE_PREVENTION_AND_PROTECTION 4/8
burning ban or air quality alter is in effect. Every open burn event shall be constantly attended by
the permit holder or his competent representative. The open burning site shall have available
appropriate communication and fire suppression equipment as set out in the fire safety plan. The
open burn fire shall be completely extinguished before the permit holder or his representative
leaves the site. It is the responsibility of the permit holder to have a valid permit, as required by
this section, available for inspection on the site by the police department, fire department, or
DNR forest/conservation officer.
(b) The permit holder is responsible for compliance and implementation of all general conditions,
special conditions, and the burn event safety plan as established in the permit issued. The permit
holder shall be responsible for all costs incurred as a result of the burn including, but not limited
to, fire suppression and administrative fees.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.070)
Sec 38-29 Revocation Of Open Burning Permit
The open burning permit is subject to revocation at the discretion of DNR forest/conservation office or
the city fire chief. Reasons for revocation include, but are not limited to, a fire hazard exists or develops
during the course of the burn, any of the conditions of the permit being violated during the course of the
burn, pollution, or nuisance conditions developing during the course of the burn, or a fire smoldering with
no flame present.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.080)
Sec 38-30 Denial Of Open Burning Permit
If established criteria for the issuance of an open burning permit are not met or during review of said
application, it is determined that a practical alternative method of disposal of the material exists, or a
pollution or nuisance condition would result, or if a burn event safety plan cannot be drafted to the
satisfaction of the fire chief, then a city staff person may deny the open burning permit application.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.090)
Sec 38-31 Burning Ban Or Air Quality Alter
No camp or recreation or open burn will be permitted when the city or DNR has officially declared a
burning ban due to potential hazardous fire conditions or when the MPCA has declared an air quality
alter.
(Code 1996, § 8.20.100)
Sec 38-32 Nuisances
(a) A permit issued pursuant to this ordinance shall not be deemed to authorize burning which is in
fact a nuisance and compliance with a permit is not a defense to a claim that the fire in fact
creates a nuisance.
(b) Nuisance fires. The following are nuisances and may be extinguished immediately by city staff
without notice:
1. Open burning in violation of this chapter;
2. Open burning which because of changes in weather or other conditions creates a risk to
public health or safety;
3. Open burning which unreasonably interferes with the enjoyment of another person or of
the other person's property or public property.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_38_FIRE_PREVENTION_AND_PROTECTION 5/8
(Ord. No. 111, § 1, 12-11-2006)
ARTICLE III FIREWORKS
Sec 38-51 License Required
Sec 38-52 Application
Sec 38-53 Fees
Sec 38-51 License Required
No person shall use or explode any fireworks as defined in Minn. Stats. § 624.20 without a license.
(Code 1996, § 8.04.010)
State Law reference — Public display license, Minn. Stats. § 624.22.
Sec 38-52 Application
Every application for such a license shall be made in writing to the city administrator at least 15 days in
advance of the date of the display. The application shall be promptly referred to the fire marshal, who
shall make an investigation to determine whether the operator of the display is competent and whether
the display is of such a character and is to be so located, discharged, or fired that it will not be
hazardous to property or endanger any person. The fire marshal shall report the results of this
investigation to the city administrator and if he reports that in his opinion the operator is competent and
that the display as planned will conform to safety requirements, including the rules and regulations of the
state fire marshal, the city administrator shall issue a license for the display.
(Code 1996, § 8.04.020)
Sec 38-53 Fees
The license shall not be issued until a fee, set by city council in the fee schedule which is on file in the
city clerk's office, is paid for each day of display.
(Code 1996, § 8.04.010)
ARTICLE IV FEES FOR EMERGENCY FIRE SERVICES
Sec 38-61 Definitions
Sec 38-62 Service Fees
Sec 38-63 Approval Of Fees
Sec 38-64 Billing And Collection
Sec 38-65 Mutual Aid Agreement
Sec 38-66 Application Of Collections To Budget
Sec 38-61 Definitions
For purposes of this article IV the terms below shall have the following meanings:
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_38_FIRE_PREVENTION_AND_PROTECTION 6/8
Fire protection contract means a contract between the city and a town or other city for the city to
provide fire service.
Fire service means any deployment of City of North Branch fire fighting personnel and/or equipment
to extinguish a fire or perform any preventive measure in an effort to protect equipment, life, or
property in an area threatened by fire. It also includes the deployment of fire fighting personnel
and/or equipment to provide fire suppression, rescue, extrication, and any other services related to
fire and rescue as may occasionally occur.
Fire service charge means the charge imposed by the city for receiving fire service.
Motor vehicle means any self-propelled vehicle designed and originally manufactured to operate
primarily upon public roads and highways, and not operated exclusively upon railroad tracks. It
includes semitrailers. It does not include snowmobiles, manufactured homes, all terrain vehicles, or
park trailers.
Mutual aid agreement means an agreement between the city and a town or other city for the city's
fire department to provide assistance to the fire department of a town or other city
(Ord. No. 127-09, § 1, 2-9-2009)
Sec 38-62 Service Fees
The city council hereby establishes fees for fire service as follows:
(a) False alarms. Fees for response to false fire alarms and false carbon monoxide alarms will be
charged to the property owner for an incident after the second call to the property within any 12-
month period. A standard fee shall be charged based on the actual cost of responding to an
emergency incident. The average fee shall include the manpower costs for two hours minimal
and apparatus costs based on one truck for two minimal hours. Initially this fee will be
$____________.
(b) Chemical/hazardous materials spills/gas leaks. Fees for response to chemical spills on roadway
and at fixed private facilities within the City of North Branch will be charged to the owner of the
chemical, the owner of the motor vehicle in which the chemical is being shipped or is a part
thereof, or to the owner of the facility where the spill occurred.
1. Fees shall include, but shall not be limited to, actual manpower costs for all personnel that
respond to the incident (minimum of two hours) and the cost on a per hour basis for each
fire apparatus or other city mechanical equipment that responds to the incident (minimum
of two hours per unit).
2. In addition, the bill for service shall include any cost of clean-up of any contaminated
equipment and/or repair of any equipment damaged during the incident or its
replacement, along with replacement of any disposable equipment, supplies and/or
communication equipment, and administrative costs to be established at ten percent of
the total bill.
(c) Fire watch. Fees for personnel to stand by on fire watch due to unusual fire hazards, while
waiting for the property owner or his, her or its agent to respond to the scene following a fire
incident and/or fire alarm, may be billed to the owner of the property on a per hour basis with a
two-hour minimum. If a fire watch is established at a property, the watch shall be maintained until
the owner of the property or his, her or its agent arrives at the property and takes over
responsibility for monitoring fire safety.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_38_FIRE_PREVENTION_AND_PROTECTION 7/8
(d) Preventive fire watch. When fire department personnel provide fire watch pursuant to Fire
Prevention Bureau Policy, State of Minnesota, the fees for such personnel may be billed to the
owner of the property on a per hour basis with a two-hour minimum. Preventive fire watch is
required, pursuant to Fire Prevention Bureau, State of Minnesota, in any place of assembly or
any place where people congregate where public safety is at risk due to the number of persons,
or the nature of the performance, exhibition, display, contest, or activity, or due to unusual fire
hazards
(e) Extrication. Fees for extrication shall be established by city council fee schedule. Initially such fee
shall be $____________.
(Ord. No. 127-09, § 1, 2-9-2009)
Sec 38-63 Approval Of Fees
At least annually, the fire chief shall recommend to the city administrator for approval by the city council
the fees to be charged under this article IV and such fees as approved by the city council shall be
included in the city's fee schedule.
(Ord. No. 127-09, § 1, 2-9-2009)
Sec 38-64 Billing And Collection
(a) Parties requesting and receiving fire services may be billed directly by the city. Additionally, if the
party receiving fire services did not request services but a fire or other situation exists which, at
the discretion of the fire department personnel in charge requires fire service, the party will be
charged and billed. All parties will be billed whether or not the fire service is covered by
insurance. Any billable amount of the fire charge not covered by a party's insurance remains a
debt of the party receiving the fire service.
(b) Parties billed for fire service will have 30 days to pay. If the fire service charge is not paid by that
time, it will be considered delinquent and the city will send a notice of delinquency.
(c) If the fire service charge remains unpaid for 30 days after this notice of delinquency is sent, the
city will use all practical and reasonable legal means to collect the fire service charge. The party
receiving fire service shall be liable for all collection costs incurred by the city including, but not
limited to, reasonable attorney's fees and court costs.
(d) If the fire service charge remains unpaid for 30 days after the notice of delinquency is sent, the
city council may also, on or before October 15 of each year, certify the unpaid fire service charge
to the county auditor in which the recipient of the services owns real property for collection with
property taxes. The county auditor is responsible for remitting to the city all charges collected on
behalf of the city. The city must give the property owner notice of its intent to certify the unpaid
fire service charge by September 15.
(Ord. No. 127-09, § 1, 2-9-2009)
Sec 38-65 Mutual Aid Agreement
When the city fire department provides fire service to another fire department pursuant to a mutual aid
agreement or fire protection contract the billing will be determined by the mutual aid agreement or fire
protection contract.
(Ord. No. 127-09, § 1, 2-9-2009)
Sec 38-66 Application Of Collections To Budget
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_38_FIRE_PREVENTION_AND_PROTECTION 8/8
All collected fire charges will be city funds and used to offset the expenses of the city fire department in
providing fire services.
(Ord. No. 127-09, § 1, 2-9-2009)

Chapter 42 MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES

ARTICLE II WEAPONS
Sec 42-19 Definitions
Sec 42-20 Weapons Prohibited
Sec 42-21 Minors Under Age Of 18 Years; Parental Consent And Supervision Required
