Sec 42-19 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them
in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Deadly weapons means and includes the following:
(a) All firearms;
(b) Bows and arrows when the arrows are pointed or tipped;
(c) Sand clubs;
(d) Metal knuckles; and
(e) Daggers, dirks, stilettoes, a switch blade knife, spring blade knife, or push button knife, or figure
discs with sharpened points or edges (commonly known as throwing stars).
(Code 1996, § 9.12.010)
Sec 42-20 Weapons Prohibited
(a) No person shall keep, carry, or have in his possession, concealed or otherwise, any deadly weapon
when on any public street or in any public place, or when they are trespassing upon the premises or
property of another person, within the city. This does not apply to military or police personnel
engaged in their duties, or those who hold permits to possess and carry on their person said weapon.
Nor does this apply to the owners of weapons used for hunting or other recognized recreational uses
and are carried unloaded and in vehicles or otherwise not on their person.
(b) The aiming of any deadly weapon, whether loaded or unloaded, at or toward any human being is
prohibited.
(c) All instruments used to expel at high velocity any pellets of any kind including, but not limited to, BB
guns, air rifles, and sling shots, shall not be discharged within 500 feet of any dwelling occupied by
humans or animals.
(Code 1996, § 9.12.020)
State Law reference — Carrying weapons permit, Minn. Stats. § 624.714.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_42_MISCELLANEOUS_OFFENSES 2/11
Sec 42-21 Minors Under Age Of 18 Years; Parental Consent And Supervision Required
(a) No person shall sell, give, loan, or furnish in any way any deadly weapon to a minor under the age 18
years without the written consent of his parent or guardian, or of a police officer or magistrate.
(b) No minor shall handle, have in his possession, or under his control any deadly weapon unless
accompanied by or under the immediate charge of his parent or guardian.
(Code 1996, § 9.12.030)
Sec 42-22 Minors Under Age Of 14 Years; Guidelines; Violation Constitutes Misdemeanor
(a) It is unlawful for any minor under the age of 14 years of age to handle, or have in his possession or
under his control, except while accompanied by or under the immediate charge of his parents or
guardian, any firearm, air gun, or BB gun of any kind for hunting or target practice or any other
purpose, within the city.
(b) Any person aiding or knowingly permitting any such minor, as mentioned in subsection (a) of this
section violates the same and shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(Code 1996, § 9.12.040)
Sec 42-23 Aiming Or Pointing Weapons Prohibited
No person shall, within the city, aim or point any firearm, air gun or BB gun, of any kind, whether loaded or
not, at or towards another human being, except it be in defense of person or property against one
committing or attempting to commit a felony.
(Code 1996, § 9.12.050)
Sec 42-24 Defense; Exception
Nothing in this article shall apply to any firing of a gun or use of other weapons by police personnel or private
citizens when done in the lawful defense of one's self, family, or other persons.
(Code 1996, § 9.12.060)
ARTICLE III CURFEW
Sec 42-52 Established, Hours; Application
Sec 42-53 Unlawful For Parent Or Guardian To Permit Violation Of Curfew
Sec 42-54 Designation Of School Nights
Sec 42-55 Violations Constitutes Misdemeanor
Sec 42-52 Established, Hours; Application
It is unlawful for any minor under the age of 17 years to loiter, idle or be in or upon the public streets,
highways, parks, playgrounds, public place, places of entertainment or refreshment or any other
unsupervised places within the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. the following day;
provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to such minor accompanied by his or
her parent, guardian or other person having the care and custody of the minor or when the minor is upon
some necessary errand by permission or direction of the parent, which permission shall be in writing and
signed by such parent, guardian or other adult having the care and custody of the minor.
(Code 1996, § 9.16.010)
Sec 42-53 Unlawful For Parent Or Guardian To Permit Violation Of Curfew
It is unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the
age of 17 years of age to permit such minor to loiter, idle or be in or upon the public grounds, public places,
places of entertainment or refreshment or other unsupervised places within this city between the hours of
10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. of the following day; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_42_MISCELLANEOUS_OFFENSES 3/11
apply when the minor is accompanied by his or her parent, guardian or other adult person having the care
and custody of the minor or when the minor is upon some necessary errand by permission or direction of his
or her parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor.
(Code 1996, § 9.16.020)
Sec 42-54 Designation Of School Nights
The mayor of the city may designate certain nights during the school year as school nights. The provisions of
this article shall not apply to any student under the ages of 17 years or to his or her parent, guardian or other
adult person having the care and custody of the minor who is lawfully going to, attending, or returning from
any school function or any designated school night.
(Code 1996, § 9.16.030)
Sec 42-55 Violations Constitutes Misdemeanor
Any minor under the age of 17 years or any parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and
custody of a minor under the age of 17 years who shall violate the provisions of this article shall upon
conviction thereof be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished according to law.
(Code 1996, § 9.16.040)
ARTICLE IV DRUG LABS AND CHEMICAL DUMP SITES
DIVISION 42-IV-1 GENERALLY
DIVISION 2 ADMINISTRATION
DIVISION 42-IV-1 GENERALLY
Sec 42-85 Definitions
Sec 42-86 Purpose And Intent
Sec 42-87 Interpretation And Application
Sec 42-88 Fees
Sec 42-85 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them
in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_42_MISCELLANEOUS_OFFENSES 4/11
Chemical dumpsite means any place or area where chemicals or other waste materials used in a
clandestine drug lab have been located.
Child means any person less than 18 years of age.
Clandestine drug lab means the unlawful manufacture or attempt to manufacture controlled substances.
Clandestine drug lab site means any place or area where law enforcement has determined that
conditions associated with the operation of an unlawful clandestine drug lab exist. A clandestine drug lab
site may include dwellings, accessory buildings, accessory structures, a chemical dumpsite or any land.
Controlled substance means a drug, substance or immediate precursor in Schedules I through V of
Minn. Stats. § 152.02. The term shall not include distilled spirits, wine, malt beverages, intoxicating
liquors or tobacco.
Household hazardous wastes means waste generated from a clandestine drug lab. Such wastes shall
be treated, stored, transported or disposed of in a manner consistent with state department of health,
Minnesota Pollution Control Agency, and Chisago County Health Department rules and regulations.
Manufacture, in places other than a pharmacy, means and includes the production, cultivation, quality
control, and standardization, by mechanical, physical, chemical or pharmaceutical means, packing,
repacking, tableting, encapsulating, labeling, relabeling, filling, or by other process, of drugs.
Owner means any person, firm or corporation who owns, in whole or in part, the land, buildings or
structures associated with a clandestine drug lab site or chemical dumpsite.
Public health nuisance means all dwellings, accessory structures and buildings or adjacent property
associated with a clandestine drug lab site are potentially unsafe due to health hazards and are
considered a public health nuisance.
(Code 1996, § 9.18.010(D))
Sec 42-86 Purpose And Intent
The purpose of this article is to reduce public exposure to health risks where law enforcement officers have
determined that hazardous chemicals from a suspected clandestine drug lab site or associated dumpsite
may exist. The city council finds that such sites may contain suspected chemicals and residues that place
people, particularly children or adults of child bearing age, at risk when exposed through inhabiting or visiting
the site, now and in the future.
(Code 1996, § 9.18.010(A))
Sec 42-87 Interpretation And Application
(a) In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this article shall be construed to protect the
public health, safety and welfare.
(b) Where the conditions imposed by any provision of this article are either more or less restrictive than
comparable provisions imposed by any other law, ordinance, statute, or regulation of any kind, the
regulations which are more restrictive or which impose higher standards or requirements shall
prevail.
(Code 1996, § 9.18.010(B))
Sec 42-88 Fees
Fees for the administration of this article may be established and amended periodically by resolution of the
city council.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_42_MISCELLANEOUS_OFFENSES 5/11
(Code 1996, § 9.18.010(C))
DIVISION 2 ADMINISTRATION
Sec 42-120 Law Enforcement Notice To Other Authorities
Sec 42-121 Declaration Of Property As A Public Health Nuisance
Sec 42-122 Notice Of Public Health Nuisance To Concerned Parties
Sec 42-123 Property Owner's Responsibility To Act
Sec 42-124 Property Owner's Responsibility For Costs
Sec 42-125 Recovery Of Public Costs
Sec 42-126 Authority To Modify Or Remove Declaration Of Public Health Nuisance
Sec 42-120 Law Enforcement Notice To Other Authorities
Law enforcement authorities that identify conditions associated with a clandestine drug lab site or chemical
dump site that places neighbors, visiting public, or present and future occupants of the dwelling at risk for
exposure to harmful contaminants and other associated conditions must promptly notify the appropriate
municipal, child protection, and public health authorities of the property location, property owner if known,
and conditions found.
(Code 1996, § 9.18.020(A))
Sec 42-121 Declaration Of Property As A Public Health Nuisance
If law enforcement determines the existence of a clandestine drug lab site or chemical dumpsite, the
property shall be declared a public health nuisance.
(Code 1996, § 9.18.020(B))
Sec 42-122 Notice Of Public Health Nuisance To Concerned Parties
Upon notification by law enforcement authorities, the city building official shall promptly issue a declaration of
public health notice for the affected property and post a copy of the declaration at the probable entrance to
the dwelling or property. The building official shall also notify the owner of the property by mail and notify the
following parties:
(a) Occupants of the property;
(b) Neighbors at probable risk;
(c) The city police department;
(d) Other state and local authorities, such as MPCA and MDH, which are known to have public and
environmental protection responsibilities that are applicable to the situation.
(Code 1996, § 9.18.020(C))
Sec 42-123 Property Owner's Responsibility To Act
The building official shall also issue an order to abate the public health nuisance, including the following:
(a) Immediately vacate those portions of the property, including building or structure interiors, which may
place the occupants or visitors at risk.
(b) Promptly contract with appropriate environmental testing and cleaning firms to conduct an on-site
assessment, complete clean-up and remediation testing and follow-up testing, and determine that the
property risks are sufficiently reduced to allow safe human occupancy of the dwelling. The property
owner shall notify the city of actions taken and reach an agreement with the city on the clean-up
schedule. The city shall consider practical limitations and the availability of contractors in approving
the schedule for clean up.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_42_MISCELLANEOUS_OFFENSES 6/11
(c) Provide written documentation of the clean-up process, including a signed, written statement that the
property is safe for human occupancy and that the clean up was conducted in accordance with state
department of health guidelines.
(Code 1996, § 9.18.020(D))
Sec 42-124 Property Owner's Responsibility For Costs
The property owner shall be responsible for all costs of vacation or clean up of the site, including contractor's
fees and public costs for services that were performed in association with a clandestine drug lab site or
chemical dump site clean up. Public costs may include, but are not limited to:
(a) Posting of the site;
(b) Notification of affected parties;
(c) Expenses related to the recovery of costs, including the assessment process;
(d) Laboratory fees;
(e) Clean-up services;
(f) Administrative fees; and
(g) Other associated costs.
(Code 1996, § 9.18.020(E))
Sec 42-125 Recovery Of Public Costs
(a) If, after service of notice of the declaration of public health nuisance, the property owner fails to
arrange appropriate assessment and clean-up, the city building official is authorized to proceed in a
prompt manner to initiate the on-site assessment and clean-up.
(b) If the city is unable to locate the property owner within ten days of the declaration of public health
nuisance, the city is authorized to proceed in a prompt manner to initiate the on-site assessment and
clean-up.
(c) The city may abate the nuisance by removing the hazardous structure or building, or otherwise,
according to Minn. Stats. ch. 463.
(d) If the city abates the public health nuisance, in addition to any other legal remedy, the city shall be
entitled to recover all costs plus an additional 25 percent of the costs for administration. The city may
recover costs by civil action against the person or persons who own the property or by assessing
such costs as a special tax against the property in the manner as taxes and special assessments are
certified and collected pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 429.101.
(Code 1996, § 9.18.020(F))
Sec 42-126 Authority To Modify Or Remove Declaration Of Public Health Nuisance
(a) The building official is authorized to modify the declaration conditions or remove the declaration of
public health nuisance.
(b) Such modifications or removal of the declaration shall only occur after documentation from a qualified
environmental or leaning firm stating that the health and safety risks, including those to neighbors
and potential dwelling occupants, are sufficiently abated or corrected to allow safe occupancy of the
dwelling.
(Code 1996, § 9.18.020(G))
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_42_MISCELLANEOUS_OFFENSES 7/11
ARTICLE V SEXUAL OFFENDERS AND SEXUAL PREDATORS
Sec 42-150 Findings And Intent
Sec 42-151 Definitions
Sec 42-152 Sexual Offender Of Sexual Predator Residence Prohibition; Penalties; Exceptions
Sec 42-150 Findings And Intent
(a) Repeat sexual offenders, sexual offenders who use physical violence and sexual offenders who prey
on children are sexual predators who present an extreme threat to the public safety.
(b) It is the intent of this article to serve the city's compelling interest to promote, protect and improve the
health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city by creating areas around locations where children
regularly congregate in concentrated numbers wherein certain sexual offenders and sexual predators
are prohibited from establishing temporary or permanent residence.
(Ord. No. 141-09, § 1, 10-12-2009)
Sec 42-151 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them
in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Designated offender means any person who has been convicted of a designated sexual offense,
regardless of whether adjudication has been withheld and has been categorized as a Level III sex
offender under Minn. Stats. § 244.052 or successor of amended statute.
Designated sexual offense means a conviction, adjudication of delinquency, commitment under Minn.
Stats. ch. 253B, or admission of guilt under oath without adjudication involving any of the following
offenses: 609.341; 609.343; 609.344; 609.345; 609.352; 609.365; 617.23; 617.246; 617.247; 617.293;
successor or amended statute, or similar offense from another state.
Permanent residence means a place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for 14 or more
consecutive days. Permanent residence does not require an ownership interest by the person in such
residence.
Temporary residence means a place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for a period of 14 or
more days in the aggregate during any calendar years and which is not the person's permanent
address, or place where the person routinely abides, lodges, or resides for a period of four or more
consecutive or nonconsecutive days in any month and which is not the person's permanent residence.
(Ord. No. 141-09, § 1, 10-12-2009)
Sec 42-152 Sexual Offender Of Sexual Predator Residence Prohibition; Penalties; Exceptions
(a) Prohibited location of residence. It is unlawful for any designated offender to establish a permanent
residence or temporary residence:
1. Within 2,000 feet of any school, licensed day care center, park or public playground; or
2. Within 1,000 feet of any designated place of worship which provides regular educational
programs (i.e., Sunday School), or other places where children are known to congregate
unsupervised, excluding designated public school bus stops.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_42_MISCELLANEOUS_OFFENSES 8/11
(b) Prohibited activity. It is unlawful for any designated offender to participate in a holiday event involving
children under 18 years of age, such as distributing candy or other items to children on Halloween,
wearing a Santa Claus costume on or preceding Christmas, or wearing an Easter Bunny costume on
or preceding Easter. Holiday events in which the offender is the parent or guardian of the children
involved, and no nonfamilial children are present, are exempt from this paragraph.
(c) Measurement of distance.
1. For purposes of determining the minimum distance separation, the requirement shall be
measured by following a straight line from the outer property line of the permanent residence
or temporary residence to nearest outer property line of a school, day care center, park
playground, place of worship or other place where children regularly congregate.
2. The city clerk shall maintain an official map showing prohibited locations as defined by this
article. The clerk shall update the map at least annually to reflect the changes in the location
of prohibited zones. The map shall not be deemed conclusive or all encompassing since
prohibited zones change from time to time including, but not limited to, other places where
children are known to congregate.
(d) Exceptions. A designated offender residing within a prohibited area as described in (Minn. Stats. §
540.003, subd. 1) does not commit a violation of this section if any of the following apply:
1. The person established the permanent residence or temporary residence and reported and
registered the residence pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 243.166, or § 243.167, or successor
statutes, prior to October 12, 2009.
2. The person is a minor.
3. The school or day care center within 2,000 feet of the person's permanent residence was
opened after the person established the permanent residence or temporary residence and
reported and registered the residence pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 243.166 or § 243.167.
(Ord. No. 141-09, § 1, 10-12-2009; Ord. No. 142-09, § 1, 11-23-2009)
ARTICLE VI LOITERING
Sec 42-200 Definitions
Sec 42-201 Warning; Exception
Sec 42-202 Circumstances Causing Alarm
Sec 42-203 Intent To Commit Crime
Sec 42-204 Penalties
Sec 42-205 Severability And Savings Clause
Sec 42-206 Penalty Definition
Sec 42-200 Definitions
For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, and words shall have the meanings given
herein. The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directory.
Loitering. Whoever commits any of the following acts is guilty of loitering:
(a) Unauthorized lingering about the entryway of any public or private premises, or sitting or linge
upon the sidewalk, steps, windowsills, railing, fence, or parking area adjacent to any such premise
such a manner so as to obstruct or partially obstruct ingress to or egress from such building to
annoyance or inconvenience of owners, occupants, pedestrians, or entrants.
(b) Unauthorized lingering for any length of time upon any public or private premises or move in a s
and deliberate manner without purpose or otherwise interfere with, obstruct, or render dangerou
unreasonable for passage, any public highway, street, sidewalk, parking area, or right-of-way.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_42_MISCELLANEOUS_OFFENSES 9/11
(c) Remaining for more than five minutes on any public or private premises which are posted wi
conspicuous sign containing the words "No Loitering".
(d) Lurking, loitering, or prowling in any place at a time or in a manner not usual for law abi
individuals, under circumstances that warrant alarm for the safety of persons or property in
vicinity.
Premises. For the purposes of this article, premises shall include any house; yard; lot; parcel; sidewalk;
boulevard; street; highway; alley; park; playground; restaurant; café; church or other place of worship;
school; any car or other motor vehicle; parking lot; drive-in; building used for public, business,
commercial or industrial purposes; washroom; apartment building and entryways and hallways located
therein; or any other location whether public or private in the City of North Branch.
(Ord. No. 140-09, § 1, 9-28-2009)
Sec 42-201 Warning; Exception
A person may not be arrested or convicted under section 42-200, "loitering" (1) through (3) until after a law
enforcement officer has informed the person at least once in the previous 72-hour period that his or her
action violates this article. It shall not be necessary to inform any person.
(a) Who is charged under section 42-200, "loitering" (4); or
(b) Who has been convicted of a violation of this article within one year of the act complained of.
(Ord. No. 140-09, § 1, 9-28-2009)
Sec 42-202 Circumstances Causing Alarm
(a) Prohibition. A person shall not lurk, loiter, or prowl in any place, at a time or in a manner not usual for
law abiding individuals, under circumstances that warrant alarm for the safety of persons or property
in the vicinity.
1. Circumstances causing alarm. Among the circumstances that may be considered in
determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the
appearance of a police officer, refuses to identify himself, or endeavors to conceal himself.
(b) Authority to detain. A police officer may stop and briefly detain a person suspected of violating
subsection 42-202(a) if the person's behavior reasonably causes suspicion of criminal activity. The
officer's reasonable suspicion must be based on objective, articulable facts and reasonable
inferences drawn from all the circumstances surrounding the person's behavior.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_42_MISCELLANEOUS_OFFENSES 10/11
(c) Opportunity to dispel alarm. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impracticable,
a police officer must, prior to any arrest for a violation of subsection 42-202(a) allow the person an
opportunity to dispel any alarm which would otherwise be warranted by requesting him to identify
himself and explain his presence and conduct. The person may identify himself by presenting any of
the following:
1. A state-issued identification card or driver's license containing the person's photograph;
2. An employer-issued identification card which verifies the person's employment and includes
the person's photograph;
3. A currently valid passport;
4. A certified copy of a person's birth certificate; or
5. Verification of the person's identity by another person who can establish his own identity by
one of the documents listed above.
Any explanation of the person's presence and conduct will be sufficient to dispel alarm if it
shows that the person was engaging in and planning to continue engaging in, lawful activity
consistent with his actions and all the circumstances surrounding his behavior.
(d) Requisites for conviction. A person may not be convicted of a violation of section 42-202 if:
1. No police officer gave the person the opportunity provided in section 42-202(c) to dispel the
alarm created by his actions; or
2. The finder-of-fact determines that the police officer should have accepted the person's
explanation as sufficient to dispel alarm.
(Ord. No. 140-09, § 1, 9-28-2009)
Sec 42-203 Intent To Commit Crime
A person shall not in any public or private place lurk, loiter, prowl, lie in wait, or be concealed with intent to
commit any act prohibited by law.
(Ord. No. 140-09, § 1, 9-28-2009)
Sec 42-204 Penalties
Misdemeanor. Whoever commits any of the following acts is guilty of a misdemeanor:
(a) Loitering with intent to commit a crime as provided in section 42-203.
(b) Any of the acts enumerated in this article within one year of being found guilty of any violation of this
article; and
(c) Failing or refusing to vacate or leave any premises after being requested or ordered, either orally or
in writing, to do so by the owner, agent, manager or person in charge thereof, or by any law
enforcement officer or official or returning at any time thereafter to any such premises after having
been so requested or ordered to vacate such premises.
(d) Whoever commits any of the acts enumerated in section 42-200 or section 42-202 of this article.
(Ord. No. 140-09, § 1, 9-28-2009)
Sec 42-205 Severability And Savings Clause
Should any section, subdivision, clause or other provision of this article be held to be invalid by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the article as a whole, or of any part
thereof, other than the part held to be invalid.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_42_MISCELLANEOUS_OFFENSES 11/11
(Ord. No. 140-09, § 1, 9-28-2009)
Sec 42-206 Penalty Definition
For the purposes of this article, "misdemeanor" shall be as defined in Minn. Stats. § 609.02, subd. 3.
(Ord. No. 140-09, § 1, 9-28-2009)

DIVISION 42-II-1 GENERALLY
Sec 46-19 Garbage And Rubbish Defined
Sec 46-19 Garbage And Rubbish Defined
For the purpose of this article, garbage and rubbish are defined to include garbage and rubbish of all
kinds that accumulate in the ordinary operation of a household, grass trimmings, ashes, tree branches,
leaves and other refuse small enough to go into a 20-gallon garbage can.
(Code 1996, § 8.12.080)
DIVISION 2 RECEPTACLES
Sec 46-42 Placement
Sec 46-43 Accumulations Of Garbage Prohibited
Sec 46-44 Garbage To Be Placed In Receptacles
Sec 46-45 Regulations
Sec 46-42 Placement
Every person owning or managing any place of business, public building, multiple dwelling or residence
shall provide a receptacle sufficient for the depositing of all garbage, rubbish, and dirt from his premises.
It is unlawful in any district classified as an "R" district under the zoning regulations of the city to place,
keep, store, or locate within the right-of-way of a street, sidewalk, or alley, or within any front yard as
defined in the zoning regulations of the city, any such receptacle; provided, however, such receptacle
may be placed within such area for the purpose of the collection of garbage from 12:00 midnight to
12:00 midnight on the day or days designated for the pickup thereof and for a period of not to exceed
ten hours prior to 12:00 midnight of the day of pickup.
(Code 1996, § 8.12.010)
Sec 46-43 Accumulations Of Garbage Prohibited
No person shall fail to dispose of garbage and rubbish accumulated upon property owned or occupied
by him in a sanitary manner at least once per week. Every person who shall fail or refuse to make
provision for and secure such disposal shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(Code 1996, § 8.12.020)
Sec 46-44 Garbage To Be Placed In Receptacles
All garbage and rubbish accumulating between the times of collection shall be placed in approved cans
provided for in section 46-45 of this chapter.
(Code 1996, § 8.12.030)
Sec 46-45 Regulations
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_46_SOLID_WASTE 2/3
Each garbage receptacle shall be constructed watertight and shall be provided with handles and tightfitting
cover. Each such receptacle and cover shall be made of metal or other materials as may be
approved for use by the city. Covers shall not be removed except when necessary to place garbage
therein or remove garbage therefrom. Each receptacle and its cover shall be kept clean from
accumulating grease and decomposing material. All receptacles designed to be emptied by hand shall
be so constructed as to contain not less than three nor more than 30 gallons, provided places of
business or public building may use garbage receptacles having a capacity not in excess of 36 gallons.
(Code 1996, § 8.12.040)

No person may collect or dispose of garbage for hire within the city without first receiving a license from

The city clerk may issue a license to any person to collect or dispose and to collect applicable fees
which shall be deposited in the general fund, and upon a showing of compliance with the provisions of
this division. The license so issued shall be for a term of one calendar year.
(Code 1996, § 8.12.060)
Sec 46-66 Revocation Of License
The license issued under section 46-65 may be revoked or suspended for a violation of this chapter,
upon a showing that the licensee has engaged in practices which are unsanitary or detrimental to health,
or for good cause shown.
(Code 1996, § 8.12.070)
Sec 46-67 Insurance Requirements For Licensee
The licensee shall show financial responsibility or a certificate of insurance coverage whereby each
vehicle to be used by the licensee shall be covered against loss or injury in the following amounts: each
person injured, at least $50,000.00; each accident, at least $100,000.00 for personal injury; and at least
$10,000.00 for loss or damage to property, together with evidences of workers compensation insurance
for licensee's employees. Such insurance policy shall be for the full period of the license and shall
provide for the giving of ten days prior notice to the city of the termination or cancellation of the policies.
In case any of the policies are terminated, the license shall be automatically revoked on the day the
policy complying with this section is immediately obtained.
(Code 1996, § 8.12.090)

(Code 1996, § 12.04.010)

Sec 50-25 Snow Removal On Sidewalks
(a) No person shall permit an accumulation of more than two inches of snow to build up or remain on
any public sidewalk abutting or otherwise serving lots or parcels located in the city except those
specified in subsection (d) of this section. The removal of the snow shall be the full width of the
sidewalk and shall be completed within 36 hours of the end of the snowfall.
This does not apply to sidewalks that either dead end or do not provide a connection; or that are
located in a subdivision in which less than 60 percent of the lots have buildings on them, unless
located adjacent to a street that warrants clearing, to be determined by city staff.
(b) Reserved.
(c) For the purposes of this article, person means the owner of record of the lots or parcels or in the
event that the premises of any given lot or parcel is under the control of a person other than the
owner through a lease or rental agreement, then and in that event the lessee or renter shall be
responsible for the snow removal required in this article, unless by written agreement the owner
is obligated to remove snow from affected sidewalks. If snow is not removed, the city will hire a
company to remove snow and bill to owner or renter.

Sec 50-50 Findings Purpose And Intent
To provide for the health, safety and welfare of its citizens, and to ensure the integrity of its streets and
the appropriate use of the rights-of-way, the city strives to keep its rights-of-way in a state of good repair
and free from unnecessary encumbrances.
Accordingly, the city hereby enacts this new chapter of this code relating to right-of-way permits and
administration. This chapter imposes reasonable regulation on the placement and maintenance of
facilities and equipment currently within its rights-of-way or to be placed therein at some future time. It is
intended to complement the regulatory roles of state and federal agencies. Under this chapter, persons
excavating and obstructing the rights-of-way will bear financial responsibility for their work. Finally, this
chapter provides for recovery of out-of pocket and projected costs from persons using the public rightsof-
way.
This chapter shall be interpreted consistently with 1997 Session Laws, Chapter 123, substantially
codified in Minn. Stat. §§237.16, 237.162, 237.163, 237.79, 237.81, and 238.086 (the "Act") and 2017
Session Laws, Chapter 94 amending the Act and the other laws governing applicable rights of the city
and users of the right-of-way. This chapter shall also be interpreted consistent with Minnesota Rules
7819.0050 - 7819.9950 and Minnesota Rules Chapter 7560 where possible. To the extent any provision
of this chapter cannot be interpreted consistently with the Minnesota Rules, that interpretation most
consistent with the Act and other applicable statutory and case law is intended. This chapter shall not be
interpreted to limit the regulatory and police powers of the city to adopt and enforce general ordinances
necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public.
To the extent that a franchise agreement is in full force and effect whereby the city and an Applicant are
the parties thereto, to the extent that the terms and conditions of this Chapter conflict with the terms and
conditions of the franchise agreement, the terms and conditions of the franchise agreement shall control.
HISTORY
Adopted by Ord. 289-18 on 9/11/2018

Sec 50-56 Permit Required
No person or entity, with or without a franchise, shall make any excavation in any public street, alley,
way or property without first having secured a permit therefor from the city administrator upon forms
supplied by the city.
(Code 1996, § 12.12.010)
Sec 50-57 Applications For Permit; Fee And Damage Deposit
(a) Applications for an excavation permit shall be made by the owner or authorized agent and the
party employed to do the work. The application shall state the location, name of the owner, street
number of the adjoining property, and the reason for the excavation.
(b) The contractor doing the actual work shall be responsible for the acquisition of the excavation
permit. The excavation permit fee is set by city council.
(c) The permit application must be accompanied by a $1,000.00 damage deposit in the form of cash
or letter of credit. Upon satisfactory restoration and inspection by the public works director in
accordance with sections 50-63 and 50-64, the deposit will be returned to the contractor.
(Code 1996, § 12.12.020; Ord. No. 175-11, § 1, 12-12-2011)
Sec 50-58 Excavator's License; Surety Bond; Required
(a) No person shall be granted an excavator's license until the city is furnished with a $5,000.00
surety bond made to the city and a certificate of insurance carrying liability and workers
compensation coverage conditioned that the licensee will indemnify and save harmless the city
from all suits, accidents, and damage that may arise by reason of any opening in any street,
alley, public way or property.
(b) The license fee for an excavator's license is set by city council and it runs on a calendar basis
expiring on December 31 of each year. The licensing of sewer contractors within the city is
sufficient to meet the requirements of an excavator's license.
(Code 1996, § 12.12.030)
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_50_STREETS,_SIDEWALKS_AND_OTHER_PUBLIC_PLACES 6/22
Sec 50-59 Suspension Or Revocation Of License
The city council may suspend or revoke any license issued under this article for any of the following
causes:
(a) Giving false information in connection with the application for the license;
(b) Incompetence of the licensee;
(c) Willful violation of any provisions of this article or any rule or regulation pertaining to excavations;
(d) Failure to reimburse the city for its expenses from any previous claim.
(Code 1996, § 12.12.040)
Sec 50-60 Time Of Excavation
(a) Excavations on public street, alleyway or property must be undertaken Monday through Friday
between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. Any work accomplished outside of this schedule
will require a fee for the entire cost of a public works employee to inspect the process. It is the
responsibility of the contractor doing the work to notify the city at least 24 hours in advance of
any excavation.
(b) An exception to the notice required above and the penalty imposed in section 50-62 of this article
would be authorized in the event notification is given the public works superintendent, utility
superintendent, or authorized representative thereof in a case of a bona fide emergency. This
emergency would be defined as breakage in any public utility, including natural gas, and
telephone, which requires immediate action to correct and which protects the public health,
safety or welfare. A permit will still need to be obtained but it will be accomplished after the fact.
(Code 1996, § 12.12.050)
Sec 50-61 Provisions To Excavate
No person or entity will excavate in any street, alley, public way or property unless:
(a) Twenty-four hour notice is given the city prior to any digging so that inspection or other needs
can be arranged. Failure to give proper notice will result in a $50.00 penalty fee to the contractor
doing the work;
(b) A copy of the completed and approved excavation permit is available at the job site for inspection
of the public works department personnel inspection;
(c) If the excavation so limits the total use of a public way it is the duty and responsibility of the
excavator to install barricades to bar entrance to the excavation area and/or redirect traffic. If the
excavation site has to remain open during dark hours it is the responsibility of the contractor
doing the work to provide all the barricades, excavation area and material piles with illuminated
warning lights.
(Code 1996, § 12.12.060)
Sec 50-62 Failure To Secure Required Permit, Notification Or Inspection
Any failure to secure a permit prior to digging, giving proper notification for excavation or restoration, or
operating without inspection will be the responsibility of the contractor doing the actual work including
penalties and/or legal action. A penalty will be imposed on the contractor as follows:
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_50_STREETS,_SIDEWALKS_AND_OTHER_PUBLIC_PLACES 7/22
(a) Failure to give 24-hour notice to the city requires a $50.00 additional fee;
(b) A fee of double the fee amount will be charged all contractors who operate without an excavation
permit;
(c) A fee of double the fee amount will be charged for an excavator who operates without
excavator's license;
(d) A fee of $100.00 will be charged any individual who operates without city inspection;
(e) All penalty fees are subject to revisions by resolution of the city council.
(Code 1996, § 12.12.070)
Sec 50-63 Restoration; Excavator Responsible
(a) The excavator shall be responsible for the restoration of the public street, alley, way or property.
Restoration of a paved area shall require 24-hour notice to the public works superintendent or
authorized agent thereof.
(b) Inspection of the restoration process will be required for all paved restorations. All pavement
restorations will be undertaken Monday through Friday between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:30
p.m. Any work accomplished outside of this schedule will require a fee for the entire cost of a
public works employee to inspect the process.
(Code 1996, § 12.12.080)
Sec 50-64 Minimum Standards For Restoration
(a) The restoration shall be to a minimum standard of six inches of class five and three inches of
asphalt or equal to the specifications of the original installation, whichever is greater. In addition
the hole needs to be straight-edge cut and repaired with tacked edges. Compaction of the hole is
the responsibility of the excavator. If a hole slumps greater than one inch within one year's time it
is his responsibility to correct the problem.
(b) In areas of public ways that are not paved it shall be the responsibility of the excavator to see
that all areas are seeded and grass must grow for a period of one month.
(Code 1996, § 12.12.050)
ARTICLE IV STREET AND SIDEWALK USE REGULATIONS
Sec 50-87 Throwing Of Refuse Upon Public Ways Prohibited
Sec 50-88 Sales On Public Way Prohibited; Exceptions
Sec 50-89 Sale, Possession Or Consumption Of Intoxicating Beverages; Prohibited On Public Ways
Sec 50-90 Skateboarding Or Similar Activity Prohibited; Exceptions
Sec 50-87 Throwing Of Refuse Upon Public Ways Prohibited
No person shall throw or deposit any glass, metal, garbage, or other refuse upon any public way.
(Code 1996, § 12.16.010)
Sec 50-88 Sales On Public Way Prohibited; Exceptions
No person shall buy, sell, barter or offer to buy or sell or barter for any goods, wares, merchandise or
service, or otherwise engage in any type of business on any public sidewalk or street within the city. This
section shall not apply when the activities prohibited in this article are expressly permitted in a defined
area for a specified period of time by proclamation of the city council.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_50_STREETS,_SIDEWALKS_AND_OTHER_PUBLIC_PLACES 8/22
(Code 1996, § 12.16.020)
Sec 50-89 Sale, Possession Or Consumption Of Intoxicating Beverages; Prohibited On Public
Ways
(a) It is unlawful for any person to possess, consume, sell or otherwise provide to others any
intoxicating beverage upon any public way within the city without first obtaining a permit therefor
from the city council.
(b) It is also unlawful for any person to possess, consume or otherwise provide to others any
controlled substance upon any public way within the city.
(Code 1996, § 12.16.030)
Sec 50-90 Skateboarding Or Similar Activity Prohibited; Exceptions
No person shall use a skateboard or engage in similar actions upon:
(a) Any private or public land in the business district at any time unless so designated as a
skateboard or similar activity area by signs authorized by the city council. The business district is
to include all properties zoned CBD, B-2 and B-3.
(b) Any private or public land where a sign has been erected not permitting skateboarding or similar
activity.
(c) Similar activity is the use of a skateboard, roller skate, roller blade, scooter or similar equipment
(not the use of a bicycle).
(d) A person cited or warned by a police officer in violation of the provisions of this section does by
his use of the public sidewalks, streets, and public parking lots, consent to the impoundment by a
police officer of the in-line skates, roller skates, or skateboard for a period of three days upon first
offense, a week upon second offense and indefinitely on a third offense.
(Code 1996, § 12.16.040)
ARTICLE V PARKS, PLAYGROUND AND PUBLIC GROUNDS
Sec 50-109 Application
Sec 50-110 Hours Of Use For Parks, Playgrounds And Public Grounds
Sec 50-111 Uses Prohibited
Sec 50-112 Violation; Penalty
Sec 50-109 Application
This article shall apply to all parks, playgrounds and public grounds owned by or otherwise under the
control of the city council within the municipal boundaries of the city, irrespective of whether or not any
such lands are open to the unsolicited use thereof by city residents or other persons.
(Code 1996, § 12.20.010)
Sec 50-110 Hours Of Use For Parks, Playgrounds And Public Grounds
Unless otherwise posted, no person shall be present in or located upon any park, playground or other
public ground, including parking areas appurtenant thereto, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00
a.m. without the express approval of the city council; provided, that this section shall not apply to
persons who, without delay, are traveling through such parks, playgrounds or public grounds upon
established walks, paths and streets.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_50_STREETS,_SIDEWALKS_AND_OTHER_PUBLIC_PLACES 9/22
This section shall also not apply to sporting activities that are clearing the site and leaving the facilities. It
does not allow the activity itself to continue past 10:00 p.m.
(Code 1996, § 12.20.020; Ord. No. 122B-08, § 1, 7-14-2008)
Sec 50-111 Uses Prohibited
(a) No person not an employee of the city shall pick or cut any wild or cultivated flower or cut, break
or in any way injure or deface any tree, shrub or plant or otherwise disturb or disrupt the soil or
grounds of such public areas.
(b) No person, except employees of the city, shall plant any wild, cultivated or exotic tree, shrub or
plant without the permission of the city.
(c) No person shall kill, pursue, injure, molest, disturb or have in possession any species of wildlife
including birds, waterfowl or other animals found within the confines of the park.
(d) No person shall rob, disturb or molest the nest, eggs or young of any birds or other animals
found within the park.
(e) No person shall operate a motorized vehicle in any city park or trail, except on designated
roadways and parking lots, unless prior approval is obtained from the city.
(f) No person shall start any fire in any such public area, except for small fires and charcoal heating
for culinary purposes in the cooking devices designed for such use as located in such public
areas, or in such devices as are brought into such public areas expressly designed and safely
located for such purposes. No person who starts or otherwise uses any charcoal fire or other fire
shall leave such fire until same has been completely extinguished. No person starting or using a
charcoal fire or other fire shall dispose of the ashes or coals in any place in any public area other
than a receptacle provided for refuse and then only after such ashes or coals are sufficiently cold
to prevent damage to the receptacles or contents thereof.
(g) The city may at its discretion prohibit fires for limited periods at any park location for the
continued protection of park, property, resources and the city.
(h) No person shall tamper with, climb, deface, destroy, disturb, damage or remove any part of any
park building, sign, light, table, grill, shelter, equipment or other property found therein.
(i) No person shall disregard or fail to comply with any posted regulations, directional signs, barriers
or other control devices located within any city park.
(j) No person shall swim or bathe in any water in or adjacent to any city park.
(k) No person shall deposit, allow to accumulate or dispose of any inorganic waste in or upon a
stated public area, except to place same in garbage receptacles provided therefor.
(l) No person shall engage in boisterous, disruptive behavior, or excessively loud music or noise
within or upon any stated public area or otherwise conduct himself so as to unreasonably disturb
or aggravate another person or persons.
(m) No person shall erect or place in any or upon any stated public area a tent, camping equipment
or other temporarily located structure, nor shall any person leave any vehicle or movable
structure which could be used for the purpose of overnight camping unless prior approval
obtained from the city. No staking is allowed of said structures without written approval from the
city.
(n) No person shall place or erect any sign or advertisement on any park land, trees, structures or
equipment located therein, unless permission is granted by the city.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_50_STREETS,_SIDEWALKS_AND_OTHER_PUBLIC_PLACES 10/22
(o) No person shall be permitted to take any dog or cat into any park, unless the animal is restrained
by a leash or lead. Any fecal material from the animal shall be cleaned up by the owner
immediately.
(p) No person shall cast, deposit, throw, damage, lay, place or scatter upon any of the stated public
areas, or in or upon any water located therein or adjacent thereto, any cigars, cigarettes, glass,
bottles, nails, tacks, wire, crockery, cans or any other refuse matter. No person shall have in his
possession any glass or other objects easily fragmented in or upon any water located within the
park.
(q) No person shall possess, consume or provide to others any alcoholic beverages in or upon any
park, playground or public ground without first obtaining a written permit therefor from the city
council. No person shall possess, consume or otherwise provide to others any controlled
substance in any park, playground or public ground.
(Code 1996, § 12.20.030; Ord. No. 162-11, §§ 1, 2, 4-25-2011)
Sec 50-112 Violation; Penalty
(a) Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a petty misdemeanor.
(b) Any person violating any of the provisions of this article may be expelled or ejected at such time
from a park at the discretion of a law enforcement officer.
(Code 1996, § 12.20.040)
ARTICLE VI REGULATIONS FOR INSTALLATION AND USE OF ANTENNAS UPON CITY
PROPERTY
Sec 50-138 Purpose
Sec 50-139 Definitions
Sec 50-140 Lease Required
Sec 50-141 Application To Enter Into Lease
Sec 50-142 Application Fee
Sec 50-143 Lease Agreement
Sec 50-138 Purpose
The purpose of this article is to regulate the conditions under which private and noncity public antennas
may be placed upon city property, including water towers and other towers belonging to the city.
(Code 1996, § 12.22.010)
Sec 50-139 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Antenna means that portion of any equipment located on the exterior or outside of any structure
used for receiving and/or transmitting radio, television, electromagnetic, or other means of wireless
transmission.
Lease means that lease agreement outlined in section 50-143.
Structure means any manmade building or device extending upward from the ground upon which
may be constructed or affixed to an antenna.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_50_STREETS,_SIDEWALKS_AND_OTHER_PUBLIC_PLACES 11/22
(Code 1996, § 12.22.020
Sec 50-140 Lease Required
It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to construct or affix upon any city structure an antenna
without first entering into a lease with the city, duly dated and executed by the city and the lessee.
(Code 1996, § 12.22.030)
Sec 50-141 Application To Enter Into Lease
Any person or entity desiring to enter into a lease with the city for the purpose of constructing or affixing
an antenna to city property must first file with the city an application on a form supplied by the city, which
application shall contain, but not be limited to, the following information:
(a) Name and address of the person or entity; if an entity, a copy of the articles or other such
document as will confirm its statutory organization.
(b) Description of city structure(s) desired to be leased.
(c) Detailed description of the exact nature of the type or mode of wireless transmission to be
utilized and the location from and to which any signals will be transmitted or received.
(d) List of any known means or modes of wireless transmission known to conflict with or otherwise
cause interference with the applicant's use.
(e) A schematic and mechanical diagram, to scale, showing all components of the antenna and
other equipment to be placed within or upon the city structure.
(f) The hours of operation during which the antenna will be in use.
(g) The source of any power needed to operate the antenna and equipment.
(h) Whether the applicant will be maintaining the antenna and equipment; if not, the name and
address of the person or entity doing the maintenance.
(i) The lighting or safety equipment required for said antenna under federal, state, and/or local law,
regulation, or ordinance.
(j) Copies of each and every federal, state, or local permit or other approval, aside from those of the
city, required for the construction, maintenance and/or use of said antenna.
(k) Whether the applicant presently anticipates any increase in or change of the use of said antenna.
(Code 1996, § 12.22.030)
Sec 50-142 Application Fee
Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee in the sum of $500.00 to permit the city
to obtain an independent analysis of the feasibility, compatibility and incompatibility of permitting the
antenna requested.
(Code 1996, § 12.22.050)
Sec 50-143 Lease Agreement
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_50_STREETS,_SIDEWALKS_AND_OTHER_PUBLIC_PLACES 12/22
Lease agreement shall be in the following format:
CITY OF NORTH BRANCH, MINNESOTA
LEASE TO PERMIT ANTENNA ON CITY STRUCTURE
This agreement is made and entered into on the date signed below by and between the City of North
Branch, Minnesota, a municipal corporation, hereinafter Lessor; and ____________, hereinafter Lessee:
RECITALS
(1) Lessor is the owner or manager of certain real property located in the County of Chisago, State of
Minnesota, described in exhibit A attached hereto.
(2) Lessor desires to make available, and Lessee desires to lease, a portion of the above described
property.
AGREEMENT
(1) Ownership and authority. Lessor represents and warrants that it has all necessary title and full
authority to enter into and perform this agreement, and that there are no liens, judgments, or
impediments to Lessor's title to the property affecting this agreement, or to Lessor's ability to perform
under this agreement.
(2) Premises. Lessor agrees to provide space for Lessee on the property to accommodate an antenna,
to be mounted at ____________ feet AGL on ____________/____________/____________ with
____________ feet of vertical clearance and ____________ (the "antenna space") as described on
exhibit B attached hereto. In addition, ____________ square feet of space will be provided for related
equipment on the property as described on exhibit B attached hereto ("equipment space"). The antenna
space and the equipment space constitute the "premises" hereunder.
(3) Electrical service. Lessee, at its own expense, shall provide for such electrical or other power as is
required by the operation of said antenna and to pay when due all fees and charges incurred as a result
thereof.
(4) Term and termination. This agreement shall be for an initial term of ____________ years
commencing on ____________. This lease shall automatically renew for up to ____________
subsequent year term unless either party has given six months advance written notice of its desire to
terminate this agreement as of the end of the then-current term.
(5) Rent. Lessee shall pay Lessor $____________ per annum as rent hereunder. Payable in advance in
equal monthly installments of $____________.
(6) Use. Lessee shall use the premises for the purpose of constructing, maintaining, and operating a
wireless communications facility and uses incidental thereto. Lessee may make the following use (mode
or type of transmission): to be operated ____________ hours per day ____________ days per week
during the term of this lease. Lessee may not extend or increase such use by adding call signs,
frequencies, additional equipment, or otherwise without first obtaining the written consent of the Lessor.
Any change or increase in such use shall be at the sole expense of the Lessee. Lessee shall maintain
the premises in good, safe-working condition and in accordance with any requirements of federal, state,
or local laws, regulations, and ordinances.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_50_STREETS,_SIDEWALKS_AND_OTHER_PUBLIC_PLACES 13/22
(7) Other approvals. Lessee's obligations under this agreement are contingent upon certificates, permits,
and other approvals that may be required by any federal, state, or local authorities. In the event any
such approvals are canceled, withdrawn, or terminated, Lessee may terminate this lease following 60
days written notice of the cause and proof of such termination to Lessor. Notice of Lessee's exercise of
its right to terminate under this paragraph shall be given to Lessor in writing by certified mail, return
receipt requested, and shall be effective 60 days following the receipt of such notice by Lessor. If this
agreement is terminated by Lessee under the provisions of this paragraph, Lessor shall be entitled to
receive or retain all rents required until the date of termination provided herein.
(8) Access and quiet enjoyment. Lessee shall be afforded access to the premises and its facilities at all
times for all purposes related to the proposed use of the premises. Lessor agrees, for itself and its
successors and assigns, not to construct or permit, approve, cause or otherwise allow to be constructed
on the property, or any other property located within a radius of 500 feet of the premises that may be
owned, leased, licensed, or otherwise controlled by Lessor, any improvements, building structures, or
other facilities that would interfere with Lessee's use of the premises under this agreement. Specifically,
without limitation, Lessor shall be prohibited from interfering with the proper and optimum placement of
all equipment and apparatus by Lessee to construct and operate Lessee's equipment on the premises.
In the event such interference shall occur, Lessor at its sole cost shall immediately take all steps as are
necessary to correct and eliminate such interference, including, without limitation, taking such legal
action as may reasonably be required by Lessee. Without limiting the foregoing, Lessor covenants that
Lessee shall and may peacefully and quietly have, hold, and enjoy the premises for the purposes
intended hereby.
(9) Hazardous substances. Lessee shall indemnify, defer, and hold Lessor and its agents and
employees harmless from and against any claim, cost, expense (including reasonable attorney's and
consultants fees), damage, penalty, or liability imposed upon Lessor resulting from the treatment,
storage, generation, release or disposal of any substance by Lessee under, in or about the premises
which substance is designated as hazardous, dangerous, toxic, or harmful and/or subject to regulation
under federal, state, or local law, regulation or ordinance. Except to the extent caused by an act of
Lessee, Lessor shall indemnify, defer, and hold Lessee and its agents and employees harmless from
and against any claim, cost, expense (including reasonable attorney's and consultant's fees), damage,
penalty, or liability imposed upon Lessee resulting from the treatment, storage, generation, release or
disposal of any hazardous substance on, under, in or about the property for the duration of this
agreement.
(10) Further indemnities. Lessor and Lessee shall each indemnify and hold the other harmless from and
against any claim of liability or loss from personal injury or property damage resulting from or arising out
of the use and occupancy of the property or premises by such party or its employees or agents.
(11) Assignment and assumption. Lessee may not assign nor permit the assumption of this lease, nor
any part thereof, nor obligations thereunder, without first receiving the written consent of the Lessor. Any
sale by the Lessor of the property shall be subject to the rights of the Lessee set forth herein for so long
as said lease is in effect, and Lessee is not in default thereof.
(12) Termination of lease. Either party to this lease may terminate same by submitting to the other party,
by certified mail, a notice in writing stating the intent to terminate this lease, which termination shall be
effective 180 days following the receipt of said notice by the receiving party.
(13) Removal of property. Upon termination of this agreement, Lessee shall, within 60 days after the
date of termination, remove its equipment, antenna, and any other improvements affixed to the property
by the Lessee, together with all of Lessee's personal property, fixtures, and equipment, at no cost to
Lessor. Should Lessee fail or refuse to timely remove such equipment, antenna and improvements,
Lessor may, in its sole discretion, remove same, apply the proceeds of any sale to any delinquencies or
defaults then existing as to this lease, and its costs of removal and sale. Any balance remaining shall be
paid to Lessee.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_50_STREETS,_SIDEWALKS_AND_OTHER_PUBLIC_PLACES 14/22
(14) Interference. The parties acknowledge that there is at present no harmful electronic interference
between Lessee's operations on the property, if any, and those of Lessor and/or other parties present on
the property. Lessor and Lessee acknowledge their mutual obligation not to install or add, or permit to be
installed or added, to existing facilities on the property in a way which would cause such interference. In
the event either party by its activities on the property causes or permits electronic interference to preexisting
operation by the other party, the interfering or permitting party shall, on request, remove
forthwith the source of such interference.
(15) Damage or destruction/eminent domain. If the whole or any part of Lessee's property or the
premises, including the easements, are damaged or destroyed by fire, the elements, subsidence of
sublateral or subjacent support, or any other casualty, or taken in whole or in part by eminent domain or
condemnation to make the premises unsuitable or uneconomic for Lessee's use, Lessee may terminate
this agreement and all of the obligations of either party hereunder upon 60 days notice to Lessor. Any
award for eminent domain or condemnation shall be apportioned upon a reasonable basis.
(16) Integration. It is hereby mutually agreed and understood that this agreement contains all
agreements, promises, and understandings between the Lessor and Lessee regarding the subject
matter hereof and that no verbal or oral agreements, promises, or understandings shall or will be binding
upon either the Lessor or Lessee in any dispute, controversy, or proceeding in law, and any addition,
variation or modification to this agreement shall be void and ineffective unless in writing and signed by
the parties hereto.
(17) Applicable law. This agreement and the performance thereof shall be governed, interpreted,
construed, and regulated by the laws of the state.
(18) Attorney's fees. In the event that either party hereto shall institute suit to enforce any rights
hereunder, the prevailing party shall be entitled to recover court costs and reasonable attorney's fees.
Upon appeal, the prevailing party shall be entitled to recover court costs and reasonable attorney's fees
incurred as a result of such appeal.
(19) Notices. All notices hereunder must be in writing and shall be deemed validly given if sent by
certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed as follows (or any other address that the party to be
notified may have designated to the sender by like notice):
LESSEE: ____________
____________
____________
LESSOR: City of North Branch
1356 Main Street
North Branch, MN 55056
(20) Equipment financing and leasehold mortgage. Lessor hereby expressly understands and agrees
that at all times during the term of the agreement, Lessee shall have the absolute and unconditional right
to grant to any person or entity a security interest in some or all of the Lessee's fixtures and equipment
to be utilized in connection with the use of the premises or to assign or pledge Lessee's interest in this
agreement and the premises, including the easements, to its lender for purposes of financing its
equipment or for the operation of its business, and to record against Lessee's interest in the premises
any instruments or documents as may be required with respect to such equipment financing or
leasehold assignment.

https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_50_STREETS,_SIDEWALKS_AND_OTHER_PUBLIC_PLACES 15/22
(21) Taxes and use charges. Lessee shall pay when due any and all taxes, of whatever nature, and user
charges incurred or imposed as a result of the use of the premises by Lessee described herein, and said
antenna and equipment.
(22) Miscellaneous. In the event the antenna and/or other equipment become subject to additional
requirements, safety, or otherwise in the future, Lessee shall at its own expense take any and all steps
and make such expenditures as are necessary to comply with same.
