Sec 58-128 User Fees; Purpose
It is the purpose of this division to provide for the recovery of cost from users of the city's sewer utility for the
implementation of the program established herein and to maintain a system of charges by which each user
will pay for the costs associated with the amount of wastewater collection and treatment services received by
the user. The applicable charges or fees shall be set forth in the city's schedule of charges and fees, to be
prepared, annually, by the city administrator and approved by the city council.
(Code 1996, § 13.16.130)
Sec 58-129 Charge And Fees; Outlined
The city council shall adopt annually user charges which may include:
(a) Rates for residential users of the sewer utility. These charges shall be assessed based upon metered
water usage;
(b) Rates for commercial, governmental and institutional users of the sewer utility. These charges shall
be assessed based upon equivalent residential units or upon a city approved metering of the user's
private water supply;
(c) Rates for industrial users of the sewer utility. There are no industries in the community known to
discharge wastes in excess of the stipulated volumetric, biological or suspended solids loading rates.
Therefore, these charges will not be assessed at present. Should an industry choose to locate in the
community and discharge wastes to the sewer utility, an industrial rate schedule will be developed
based upon equivalent residential units as identified by section 58-120.
(Code 1996, § 13.16.140)
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 35/54
Sec 58-130 Revenue Gathered By User Charges; Separate Accounts
(a) All revenue gathered by the user charges shall be maintained in an account separate from other
municipal accounts, and shall be used solely to defray the cost of operation, maintenance and
replacement of the sewer utility. Revenue sufficient to insure adequate replacement shall be held in a
replacement fund separate from other operation and maintenance revenues.
(b) Interest generated by the replacement fund shall remain in the replacement fund.
(c) Revenue from the sewer fund shall be used to retire the debt of the WWTF. The sewer availability
charge funds can also be used to help retire the debt if the city so chooses. Sewer user fees for debt
retirement shall be kept in the sewer fund for making debt payments on the construction of the
WWTF.
(Code 1996, § 13.16.150)
Sec 58-131 Wastewater Service Charges; General Provisions
(a) Service charges. The wastewater service charges for the use of and service supplied by the
wastewater facilities of the city shall be set and adjusted from time to time by ordinance of the city
council. This may be accomplished after an audit of the operating costs and revenues concerning the
operation of the WWFT.
(b) Bills.
1. The rates or charges for service shall be payable monthly. All properties connected to the
municipal sewer system will be charged a based fee, regardless of usage.
2. The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service shall be jointly
liable to pay for the service to such premises and the service is finished to the premises by
the city only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant, and user of the
services are jointly liable therefor to the city.
3. Bills for sewer service shall be sent out by the water and light department on the last day of
each month for which the service is billed.
4. All sewer bills are due and payable 15 days after being sent out. A penalty of ten percent shall
be added to all bills not paid 15 days after they have been rendered. The penalty fee shall be
applied to the amount overdue only once, and the fees shall not compound.
(c) Delinquent bills. If the charges for such services are not paid within 30 days after the rendition of the
bill for such services, such services may be discontinued without further notice and shall not be
reinstated until all claims are settled.
(d) Lien; notice of delinquency.
1. Whenever a bill for sewer service remains unpaid for 90 days after it has been rendered, the
city shall file with the county recorder a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain
the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that
the city claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges subsequent to the period
covered by the bill.
2. If the user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the city has notice of this,
notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises if his address be known to the city,
whenever such bill remains unpaid for the period of 90 days after it has been rendered.
3. The failure of the city to record such lien or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to
receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid bills as mentioned
in the foregoing section.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 36/54
(e) Foreclosure of lien. Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the
same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is
the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosures shall be by bill-in-equity in the name
of the city. The city's attorney is authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of
the city in any court having jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which the bill has
remained unpaid 180 days after it has been rendered.
(f) Revenues. All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the sewerage system shall be
deposited in the sewerage account of the sewerage fund. All such revenues and moneys shall be
held by the city separate and apart from their private funds and separate and apart from all other
funds of the city. The city shall receive all such revenues from the sewerage system and all other
funds and moneys incident to the operation of such system as the same may be delivered to them
and deposit the same in the amount of the fund designated as the sewerage fund. The fund shall be
administered in every respect in the manner provided by state statute.
(g) Accounts. The city shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records,
and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the
sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals shall cause to be made an audit by an independent
auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the sewerage system.
(h) Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this division shall be fined not less
than $50.00 nor more than $100.00 for each offense.
(i) Access to records. The state pollution control agency or its authorized representative shall have
access to any books, documents, papers and records of the city which are applicable to the city
system of service charges for the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and transactions
thereof to insure compliance with the terms of the special and general conditions to any state grant.
(j) Sanitary sewer disconnect—User/Owner sanitary sewer disconnect/shut off request. The owner or
his/her authorized agent may request that his/her sanitary sewer be shut off from accumulating
additional sewer charges other than the base sewer connect fee as outlined in the city's fee
schedule. This request will need to be made in writing to the city's public works director stating the
reason for such request along with a copy of the letter that was given to the water department
requesting the water be shut off. The minimum monthly sewer fee will be discontinued only after the
property owner has provided a written request for the sewer to be physically disconnected from the
city's sanitary sewer main. The following sewer disconnect procedure must be utilized when
disconnecting service from the sanitary sewer main:
1. Owner must submit a letter stating reason for the disconnect.
2. Work will need to be completed by a licensed and bonded contractor approved by the city.
3. Work will be done to city's engineering construction detail for sanitary sewer service removal,
street restoration, traffic control, bypass pumping, and turf establishment.
4. All inspections for above work will require 24-hour advanced notice. All work to be completed
Monday thru Friday.
(Code 1996, § 13.16.160; Ord. No. 229-15, § 1, 6-9-2015)
Sec 58-132 Effective Date Of Rates
The rates and service charges established for user charges shall become effective one month after notice is
given to users of the rate change.
(Code 1996, § 13.16.170)
Sec 58-133 Powers And Authority Of Enforcing Agents
(a) The city shall be permitted to gain access to such properties as may be necessary for the purpose of
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 37/54
inspection, maintenance and repair, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing, in accordance
with provisions of these regulations. Any person found to be violating any provisions of this division
shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a
reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. Any person who shall continue any
violation beyond the time limit shall be guilty of violation of the service contract and shall be
summarily disconnected from the sanitary sewer and/or water service. Such disconnection and
reconnection would be at the total expense of the customer.
(b) Where acids and chemicals damaging to sewer lines or treatment processes are released to the
sewer causing rapid deterioration of these structures or interfering with proper treatment of sewage,
the city is authorized to immediately terminate services by such measures as are necessary to
protect the facilities.
(c) Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this division shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00. Each day of
each violation shall be deemed a separate offense. Any person violating any of the provisions of this
division shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned by the city by
reason of such violation.
(d) Any additional costs caused by discharges to the treatment works of toxics or other incompatible
wastes, including the costs of restoring wastewater treatment services, cleanup and restoration of the
receiving waters and environs, and sludge disposal, shall be borne by the discharger(s) of the
wastes, at no expense to the city.
(e) As a condition of use, the city shall be granted access by industrial users to information regarding
industrial processes which have a direct bearing on the type and source of discharges to the
wastewater collection system.
(f) All work performed on private property by the city in the course of the operating and maintaining the
city's sewer utility shall be performed in full accordance with a duly negotiated and executed
easement.
(g) The city and its authorized employees shall observe all applicable safety rules while performing work
on private property and the city shall hold the owner blameless for injury or death except as such may
be caused by negligence or failure of the owner to maintain safe conditions.
(Code 1996, § 13.16.180)
ARTICLE IV TRUNK WATER AND SEWER UNIT CHARGES
Sec 58-165 Established
Sec 58-166 Trunk Sewer Unit Charges
Sec 58-167 Trunk Water Main Unit Charges
Sec 58-165 Established
Trunk water and sewer charges are established and outlined in the city's comprehensive sanitary sewer plan
and the North Branch Water and Light Commission Comprehensive Water System Plan. Trunk water and
sewer fees have been established and will be changed from time to time by city council ordinance. The
residential unit shall be based on the procedure outlined in article III, division 3, except that:
(a) Apartment complexes are charged on a commercial/industrial per acre basis, and
(b) Rental townhomes in a successful tax credit project are charged on a commercial/industrial per acre
basis.
(Code 1996, § 7.02.140; Ord. No. 120-08, § 1, 4-28-2008)
Sec 58-166 Trunk Sewer Unit Charges
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 38/54
(a) A permanent improvement revolving fund shall be established to finance lift stations, force mains,
sewer mains over eight inches in diameter, jacked or bored highway crossings, sewer laterals, and/or
sewer service lines to extend service to an area adjacent to the improvement project that can't be
assessed at this time, hereinafter referred to as trunk sewer mains.
(b) Each individual connection to the sanitary sewerage system shall be charged a trunk sewer unit
charge as set forth in the city's schedule of charges and fees, to be prepared, annually, by the city
administrator and approved by the city council.
(c) The trunk sewer unit charge for residential property shall be collected by the city at the time of final
platting of a parcel or at the time of lot split of unplatted or previously platted land. For residential
development with over ten lots, the developer may at his discretion pay the charge in the following
manner:
1. Twenty-five percent at the time of final plat filing;
2. Twenty-five percent one year later;
3. Twenty-five percent two years later; and
4. The balance at three years after the filing of the final plat.
Interest in the amount of seven percent per annum shall be added to any balance carried over
to the next year. If this option is chosen, financial security in a form approved by the city
attorney, must accompany the first installment. Advancement of the payment of installments
will be triggered by issuance of 33 percent, 66 percent, and 100 percent of the building
permits within the development. The trunk sewer unit charge for commercial/industrial
property shall be collected by the city at the time of issuance of the building permit. The
developer may at the city's discretion pay 15 percent of the commercial/industrial trunk fee at
the time of issuance of the building permit, with the remainder paid over a five-year time
period at two percent over the city's average rate of return for the previous year unless the
rate exceeds the bank's prime lending rate as determined by the city's official depository bank
in which case the rate should be set at one percent below prime as long as the resulting rate
is above the most recent bonding for SAC/WAC and trunk projects.
An irrevocable letter of credit in the amount of 125% of the outstanding balance shall be
posted and remain in effect until all outstanding fees have been paid.
(Code 1996, § 7.02.140(A); Ord. No. 120-08, § 1, 4-28-2008; Ord. No. 229-15, § 3, 6-9-2015)
Sec 58-167 Trunk Water Main Unit Charges
(a) A permanent improvement revolving fund shall be established to finance wells, pumphouses,
elevated tanks, water mains over eight inches in diameter for residential development and over 12
inches in diameter for commercial/industrial development, jacked or bored highway crossings, water
mains extended for the sole purpose of servicing an adjacent area that can't be assessed at this time,
hereinafter referred to as trunk water mains.
(b) Each individual connection to the water main system shall be charged a trunk water main unit charge
as set forth in the city's schedule of charges and fees, to be prepared, annually, by the city
administrator and approved by the city council of the city.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 39/54
(c) The trunk water main unit charge for residential property shall be collected by the city at the time of
final platting of a parcel or at the time of lot split of unplatted or previously platted land. For residential
development with over ten lots, the developer may at his discretion pay the charge in the following
manner:
1. Twenty-five percent at the time of final plat filing;
2. Twenty-five percent one year later;
3. Twenty-five percent two years later; and
4. The balance at three years after the filing of the final plat.
Interest in the amount of seven percent per annum shall be added to any balance carried over
to the next year. If this option is chosen, financial security in a form approved by the city
attorney, must accompany the first installment. Advancement of the payment of installments
will be triggered by issuance of 33 percent, 66 percent, and 100 percent of the building
permits within the development. The trunk water main unit charge for commercial/industrial
property shall be collected by the city at the time of issuance of the building permit. The
developer may at the city's discretion pay 15 percent of the commercial/industrial trunk fee at
the time of issuance of the building permit, with the remainder paid over a five-year time
period at two percent over the city's average rate of return for the previous year unless the
rate exceeds the bank's prime lending rate as determined by the city's official depository bank
in which case the rate should be set at one percent below prime as long as the resulting rate
is above the most recent bonding for SAC/WAC and trunk projects.
An irrevocable letter of credit in the amount of 125 percent of the outstanding balance shall be
posted and remain in effect until all outstanding fees have been paid.
(Code 1996, § 7.02.140(B); Ord. No. 120-08, § 1, 4-28-2008; Ord. No. 229-15, § 2, 6-9-2015)

Sec 58-221 Penalty For Late Payment

Sec 58-214 Establishment Of Stormwater Drainage System Utility
Pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subd. 3, the city establishes a stormwater drainage system utility and
authorizes the imposition of just and reasonable charges for the use and availability of storm sewer facilities.
(Ord. No. 123-08, § 1, 9-29-2008)
Sec 58-215 Findings And Determinations
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 40/54
(a) In the exercise of its governmental authority and in order to promote the public health, safety,
convenience and general welfare, the city has constructed, operated and maintained a stormwater
drainage system (the storm sewer system) consisting of certain storm sewer facilities. This division of
the Code is adopted in the further exercise of such authority and for the same purposes.
(b) The city has previously financed the cost of constructing, operating and maintaining the storm sewer
system by creating special storm sewer tax districts, and levying ad valorem taxes upon property
located in the storm sewer tax districts. The city has determined that it is now necessary and
desirable to provide an alternative method of recovering some or all of the costs of improving,
maintaining and operating the storm sewerage system by imposing just and reasonable charges for
the use and availability of the storm sewerage system (the storm sewerage system fee) as provided
in this division.
(c) Pursuant to state law, the city finds that it is necessary to establish the storm sewerage system fee in
a just and equitable manner. On the basis of a report prepared by the city engineer dated June 1992
(the engineer's report) and subsequent reports which analyzed the status of the completion of the
storm sewerage system, past methods of recovering storm sewerage system costs, the topography
of the city and other relevant factors, it is determined that it would be just and equitable to assign
responsibility for some or all of the costs of operating, maintaining and improving the storm sewerage
system on the basis of the expected stormwater runoff from the various parcels of land within the city
during a standard rainfall event. For the purposes of this division, a standard rainfall event is defined
as a rainfall event with a return frequency of ten years.
(d) On the basis of the engineer's report, the city finds that it would be appropriate to exempt from the
storm sewer fee lakes and landlocked basins. Lakes and landlocked basins receive little, if any,
benefit from the storm sewerage system.
(Ord. No. 123-08, § 1, 9-29-2008)
Sec 58-216 Rates And Charges
(a) Residential equivalent factor (REF). The storm sewage system fee shall be determined through the
use of a residential equivalent factor (REF). For the purposes of this section, one REF is defined as
the ratio of the average volume of surface stormwater runoff coming from one acre of land in a
particular land use classification to the average volume of runoff coming from one acre of land
subjected to typical single-family residential use within the city during a standard rainfall event.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 41/54
(b) Stormwater drainage system charges. In determining the storm sewage system fee, the city council
shall establish a basic system rate to be charged a residential lot having a residential equivalent
factor (REF) of one. The basis of determining a REF will be a residential lot, and the average
residential lot is estimated to be one-fourth acre. The charge to be made against each parcel of land
shall then be determined by multiplying the REF for that parcel's land use classification times that
parcel's acreage times the basic system rate. The REFs for the following land uses within the city and
the billing classifications for such land uses are as follows:
Classification Land Uses Residential Equivalent Factor
1 Residential 1
2 Commercial/Industrial 4
3 Churches 4
4 Apartments 1/unit
5 Mobile homes 1
6 Double bungalows/duplexes 2
7 School district 1
8 Commercial/Industrial 1 (with an on site pond and future outlet to the
municipal system)
Commercial/industrial shall have a minimum rate equal to 1 REF.
(Ord. No. 123-08, § 1, 9-29-2008; Ord. No. 183-12, § 1, 3-12-2012)
Sec 58-217 Other Land Uses
Land uses not listed in the resolution concerning fees and rates will be classified by the city engineer, who
shall assign them to classes, or properties, most nearly like the listed uses, from the standpoint of runoff
volume for the standard rainfall event.
(Ord. No. 123-08, § 1, 9-29-2008; Ord. No 183-12, § 1, 3-12-2012)
Sec 58-218 Incorporation Of Properties Paying For Storm Sewer District Taxes
In the event the storm sewer utility establishes charges prior to the end of a calendar year the properties who
are presently paying storm sewer district taxes will not be charged a user fee between the effective date of
the ordinance codified in this chapter and the termination of the existing districts.
(Ord. No. 123-08, § 1, 9-29-2008)
Sec 58-219 Certain Land Uses Except From Charges
Lakes and land-locked basins are exempt from the payment of stormwater drainage charges.
(Ord. No. 123-08, § 1, 9-29-2008)
Sec 58-220 Payment Of Charge
The city shall specify the storm sewerage system fee and must mail bills for the storm sewerage system fee
to the property owner or other persons responsible for payment on a monthly basis, in areas billed for utilities
by the city through North Branch Water and Light. Payment is due and payable in full upon receipt of the bill.
Parcels not receiving a utility bill for any reason through North Branch Water and Light will be billed on the
Chisago County Tax Statement. Fees billed in this manner will be due and payable with other tax payments.
(Ord. No. 123-08, § 1, 9-29-2008)
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 42/54
Sec 58-221 Penalty For Late Payment
Each bill for the storm sewerage system fee not paid within 15 days of the date when due will incur a penalty
charge of ten percent of the amount past due.
(Ord. No. 123-08, § 1, 9-29-2008)
Sec 58-222 Establishment Of Tax Lien
Any past due payment of the storm sewerage system fee in excess of 90 days past due may be certified to
the county auditor for collection with real estate or personal property taxes in the following year pursuant to
Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subd. 3. In addition, the city has the right to bring a civil action or to take other legal
remedies to collect any unpaid system use and availability charges.
(Ord. No. 123-08, § 1, 9-29-2008)
DIVISION 3 STORMWATER MANAGEMENT PRACTICES

Sec 58-253 Authorization
This division is adopted pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 462.351. This section is adopted pursuant to the
authorization and policies contained in Minn. Stats. chs. 103B and 462; Minnesota Rules Parts 6120.2500-
6120.399, Minnesota Rules Chapter 8410, 8420 and 70510.0210.
(Code 1996, § 13.18.010; Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-254 Findings
The North Branch city council hereby finds that uncontrolled and inadequately planned use of wetlands,
woodlands, natural habitat areas, areas subject to soil erosion and areas containing restrictive soil adversely
affects the public health, safety, and general welfare by impacting water quality and contributing to other
environmental problems, creating nuisances, impairing other beneficial uses or environmental resources and
hindering the ability of the city to provide adequate water, sewage, flood control, and other community
services. In addition, extraordinary public expenditures may be required for the protection of persons and
property in such areas and in areas which may be affected by unplanned land usage.
(Code 1996, § 13.18.020; Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-255 Purpose
The purpose of this division is to promote, preserve, and enhance the natural resources within the city and
protect them from adverse effects occasioned by poorly sited development or incompatible activities by
regulating land disturbing or development activities that would have an adverse and potentially irreversible
impact on water quality and unique and fragile environmentally sensitive land; by minimizing conflicts and
encouraging compatibility between land disturbing and development activities and encouraging compatibility
between land disturbing and development activities and water quality and environmentally sensitive land;
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 43/54
and by requiring detailed review standards and procedures for land disturbing or development activities
proposed for such areas, thereby achieving a balance between urban growth and development and
protection of water quality and natural areas.
(Code 1996, § 13.18.030)
Sec 58-256 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Applicant means any person who wishes to obtain a building permit, zoning or subdivision approval.
Best management practices (BMPS) means the most effective and practicable means or erosion
prevention and sediment control, and water quality management practices that are the most effective
and practicable means to control, prevent and minimize degradation of surface water, including
avoidance of impacts, construction-phasing, minimizing the length of time soil areas are exposed,
prohibitions, pollution prevention through good housekeeping, and other management practices
published by state or designated area-wide planning agencies.
Construction activity means a disturbance to the land that results in a change in the topography, existing
soil cover (both vegetative and nonvegetative), or the existing soil topography that may result in
accelerated stormwater runoff, leading to soil erosion and movement of sediment into surface waters or
drainage systems.
Control measure is a practice or combination of practices to control erosion and attendant pollution.
Detention facility means a permanent natural or man-made structure, including wetlands, for the
temporary storage of runoff which contains a permanent pool of water.
Dewatering means the removal of water for construction activity. It can be a discharge of appropriated
surface or ground water to dry and/or solidify a construction site. It may require Minnesota Department
of Natural Resources permits to be appropriated and if contaminated may require other MPCA permits
to be discharged.
Erosion means any process that wears away the surface of the land by action of water.
Erosion control means methods employed to prevent erosion. Examples include soil stabilization
practices, horizontal slope grading, temporary or permanent cover and construction phasing.
Erosion prevention means any measures employed to prevent erosion. Examples include but are not
limited to: soil stabilization practices, limited grading, mulch, temporary or permanent cover and
construction phasing.
Final stabilization means:
(a) All soil disturbing activities at the site have been completed and a uniform (e.g., evenly disturb
without large bare areas) perennial vegetative cover with a density of 70 percent of the na
background vegetative cover for the area has been established on all unpaved areas and areas
covered by permanent structures, or equivalent permanent stabilization measures (such as the us
riprap, gabions, or geotextiles) have been employed;
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 44/54
(b) For individual lots in residential construction by either:
1. The homebuilder completing final stabilization as specified above; or
2. The homebuilder establishing temporary stabilization including perimeter controls for
individual lot prior to occupation of the home by the homeowner and informing the homeow
of the need for, and benefits of, final stabilization (homeowners typically have an incentiv
put in the landscaping functionally equivalent to final stabilization as quick as possible to k
mud out of their homes and off sidewalks and driveways); or
(c) For construction project on land used for agricultural purposes (e.g., pipelines across crop or ra
land) final stabilization may be accomplished by returning the disturbed land to its preconstruc
agricultural use. Areas disturbed that were not previously used for agricultural activities, such
buffer strips immediately adjacent to surface waters and drainage systems, and areas which are
being returned to their preconstruction agricultural use must meet the final stabilization criteri
subsection (1) or (2) of this definition.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 45/54
Land disturbing activity means any activity that changes the volume or peak discharge rate of
stormwater runoff from the land surface. This may include the grading, digging, cutting, scraping, or
excavating of soil, placement of fill materials, paving, construction, substantial removal of vegetation, or
any activity that bares soil or rock or involves the diversion or piping of any natural or fabricated
watercourse.
National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) means the program for issuing, modifying,
revoking, reissuing, terminating, monitoring and enforcing permits under the Clean Water Act (Sections
301, 318, 402 and 405) and United States Code of Federal Regulations Title 33, Sections 1317, 1328,
1342 and 1345.
Person means any individual, firm, corporation, partnership, franchisee, association or governmental
entity.
Public waters means waters of the state as defined in Minn. Stats. § 130G.005, subdiv. 15.
Regional flood means a flood that is representative of large floods known to have occurred generally in
the state and reasonably characteristic of what can be expected to occur on an average frequency in the
magnitude of a 100-year recurrence interval.
Retention facility means a permanent natural or manmade structure that provides for the storage of
stormwater runoff by means of a permanent pool of water.
Sediment means solid matter carried by water, sewage or other liquid.
Sedimentation means the process or action of depositing sediment.
Sediment control means the measures and methods used to prevent sediment from leaving the site or
from a property. Sediment control practices include silt fences, sediment traps, earth dikes, drainage
swales, check dams, subsurface drains, pipe slope drains, storm drain inlet protection and temporary or
permanent sedimentation basins.
Stormwater is defined under Minnesota Rules 7077.0105, subp. 41(b), and includes precipitation runoff,
stormwater runoff, snow melt runoff and any other surface runoff and drainage.
Structure means anything manufactured, constructed, or erected which is normally attached to or
positioned on land, including portable structures, earthen structures, roads, parking lots, and paved
storage areas.
Wetlands means lands transitional between terrestrial and aquatic systems where the water table is
usually at or near the surface or the land is covered by shallow water. For purposes of this definition,
wetlands must have the following three attributes:
(a) Have a predominance of hydric soils;
(b) Are inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficien
support a prevalence of hydrophytic vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditi
and
(c) Under normal circumstances support a prevalence of such vegetation.
(Code 1996, § 13.18.040; Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-257 Scope And Effect
(a) Applicability. Every applicant for a building permit, subdivision approval, or a permit to allow land
disturbing activities must submit a stormwater management plan to the city. No building permit,
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 46/54
subdivision approval, or permit to allow land disturbing activities shall be issued until approval
requirements has been obtained in strict conformance with the provisions of this division.
(b) Minnesota Pollution Control Agency (MPCA). The MPCA is the permitting authority for land disturbing
activities requiring a NPDES Permit is in addition to permit required by the City of North Branch.
(c) Exemptions. The provisions of this division do not apply to:
1. Any part of a subdivision if a plat for the subdivision has been approved by the city council on
or before the enactment of this division;
2. A lot for which a building permit has been approved on or before the enactment of this
division;
3. Installation of fence, sign, telephone, and electric poles and other kinds of posts or poles; or
4. Emergency work to protect life, limb or property.
(d) Waiver. The city council may waive any requirements of this division upon making a finding that
compliance with the requirements will involve an unnecessary hardship and the waiver of such
requirements will not adversely affect the standards and requirements set forth in this division. The
city council may require as a condition of the waiver, such dedication or construction, or agreement to
dedicate or construct as may be necessary to adequately meet said standards and requirements.
(Code 1996, § 13.18.050; Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-258 Incorporation By Reference
(a) The following are hereby incorporated into this chapter by reference:
1. The city's engineering design standards are hereby incorporated into this chapter by
reference. The standards shall serve as the official guide for stormwater principles methods,
and practices for proposed development activities for the City of North Branch.
2. The National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System Permit, MN R100001 (NPDES general
construction permit) issued by the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency, August 1, 2013, as
amended. The NPDES general construction permit is incorporated into this chapter by
reference.
(Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-259 Stormwater Management Plan Approval Procedures
A written application for stormwater management plan approval, along with the proposed stormwater
management plan and maintenance agreement shall be filed with the city. Prior to applying for approval of a
stormwater management plan and maintenance agreement, an applicant may have the stormwater
management plans reviewed by the appropriate departments of the city. A description of all vegetation which
may be found in the water and a statement of general water quality shall be included. Unless otherwise
exempted by this ordinance, an application for stormwater management approval shall include the following
as condition for its consideration:
(a) A stormwater management plan.
(b) A maintenance agreement. The stormwater management plan shall be prepared to meet requirement
of section 58-260 approval standards of this division, as well as requirements within the city's
engineering design standards; the maintenance agreement shall be prepared to meet the
requirement of section 58-261 stormwater treatment maintenance plan and agreement of this
division.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 47/54
(Code 1996, § 13.18.060; Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-260 Approval Standards
(a) Standards. No stormwater management plan that fails to meet the standards contained in this section
shall be approved by the city engineer.
(b) All land disturbing activities are required to follow the construction site stormwater runoff control
standards set within this division and the city's engineering design standards. The standards should
follow the following requirements:
1. Erosion control.
2. Sediment control practices.
3. Temporary sediment basins.
4. Dewatering and basin draining.
5. Inspection and maintenance.
6. Pollution management measures/construction site waste control.
7. Final stabilization.
8. Training.
(c) Design standards. Stormwater detention facilities constructed in the City of North Branch shall be
designed according to the most current technology as reflected in this ordinance and the city's
engineering design standards.
(Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-261 Stormwater Management Criteria For Permanent Facilities
(a) An applicant shall install or construct, on or for the proposed land disturbing or development activity,
all stormwater management facilities necessary to manage increased runoff so that the two year, ten
years, and 100-year storm peak discharge rates existing before the proposed development shall not
be increased and accelerated channel erosion will not occur as a result of the proposed land
disturbing or development activity. An applicant may also make an in-kind or monetary contribution to
the development and maintenance of community stormwater management facilities designed to
serve multiple land disturbing and development activities undertaken by one or more persons,
including the applicant.
(b) The applicant shall give consideration to reducing the need for stormwater management facilities by
incorporating the use of natural topography and land cover such as wetlands, ponds, natural swales
and depressions as they exist before development to the degree that they can accommodate the
additional flow of water without compromising the integrity or quality of the wetland or pond.
(c) The following stormwater management practices shall be investigated in developing a stormwater
management plan in the following descending order of preference:
1. Infiltration of runoff on-site, if suitable soil conditions are available for use;
2. Flow attenuation by use of open vegetated swales and natural depressions;
3. Stormwater retention facilities; and
4. Stormwater detention facilities.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 48/54
(d) A combination of successive practices may be used to achieve the applicable minimum control
requirements specified in subsection (a) above. Justification shall be provided by the applicant for the
method selected.
(Code 1996, § 13.18.070; Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-262 Stormwater Maintenance Plan And Agreement
(a) Maintenance agreement. The applicant shall enter into a maintenance agreement with the city that
documents all responsibilities for operation and maintenance of all stormwater treatment practices.
Such responsibility shall be documented in a maintenance plan and executed through a maintenance
agreement. The maintenance agreement shall be executed and recorded against the parcel. The
maintenance agreement shall be in a form approved by the city shall describe the inspection and
maintenance obligations of this section and shall, at a minimum:
1. Designate the responsible party that shall be permanently responsible for maintenance of the
structural or nonstructural measures.
2. Pass responsibility for such maintenance to successors in title.
3. Grant the city and its representatives the right of entry for the purposes of inspecting all
stormwater treatment practices.
4. Allow the city the right to repair and maintain the facility, if necessary maintenance is not
performed after proper and reasonable notice to the responsible party.
5. Include a maintenance plan that contains, but is not limited to the following:
a. Identification of all structural stormwater treatment practices.
b. A schedule for regular inspection, monitoring, and maintenance for each practice.
Monitoring shall verify whether the practice is functioning as designed and may
include, but is not limited to quality, temperature, and quantity of runoff.
c. Identification of the responsible party for conducting the inspection, monitoring, and
maintenance for each practice.
6. Identify a schedule and format for reporting compliance with the maintenance plan to the city.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 49/54
(b) Inspection of stormwater facility. Inspection programs shall be established on any reasonable basis,
including but not limited to: routine inspections; random inspections; inspections based upon
complaints or other notice of possible violations; inspection of drainage basins or areas identified as
higher than typical sources of sediment or other contaminants or pollutants; inspections of
businesses or industries of a type associated with higher than usual discharges of contaminants or
pollutants or with discharges of a type which are more likely than the typical discharge to cause
violations of state or federal water or sediment quality standards or the National Pollutant Discharge
Elimination System (NPDES) stormwater permit; and joint inspections with other agencies inspecting
under environmental or safety laws. Inspections may include, but are not limited to, reviewing
maintenance and repair records; sampling discharges, surface water, groundwater, and material or
water in drainage control facilities; and evaluating the condition of drainage control facilities and other
stormwater treatment practices.
As a part of an approved stormwater treatment plan and agreement, when any new stormwater
treatment practice is installed on private property, or when any new connection is made between
private property and a public drainage control system, or sanitary sewer; the property owner shall
grant to the city the right to enter the property at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner for the
purpose of inspection. This includes the right to enter a property when the city has a reasonable
basis to believe that a violation of this ordinance is occurring or has occurred, and to enter when
necessary for abatement of a public nuisance or correction of a violation of this division.
The director of public works, or designated representative, shall inspect all stormwater management
facilities during construction, during the first year of operation, and at least once every five years
thereafter. The inspection records will be kept on file at the public works department for a period of
six years. It shall be responsibility of the applicant to dedicate or obtain any necessary easements or
other property interests to allow the city access to the stormwater management facilities for
inspection and maintenance purposes.
(c) Records of installation and maintenance activities. The responsible party shall make records of the
installation and of all maintenance and repairs of the stormwater treatment practices, and shall retain
the records for at least three years. These records shall be made available to the city during
inspection of the stormwater treatment practice and at other reasonable times upon request.
(d) Failure to maintain practices. If a responsible party fails or refuses to meet the requirements of the
maintenance agreement, the city, after reasonable notice, may correct a violation of the design
standards or maintenance needs by performing all necessary work to place the stormwater treatment
practice in proper working condition. In the event that the stormwater treatment practice becomes a
danger to public safety or public health, the city shall notify the responsible party in writing. Upon
receipt of that notice, the responsible party shall have 30 days to perform maintenance and repair of
the facility in an approved manner. After proper notice, the city may specially assess the owner(s) of
the stormwater treatment practice for the cost of repair work and any penalties; and the cost of the
work shall be assessed against the property and collected along with ordinary taxes by the county.
(Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-263 Right Of Entry
The issuance of a building permit or a permit to allow land disturbing activities permit constitutes a right-ofentry
for the city or its contractor to enter the construction site. The applicant shall allow the city and its
authorized representatives, to:
(a) Enter the permitted site for the purpose of obtaining information, examining records, conducting
investigations or surveys;
(b) Bring such equipment on the site as is necessary to conduct such surveys and investigations;
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 50/54
(c) Examine and copy any books, papers, or digital files pertaining to activities or records required to be
kept under the terms and conditions of the permitted site;
(d) Inspect the stormwater pollution control treatment practices;
(e) Sample and monitor any items or activities pertaining to stormwater pollution control measures;
(f) Correct deficiencies in stormwater and erosion and sediment control measures consistent with these
ordinances and the city's engineering design standards.
(Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-264 Penalty
(a) Notice of violation. When the city determines that an activity is not being carried out in accordance
with the requirements of this division, it shall issue a written notice of violation to the owner of the
property. The notice of violation shall contain:
1. The name and address of the owner of applicant,
2. The address when available or a description of the land upon which the violation is occurring,
3. A statement specifying the nature of the violation,
4. A description of the remedial measures necessary to bring the development activity into
compliance with this division and a time schedule for the completion of such remedial action,
5. At statement of the penalty or penalties that shall or may be assessed against the person to
whom the notice of violation is directed, and
6. A statement that the determination of violation may be appealed to the city by filing a written
notice of appeal within 15 days of services notice of violation.
(b) Stop work orders. Persons receiving a notice of violation will be required to halt all construction
activities. This stop work order will be in effect until the city confirms that the land disturbance activity
is in compliance and the violation has been satisfactorily addressed. Failure to address a notice of
violation in a timely manner may result in civil, criminal, or monetary penalties in accordance with the
enforcement measures authorized in this division.
(c) Civil and criminal penalties. In addition to or as an alternative to any penalty provided herein or by
law, any person who violates the provisions of this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and
subject to prosecution. Such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each day during which
the violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-265 Appeals
Any person aggrieved by the action of any official charged with the enforcement of this division, as the result
of the disapproval of a properly filed application for approval, issuance of a written notice of violation, or an
alleged failure to properly enforce the ordinance in regard to a specific application, shall have the right to
appeal the action.
(Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-266 Additional Proceedings
The city council may institute proceedings to prevent, abate, correct, or restrain any failure to comply with
the provisions of this division and assess the cost of such action or proceeding against the affected real
property and/or collect the same from the person failing to comply.
(Code 1996, § 13.18.090; Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 51/54
Sec 58-267 Other Controls
In the event of any conflict between the provisions of this division and the provisions of the erosion control or
shoreland protection ordinance adopted by the city council, the more restrictive standard prevails.
(Code 1996, § 13.18.100; Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
Sec 58-268 Severability
The provisions of this division are severable. If any provision of this division of the application thereof to any
person or circumstance is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applicants of this
division which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application.
(Ord. No. 227-15, § 4, 5-26-2015)
ARTICLE VI SECURING PAYMENT OF CITY UTILITY CHARGES

Sec 58-281 Definitions
For the purpose of this article, the following capitalized terms listed in alphabetical order shall have the
following meanings:
Account. A record of utility services provided by the city utility services and used by each property and
the periodic costs for those utility services.
City. The City of North Branch, County of Chisago, State of Minnesota.
City utility system. Facilities used for providing public utility service owned or operated by city or agency
thereof, including electric, sanitary sewer, storm sewer and water service.
Commission. The water and light commission of the city.
Electric system. Electric generation facilities, above and below ground transmission lines, fixtures,
meters and all equipment and appurtenances owned or operated by the city and/or commission for the
purpose of providing electric services for public or private use.
Owner. The fee title owner of a property which is provided services by the city utility system.
Utility rate schedule. A schedule of all utility rates and charges set from time to time by ordinance of the
city or as authorized, by the commission.
Waterworks system. Water and sewer transmission pipes, lines, fixtures, meters and all necessary
equipment and appurtenances owned or operated by the city and/or commission for the purpose of
providing water and sewer services for public or private use.
(Ord. No. 150-10, § 2, 4-12-2010)
Sec 58-282 Accounts
All accounts shall be carried in the name of the owner who personally, or by his, her or its authorized agent,
applied for such service. The owner shall be liable for water, sewer, storm sewer and electric services
supplied to the property as part of the city utility system, whether he, she or it is occupying the property or
not, and any unpaid charges shall be a lien upon the property in accordance with this article VI.
(Ord. No. 150-10, § 2, 4-12-2010)
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 52/54
Sec 58-283 Billing
Water, sewer, storm sewer and electric charges shall be billed on one bill as applicable to each account. All
bills shall contain the title, address and telephone number of the office in charge of billing. Bills shall be
mailed to the customers on or before the fifth day of each month and specify the water, sewer and electric
utility services consumed and storm sewer charges in accordance with the current fee schedule set by
ordinance of the city or adopted by the commission. All charges for water, storm sewer and electric utility
services shall be due upon receipt and considered delinquent after the 15th day of the month following billing
(a "delinquent account").
(Ord. No. 150-10, § 2, 4-12-2010)
Sec 58-284 Utility Rate Schedule
(a) The utility rate schedule shall be adopted not less frequently than annually by ordinance of the city or
by resolution of the commission.
(b) The city ordinance setting out the utility rate schedule may also establish the number of certification
cycles per year at which time delinquent accounts may be certified to the tax records for the property
to which city utility system services are provided. At least one certification cycle will be timed each
year to coincide with Chisago County's requirements for certification to the following year's taxes.
Additional certification cycles may be set in the annual rate schedule ordinance however, this shall
not limit the city from certifying delinquent accounts at other times in its discretion. Each year, the city
council shall establish one or more certification cut-off dates. All city utility accounts, unless exempt
for other legal reason, which have been billed and remain unpaid as of the certification cut-off date in
accordance with this article shall have the balance on the account included in a preliminary
certification list.
(Ord. No. 150-10, § 2, 4-12-2010)
Sec 58-285 Delinquent Accounts
Delinquent accounts shall, in the discretion of the city or the commission be subject to any or all of the
following:
(a) Penalties. A late payment penalty of ten percent will be added to each delinquent account.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 53/54
(b) Shut-off for nonpayment. Utilities shall not be shut-off until notice and an opportunity for a preliminary
hearing before the general manager of the commission (the "initial hearing") and for an appeal
hearing before the commission (the "appeal hearing") has been provided to the occupant and owner
of the property involved as described below:
1. If any bill is not paid by the due date listed on the bill, a second bill will be mailed by first class
mail to the owner address provided when establishing the account and to the property
address, if different and shall contain a shut off notice ("shut off notice") stating that if payment
is not made or an initial hearing is not requested within ten days of the mailing of the second
bill, utility service to the premises will be shut off for nonpayment.
2. The second bill and shut off notice shall contain the address and telephone number of the
general manager of the commission. This information shall be clearly visible and easily
readable.
3. The shut off notice shall also state that the owner and/or occupant has the right to an initial
hearing before the utility service is shut-off by requesting such hearing in writing within ten
days of receipt of the shut off notice. If the written initial hearing request is not received by the
commission within such time period, the owner and occupant shall have no further hearing or
appeal rights. If both the owner and the occupant request an initial hearing, both shall appear
at the same hearing. The owner and/or occupant may be represented at the initial hearing in
person and by counsel or any other person of his, her or its choosing. The owner and/or
occupant may present orally or in writing his, her or its position to the general manager of the
commission. The general manager shall be authorized to order continuation of the utility
service and shall have the authority to adjust the owner's bill or enter into a mutually
agreeable payment plan. The general manager shall notify the owner and/or occupant of his
or her decision in writing within five days of the initial hearing. If no written decision is issued,
the owner's and/or occupant's position shall be deemed denied as of the end of such fifth day.
4. If after the initial hearing before the general manager of the commission, the owner and/or
occupant is unsatisfied with the decision of the general manager, the owner and/or occupant
may appeal the decision to the commission by written notice of appeal which must be
received by the commission within ten days of the date the general manager issues his or her
decision. The commission shall review such facts and documents and conduct such appeal
hearing and in such manner as it shall determine to be appropriate to make a decision
regarding the owner's and/or occupant's appeal. The decision of the commission is final.
5. If the owner and/or occupant requests an initial hearing before the general manager or
subsequent appeal hearing before the commission within the required time period for each,
the utilities shall not be shut off until the hearing process is complete.
6. If the owner and/or occupant fails to pay a delinquent account, fails to request an initial
hearing or subsequent to the initial hearing fails to request an appeal hearing in the manner
and in the time set forth herein, utility service relating to the delinquent account property will
be shut off at the time specified in the notice but not until the charges have been due and
unpaid for at least 30 days.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_58_UTILITIES 54/54
(c) Certification for collection with taxes. Unpaid charges on utility accounts shall not be certified to the
county auditor until notice (the "certification notice") and an opportunity for the initial hearing before
the general manager of the commission has been provided to the owner of the property involved in
the manner provided herein. The certification notice may be combined with the shut off notice
referenced in (b) above and will be mailed by first class mail to the owner's address provided when
establishing the account and shall state that if payment is not made before the date for certification,
the entire amount unpaid plus penalties will be certified to the county auditor for collection as other
taxes are collected. The certification notice shall also state that the owner may, before such
certification date, request an appeal hearing on the matter to object to certification of unpaid utility
charges as provided below.
1. The owner of the property shall have the option of paying the balance due on the account
without penalty until the date the certification notice is mailed. After the date the certification
notice is mailed, payments will still be accepted but any penalties will be added to the amount
due on the account.
2. If the owner of the property requests an appeal hearing by written notice received by the
commission within ten days of the date of the certification notice, an appeal hearing shall be
held on the matter by the commission. The commission may schedule one or more dates and
times for appeal hearings by property owners who have appealed the certification notice in a
timely manner. At such appeal hearing, property owners who have appealed the certification
notice as and when provided herein, shall be afforded the opportunity to object to the
certification of unpaid charges to be collected as taxes are collected.
3. If a property owner fails to properly appeal a certification notice or if, after the appeal hearing
(subject to subsection (4) below), the commission finds that the amounts claimed as
delinquent are actually due and unpaid and that there is no legal reason why the unpaid
charges should not be certified for collection as other taxes are collected, the list of delinquent
utilities shall be forwarded to the city council. The city council, by resolution, at the first
regularly scheduled meeting after receipt of such list, shall consider the certification of such
delinquent utilities to be certified to the Chisago County Auditor.
4. For each certification sustained at an appeal hearing, the property owner shall have the
following options:
a. Within ten days of the appeal hearing date, to pay the delinquent amount listed on the
preliminary roll including interest and late charges, but without additional interest after
the appeal hearing date;
b. After such ten-day period, but before the certification of such amounts by the city
council, to pay the delinquent amount plus late charges and interest at the rate set in
the adopted rate schedule through the date of payment; or
c. After certification by the city council, to pay the certified amount as billed to them by
Chisago County on their property tax statement with a collection term of one year.
5. Fifteen days after adoption thereof by the city council, the certified roll of delinquent accounts,
minus any payments received with respect to any such account, shall be delivered to Chisago
County by the city clerk.
(Ord. No. 150-10, § 2, 4-12-2010)

https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_62_VEHICLES_AND_TRAFFIC 1/7

Sec 62-1 State Statues Adopted
The regulatory provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 169, as amended, are adopted as the traffic regulations for
the use of highways, streets and alleys in the city and are incorporated in and made a part of this
chapter as completely as if set out in full in this chapter.
(Code 1996, § 10.04.010)
Sec 62-2 Adoption Of Other State Statutes By Reference
The following statutes of the state are adopted and incorporated by reference as an ordinance of the city
and the provisions set forth in this chapter shall be as much a part of this chapter as if they had been set
forth in full in this chapter:
Minn. Stats. § 160.27;
Minn. Stats. § 171.02 (1);
Minn. Stats. § 171.03;
Minn. Stats. § 171.08;
Minn. Stats. § 171.22;
Minn. Stats. § 171.23;
Minn. Stats. § 171.24;
Minn. Stats. § 171.32 (1);
Minn. Stats. § 171.322;
(Code 1996, § 10.04.020)
Sec 62-3 Unclassified Violations
No person shall operate a motor vehicle on a public highway, a street or alley, upon any public parking,
or upon any privately owned parking lot which is used or available for use by the general public in such a
manner as to cause or permit:
(a) The tires to squeal either by acceleration or braking;
(b) Excessive acceleration;
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_62_VEHICLES_AND_TRAFFIC 2/7
(c) Careless, reckless or unnecessary irregular erratic speeds;
(d) Unnecessary skidding or sliding;
(e) The simulation of a race; or
(f) Unnecessary abrupt turns or the swaying of the vehicle, except when an emergency creates the
necessity for such operation.
(Code 1996, § 10.04.060)
Sec 62-4 Certain Braking Prohibited
(a) It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to use, operate, or cause to be used or operated
within the city any mechanical exhaust device designed to aid in braking or deceleration of any
vehicle which results in the excessive, loud, unusual, or explosive noise. Truck speed decreasing
by engine braking is prohibited. Decreasing the speed of a truck by the method of running
against engine compression, downshifting to reduce speed instead of using regular air brakes,
commonly called "engine braking" is prohibited in the city, except when regular brakes are
inadequate to control the vehicle.
(b) Any person convicted of violation of this section will be punished for a first conviction by a fine of
not more than $100.00 or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed ten days, or by both a fine
and imprisonment; for a second such conviction within one year, such person shall be punished
by a fine of not more than $200.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 20 days, or both a fine
and imprisonment. Upon the third and subsequent conviction within one year after the first
conviction, such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment
for not more than six month, or both a fine and imprisonment.
(Code 1996, § 10.04.070)
ARTICLE II STOPPING, STANDING, PARKING
DIVISION 62-II-1 GENERALLY
DIVISION 2 PARKING
DIVISION 62-II-1 GENERALLY
DIVISION 2 PARKING
Sec 62-56 General Parking Regulations
Sec 62-56 General Parking Regulations
(a) The state shall have control over all usage including parking along State Trunk Highway 95 as
specified in Minn. Stats. § 161.18.
(b) Seventh Avenue shall be a one-way from Highway 95 going north one block to Elm Street and
one block going south to Maple Street. Diagonal parking shall be permitted on the designated
side and parallel parking on the opposite side except as otherwise posted.
(c) It is unlawful for anyone to park a vehicle for over two consecutive hours on a city street within
the North Branch central business district on Seventh Avenue from Maple Street to Elm Street
between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. except on Sundays and/or holidays.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_62_VEHICLES_AND_TRAFFIC 3/7
(d) Not withstanding any ordinance of the city to the contrary, it is unlawful for anyone to park a
vehicle on a public alley, street, or highway within the city between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and
7:00 a.m. from November 1 until April 1, inclusive, or after any snowstorm until the snow has
been removed or during snow removal time. It is unlawful for anyone to park a vehicle in a cityowned
parking lot, except by city permit, between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. from
November 1 until April 1, inclusive, or after any snowstorm until the snow has been removed or
during snow removal time. Any vehicles parking in violation of this section may be removed from
said street, highway, or alley and all charges for removal and storage resulting therefrom shall be
assessed against the owner of the vehicle.
(Code 1996, § 10.04.040; Ord. No. 109, § 1, 10-23-2006)
ARTICLE III SNOWMOBILES
Sec 62-86 Definitions
Sec 62-87 Where Prohibited
Sec 62-88 Street Crossing Regulations
Sec 62-89 State Law Adopted
Sec 62-90 Right-Of-Way
Sec 62-91 Operations Of Snowmobiles By Minors; Owner's Responsibility
Sec 62-92 Manner Of Operation
Sec 62-93 Equipment Required For Operation Of Snowmobile
Sec 62-94 Removal Of Keys
Sec 62-86 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Operate means to ride upon and control the operations of the snowmobile.
Operator means every person who operates or is in actual physical control of a snowmobile.
Snowmobile means a self-propelled vehicle designated for travel primarily on snow or ice steered by
wheels, skis, or runners. Snowmobile shall not include all terrain vehicles.
(Code 1996, § 10.12.010)
Sec 62-87 Where Prohibited
Except as specifically permitted and authorized in this article, no person shall operate a snowmobile:
(a) On any portion of any right-of-way of any public highway, street, road, trail, or alley used for
motor vehicle travel, except the most right-hand lane, other than on county highways, when used
as the most direct route to get to or from a designated trail. Snowmobiles may also be operated
upon the ditch bottom where lawfully so posted or the outside bank of trunk, county state-aid and
county highways where such highways are so configured within the corporate limits.
Snowmobiles may be operated on the following streets for the limited purpose of entering or
leaving the city or traveling to or from areas in which operation of snowmobiles is lawful and
businesses that provide support services such as gas stations and restaurants:
1. The entire length of Elm Street from Grand Avenue to 14th Avenue;
2. That portion of Oakview Avenue from Elm Street to Highway 95;
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_62_VEHICLES_AND_TRAFFIC 4/7
3. The ditch between the west side of County Road 30 and the railroad right-of-way between
the north and south city limits.
(b) On a public sidewalk provided for pedestrian travel;
(c) On boulevards within any public right-of-way;
(d) On private property of another without specific written permission of the owner or person in
control of the property;
(e) On any other public place except as may be specifically permitted by other provisions of this
Code.
(Code 1996, § 10.12.020)
Sec 62-88 Street Crossing Regulations
A snowmobile may make direct crossing of a street or highway, except in an interstate highway or
freeway, provided:
(a) The crossing is made at an angle of approximately 90 degrees to the direction of the street or
highway and at a place where no obstruction prevents a quick and safe crossing;
(b) The snowmobile is to yield at every street;
(c) The driver yields the right-of-way to all oncoming traffic which constitutes an immediate hazard;
(d) In crossing a divided street or highway, the crossing is made only at an intersection of such
street or highway with another public street or highway;
(e) If the crossing is made between the hours of one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before
sunrise or in conditions of reduced visibility, only if both front and rear lights are on.
(Code 1996, § 10.12.030)
Sec 62-89 State Law Adopted
Minn. Stats. §§ 84.81—84.88 shall apply to the operation of snowmobiles upon street and highways,
except those which by their nature have no application.
(Code 1996, § 10.12.040)
Sec 62-90 Right-Of-Way
No snowmobile shall enter any intersection without yielding the right-of-way to any vehicles or
pedestrians at the intersection, or so close to the intersection as to constitute an immediate hazard.
(Code 1996, § 10.12.050)
Sec 62-91 Operations Of Snowmobiles By Minors; Owner's Responsibility
(a) Operation. No person under 12 years of age shall operate on streets or the roadways surface of
highways or make a direct crossing of a trunk, county, state-aid, county highway, or city street as
the operator of a snowmobile. A person 12 years of age or older, but less than 18 years of age,
may operate a snowmobile on streets and highways as permitted under this chapter and make a
direct crossing on such streets and highways only if he has in his immediate possession a valid
snowmobile safety certificate issued by the commissioner, as provided by Minn. Stats. § 84.872.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_62_VEHICLES_AND_TRAFFIC 5/7
(b) Owner's responsibility. It is unlawful for the owner of a snowmobile to permit the snowmobile to
be operated contrary to the provisions of this section.
(Code 1996, § 10.12.060)
Sec 62-92 Manner Of Operation
No person shall operate a snowmobile:
(a) At any place while under the influence of alcohol or drugs as defined in Minn. Stats. § 169.121;
(b) At a rate of speed greater than the posted speed limit;
(c) At any place in a careless, reckless or negligent manner or heedlessly in disregard of the rights
or safety of others, or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger or cause injury or
damage to any person or property;
(d) During the hours from 1:00 a.m. to 7:00 a.m. on any city street;
(e) So as to tow any person or thing in a public street or highway except through use of a rigid tow
bar attached to the rear of the snowmobile;
(f) On any streets or roads where travel is prohibited by state law or on any street adjacent to public
skating rink grounds, or park or in any cemetery.
(Code 1996, § 10.12.070)
Sec 62-93 Equipment Required For Operation Of Snowmobile
No person shall operate a snowmobile any place within the city unless it is equipped with the following:
(a) Standard mufflers which are properly attached and which reduce the noise of operation of a
motor to the minimum necessary for operation. No person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass,
straight pipe or similar device on a snowmobile motor;
(b) Brakes adequate to control the movement of and to stop and hold the snowmobile under any
condition of operation;
(c) A safety or so called "deadman throttle" in operating condition. A safety or deadman throttle is
defined as a device which, when pressure is removed from the engine accelerator or throttle,
causes the motor to be disengaged from the driving track.
(d) When operated between the hours of one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise
or at times of reduced visibility at least one clear lamp attached to the front, with sufficient
intensity to reveal persons and vehicles at a distance of at least 100 feet ahead during the hours
of darkness shall be so aimed that glaring rays are not projected into the eyes of an oncoming
snowmobile operator. It shall also be equipped with at least one red tail lamp having a minimum
candlepower of sufficient intensity to exhibit a red light plainly visible from a distance of 500 feet
to the rear during hours of darkness under normal atmospheric conditions;
(e) Reflective material at least 16 square inches on each side, forward of the handlebars, so as to
reflect light at a 90 degree angle.
(Code 1996, § 10.12.080)
Sec 62-94 Removal Of Keys
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_62_VEHICLES_AND_TRAFFIC 6/7
Every person leaving a snowmobile in a public place shall lock the ignition, remove the key and take the
same with him.
(Code 1996, § 10.12.090)
ARTICLE IV LANDS OWNED BY INDEPENDENT SCHOOL DISTRICT NO 138
Sec 62-117 Authority
Sec 62-118 Scope
Sec 62-119 Parking
Sec 62-120 Speed Limit
Sec 62-121 Other Applicable Laws And Ordinances
Sec 62-117 Authority
This article is adopted pursuant to a Joint Powers Agreement between the city and Independent School
District No. 138, under the provisions of Minn. Stats. § 471.59.
(Code 1996, § 10.14.010)
Sec 62-118 Scope
This article shall apply to all lands owned, leased, occupied, and/or operated by Independent School
District No. 138.
(Code 1996, § 10.14.020)
Sec 62-119 Parking
(a) Only those motor vehicles belonging to or otherwise driven by students with a valid school
parking permit, employees of Independent School District No. 138 and authorized visitors may
park upon school district property.
(b) Parking is prohibited on school district property between the hours of 12:30 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
on any day, except the following:
1. Motor vehicles that are owned, operated or leased by the school district.
2. Motor vehicles owned or driven by authorized persons who are in attendance at an
approved activity which is not completed by 12:30 a.m. All such vehicles must be
removed from the school district property within 30 minutes after completion of the
approved activity.
3. Motor vehicles belonging to school district employees whose hours of employment
require their presence at the school district after 12:30 a.m.
(c) Parking is prohibited on school district roadways, sidewalks, landscaped areas, fire lanes, safety
zones, and loading zones within ten feet of intersections, adjacent to yellow curbs and in areas
where parking is expressly prohibited by signs, except:
1. Those vehicles owned, operated, or leased by the school district when being used in the
performance of work on school district property.
2. Those vehicles delivering goods to the school district may park in the loading zones
during required delivery time.
(d) Any driver or other person in charge of a motor vehicle parking in violation of these regulations
shall move the vehicle off school district property when directed to do so by a school district
official.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_62_VEHICLES_AND_TRAFFIC 7/7
(e) Any motor vehicle parked on school district property in violation of this ordinance is subject to
removal from the school district property by an authorized towing representative and stored. The
cost of any such removal and storage of the vehicle shall be at the sole expense of the owner or
operator of said vehicle.
(f) Parking lanes and lots are designated by painted lines. Parking in lanes or in a position which
occupies more than one lane is prohibited
(g) All vehicles shall follow directional arrows and signs in gaining entrance to, exit from, and while
traveling upon parking areas.
(Code 1996, § 10.14.030)
Sec 62-120 Speed Limit
No motor vehicle shall be driven more than 15 miles per hour while on school district property.
(Code 1996, § 10.14.040)
Sec 62-121 Other Applicable Laws And Ordinances
Nothing in this article shall restrict state, county, or local law enforcement agencies from enforcing state
or local traffic laws in effect upon any school district property.
(Code 1996, § 10.14.050)

Chapter 66 ZONING

Sec 66-2 Relation To Comprehensive Municipal Plan
