Sec 66-318 Yard, Area, And Building Size Requirements; Townhouses
The following are yard, area and building size regulations for permitted townhouse developments
containing three or more dwelling units in the R-3 high-density residential district.
(a) Total lot area: a minimum of 7,500 square feet per dwelling unit.
(b) Total width at front yard setback line: a minimum of 150 feet.
(c) Total minimum lot depth: 100 feet.
(d) Yard dimensions:
1. Front yard setback: 30 feet from the lot line or road right-of-way if applicable.
2. Side yard setback (each end of row): minimum of six feet from the (interior) lot lines or
zero if dwelling unit is attached.
3. Corner side yard setback: minimum of 30 feet from the lot line or road right-of-way if
applicable.
4. Rear yard setback for interior lots: minimum of 30 feet from the lot line.
5. Rear yard setback for corner lots: minimum of 15 feet from the lot line.
(e) Wetland setback:
1. A 20-foot natural buffer shall be maintained adjacent to all wetlands on lots created after
the adoption of this chapter.
2. A minimum 40-foot setback is required for all structures adjacent to all wetlands on lots
created after the adoption of this chapter.
(f) Maximum building height: 35 feet.
(g) Maximum impervious area: 70 percent.
(h) Floor elevation:
1. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be three feet above the highest
known groundwater level.
2. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be two feet above the 100-year
flood elevation.
(Code 1996, § 17.12.070; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)
Sec 66-319 Yard, Area And Building Size Requirements; Apartment Dwellings
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 72/215
The following are yard, area and building size regulations for apartment dwellings in the R-3 high-density
residential district.
(a) Lot area:
1. Minimum square feet of lot area per dwelling unit:
a. Structures with four dwelling units or fewer shall have a minimum lot area of
20,000 sq. ft. An additional 2,500 sq. ft. is required for each unit over four.
b. Units for the elderly require 1,500 sq. ft. of lot area per dwelling unit with a 15,000
sq. ft. minimum lot size.
2. Apartment density bonus. A maximum of ten percent reduction in square feet of lot area
per unit for multiple family dwellings is allowed based upon the following bonus features
and square foot reductions:
Bonus Feature Reduction Per Unit
Type two construction 100 sq. ft.
Elevator serving each floor 100 sq. ft.
Indoor recreation and social rooms with a minimum of
25 square feet per unit 50 sq. ft.
Outdoor recreational facilities as approved by the
planning commission and city council 20 sq. ft.
One-half of the required parking underground or within
the principle building 150 sq. ft.
(b) Lot width at front yard setback line: minimum of 150 feet.
(c) Minimum lot depth: 100 feet.
(d) Yard dimensions:
1. Front yard setback: 30 feet from the road right-of-way.
2. Side yard setback (each side of apartment building): minimum of ten feet from the
(interior) lot lines or easement line if applicable.
3. Corner side yard setback: minimum of 30 feet from the lot line or road right-of-way.
4. Rear yard setback for interior lots: minimum of 30 feet from the lot line or easement line if
applicable.
5. Rear yard setback for corner lots: 15 feet from the lot line.
(e) Wetland setback:
1. A 20-foot natural buffer shall be maintained adjacent to all wetlands on lots created after
the adoption of this chapter.
2. A minimum 40-foot setback is required for all structures adjacent to all wetlands on lots
created after the adoption of this chapter.
(f) Maximum building height: 42 feet.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 73/215
(g) Maximum impervious area is 75 percent. All the impervious area shall be appropriately
landscaped with natural plant material. At least 75 percent of the pervious area shall be lawn or
turf. Such landscaping shall include a minimum of one tree (2.5? caliper/5' height) for every
dwelling unit.
(h) Maximum building size: 16 dwelling units in a building unless a conditional use permit has been
approved.
(i) Maximum ground coverage: Not more than 35 percent of the lot shall be covered by main
buildings and all accessory buildings.
(j) Floor elevation:
1. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be three feet above the highest
known groundwater level.
2. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be two feet above the 100-year
flood elevation.
(Code 1996, § 17.12.080; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)

Sec 66-346 Purpose
The purpose of the R-4 manufactured home district is to provide for manufactured home uses in an
appropriate, safe, sanitary and attractive environment.
(Code 1996, § 17.14.010)
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 74/215
Sec 66-347 Permitted Uses
The following are permitted uses within a R-4 manufactured home district:
(a) Manufactured homes in manufactured home parks/developments.
(Code 1996, § 17.14.020)
Sec 66-348 Accessory Uses
The following are accessory uses within a R-4 manufactured home district:
(a) Off-street private parking facilities.
(b) Recreational vehicles and equipment properly located on property.
(c) Swimming pools which have the necessary city permits, tennis courts and other recreational
facilities.
(d) Fencing, screening and landscaping as provided and regulated by section 66-970 et seq.
(e) Signs in conformance with section 66-821 et seq.
(f) Central office and community building.
(g) Rental shop, renting tools and equipment to residents of park and others. Any outside storage
areas must be approved by planning commission.
(h) Storage shed not to exceed ten feet by 12 feet or a private garage if the lots are independently
owned.
(i) Home occupation in accordance with section 66-942.
(j) Essential service buildings of 1,000 square feet or less.
(k) Rummage/garage sales (see definition).
(Code 1996, § 17.14.030; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)
Sec 66-349 Conditional Uses
There are no allowed conditional uses within a R-4 manufactured home district.
(Code 1996, § 17.14.040)
Sec 66-350 District Regulations
(a) General provisions:
1. Previously owned manufactured homes shall be pre-approved before moving one into a
Manufactured Home Park. No manufactured home for residential purposes, under 24 feet
in width shall be permitted on any site within the city unless the site is part of a
manufactured home park/development approved by the state department of
administration in accordance with Minn. Stats. § 327.14.2, Minnesota State Building
Code.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 75/215
2. Manufactured homes shall not be used for residential purposes in the city if they:
a. Do not conform to the requirements of the vehicle code of the state.
b. Are in an unsanitary condition or have an exterior in bad repair.
c. Are structurally unsound and do not protect the inhabitants against all elements.
d. Do not have adequate sewage facilities as required by the city council in
accordance with the state department of health regulations.
e. Do not meet Manufactures Specification and State Building Codes.
3. No tents shall be used for other than recreational purposes in a manufactured home
park/development.
4. Access to manufactured home park/developments shall be as approved by the city.
5. Manufactured home parks shall have an adequate central community building with the
following features:
a. Laundry drying areas and machines.
b. Laundry washing machines.
c. Emergency shelter.
d. Public toilets and lavatories.
Such buildings shall have central heating and be maintained in safe, clean and
sanitary condition.
6. Expansions to existing manufactured home parks/developments shall be subject to the
provision placed on subdivisions within the city subdivision ordinances (located in chapter
54 of this Code).
7. Manufactured homes in existing parks/developments that are located in floodplain
districts are nonconforming uses and may be replaced only if in compliance with the
following conditions:
a. The manufactured home lies in the flood fringe district.
b. The manufactured home is anchored with tie downs that comply with
Manufactures Specifications or the Minnesota State Building Code and subsection
d. below.
c. The manufactured home owner or renter is notified that the manufactured home
site lies in the floodplain and may be subject to flooding.
d. The manufactured home park owner develops a flood emergency plan consistent
with the time available after a flood warning. The plan shall be filed with and
approved by the department of natural resources.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 76/215
8. Emergency shelter shall be updated and inspected between the 1st of April and the 1st of
May of each year.
a. Emergency shelters shall be:
i. Approved by city council.
ii. Structurally sound.
iii. Provide adequate room for the residents of the manufactured home park.
iv. Provide easy access into the storm shelter.
(b) A site plan shall be submitted to the planning commission and city council in accordance with
procedures outlined and information required in chapter 54.
(Code 1996, § 17.14.050; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)
Sec 66-351 Design Standards
The following are minimum design standards for the R-4 manufactured home district:
(a) Enclosure. The area beneath a manufactured home shall be enclosed, except that such
enclosure must have access for inspection and vented to code.

https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 77/215

affixed to foundations and installed to Manufactures Specifications/Minnesota State Building
Code. When manufactures specification are not available then anchoring shall meet the state
department of administration, building code division and the number of ties shall be in
accordance with the following table:

(c) Utilities.
1. All manufactured homes shall be connected to a public water and sanitary sewer system
or a private water and sewer system approved by the state department of health.
2. All installations for disposal of surface stormwater must be approved by the state
department of health.
3. All utility connections shall be as approved by the city.
4. All utilities shall be underground. There shall be no overhead wires or supporting poles
except those essential for street or other lighting.
5. The method of garbage, waste, and trash disposal must be approved by the city.
6. Owner shall pay any required sewer connection fees to the city.
(d) Streets.
1. Streets shall be hard surfaced as approved by the city.
2. Streets shall have a hard surfaced curb and gutter.
3. The minimum paved street width, shall be 32 feet unless city council approval is given for
a 28-foot rural section.
(e) Recreation. All manufactured home parks/developments shall have at least ten percent of the
land areas developed for recreational use (tennis courts, childrens' play equipment, swimming
pool, golf green, etc.) developed and maintained at the owner-operator's expense, unless the city
agrees to maintain the recreational land.
(f) Lighting. Artificial light shall be maintained during all hours of darkness in all buildings containing
public toilets, laundry equipment and the like.
(Code 1996, § 17.14.060; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)
Sec 66-352 Yard And Area Requirements
The following are yard and area regulations for the R-4 manufactured home district.
(a) Minimum lot area for each manufactured home: 4,000 square feet of land area for the exclusive
use of the occupant.
(b) Minimum lot width: 40 feet.
(c) Minimum lot depth: 100 feet.
(d) Minimum road frontage: 16 feet in width on an approved roadway.
(e) The corner of each manufactured home site shall be marked and each site shall be numbered.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 79/215
(f) Yard dimensions:
1. Front yard setback: 20 feet from the road right-of-way or lot line.
2. Side yard setback: minimum of six feet from the (interior) lot lines.
3. Corner side yard setback: minimum of ten feet from the lot line or road right-of-way.
4. Rear yard setback: minimum of ten feet from the lot line or easement line if applicable.
5. No unit or building shall be located within 30 feet of the exterior boundary of any
manufactured home park/district.
(g) Wetland setback:
1. A 20-foot natural buffer shall be maintained adjacent to all wetlands on lots created after
the adoption of this chapter.
2. A minimum 40-foot setback is required for all structures adjacent to all wetlands on lots
created after the adoption of this chapter.
(h) Floor elevation:
1. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be three feet above the highest
known groundwater level.
2. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be two feet above the 100-year
flood elevation.
(Code 1996, § 17.14.070; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)
Sec 66-353 Fencing, Screening, And Landscaping Requirements
The following fencing, screening and landscaping requirements apply to all developments in the R-4
manufactured home district:
(a) A green belt, at least 20 feet in width, shall be located along all boundaries of the manufactured
home park/development, except where it is crossed by driveways, streets and roads.
(b) Additional fencing, screening and landscaping standards and requirements are contained in
section 66-970 et seq.
(Code 1996, § 17.14.080)
Sec 66-354 Signs
All signs within the district shall comply with section 66-821 et seq.
(Code 1996, § 17.14.090)
Sec 66-355 Off-Street Parking And Loading
The following parking and loading regulations apply in the R-4 manufactured home district:
(a) Each manufactured home site shall have off-street parking space for two automobiles.
(b) Each manufactured home park shall maintain a hard surfaced off-street parking lot for guests of
occupants in the amount of one space for each five manufactured home sites.

Sec 66-393 Animals In AG-1 Districts
Sec 66-384 Purpose
The purpose of the AG-1 agricultural district is to preserve, promote, maintain and enhance the use of
land for agricultural purposes and to protect such land from encroachment by nonagricultural uses.
(Code 1996, § 17.16.010)
Sec 66-385 Permitted Uses
The following are permitted uses in the AG-1 agricultural district:
(a) Agriculture, including farm dwellings and agricultural related buildings and structures subject to
Minnesota Pollution Control Standards.
(b) Commercial agricultural uses.
(c) Public parks, recreational areas, historical sites, wildlife areas and game refuges.
(d) Single-family residences.
(e) Boarding (house) home, foster children. Restricted to serving six or fewer persons.
(f) Day care home. Restricted to a family dwelling in which foster care, supervision, and training for
children of school or pre-school age, out of their own home is provided during part of a day (less
than 24 hours) with no overnight accommodations or facilities and children are delivered and
removed daily. All such uses shall be licensed in accordance with state law and state department
of public welfare regulations and such facilities are restricted to serving ten or fewer persons.
(g) A state licensed residential facility serving from one to six mentally or physically disabled
persons.
(h) Solar farms as a principal use, in accordance with the provisions of article XI (solar energy
systems) of the zoning ordinance.
(Code 1996, § 17.16.020; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010; Ord. No. 211-14, § 2, 7-28-2014)

Operation and storage of such vehicles, equipment and machinery which are incidental to permitted or

Sec 66-386.5 Interim Uses
The following uses are interim uses in the AG1 (agricultural) district that require city council approval of
an interim use permit and shall be in conformance with the standards specified in section 66-64 of this
ordinance and the additional standards specified below:
(a) One temporary manufactured home for the property owners to occupy when rebuilding their
primary residence after a fire, flood, tornado, wind damage or other destructive event or for the
parents, grandparents or children of the property owners subject to:
1. The manufactured home would be located on a parcel of at least one-half acre (21,780
square feet) of buildable land with one permanent dwelling. The occupant(s) of either the
manufactured home or the permanent dwelling must be:
a. The parents(s) or grandparents of the occupant of the other residence on the
property; or
b. A child, sister, brother or grandchild who has full or total disability as classified by
Social Security, Worker's compensation or a doctor and who resides in or will
reside in one of the residences.
2. The applicant shall submit with the initial application and annually thereafter, a signed
statement certifying that the occupants of the manufactured home is a parent,
grandparent, child, sister or brother who suffers a full or total disability as classified by
Social Security, Worker's Compensation or a doctor. The statement shall describe the
need that makes it necessary for parents. Grandparents or relative of the first degree to
live on the same parcel with the children or children or a release that will allow the city
administrator or his/her designee to verify the disability.
3. The owner shall remove the manufactured home from the site within 120 days of such
time as it or the permanent residence ceases to be occupied by a parent, grandparent,
grandchild, child, sister or brother.
4. The owner shall not make the manufactured home a permanent residence.
5. The manufactured home shall not require the creation of a separate well.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 82/215
6. An on-site sewage treatment system to serve the manufactured home can be installed on
the property in accordance to all city and state standards or if possible, the owners may
attach the sewage system for the manufactured home to an existing on-site sewage
system if the existing system has enough capacity for additional users.
7. The placement of the proposed manufactured home must meet all setback standards and
shall not cause drainage or stormwater run-off problems for adjacent properties.
8. The owner shall not place the manufactured home in a front yard.
9. The owner submitting to the city an escrow, issued in the name of the city and payable to
the city, for the sum of $5,000.00 that the city may draw down at its sole discretion for the
purposes including, but not limited to, the cost of capping and closing of any separate onsite
sewage treatment systems or wells, site restoration, administrative and legal fees and
the repayment of delinquent personal property taxes on the manufactured home. The city
shall hold the escrow for as long as the manufactured home is on the property and shall
return the escrow within 90 days of the completion of all necessary site restoration.
(Ord. No. 210-14, § 4, 7-14-2014)
Sec 66-387 Conditional Uses
The following are conditional uses in the AG-1 agricultural district, which require a conditional use permit
based upon procedures, factors and conditions set forth in and regulated by section 66-62 et seq.:
(a) Public- or semi-public recreational buildings and neighborhood or community centers; public and
private educational institutions, limited to elementary, junior high, senior high schools and post
secondary facilities; and religious institutions such as churches, chapels, temples and
synagogues.
(b) Governmental and public utility buildings and structures necessary for the health, safety and
general welfare of the community.
(c) Commercial outdoor recreational areas including golf courses and clubhouse country clubs,
swimming pools which have the necessary city permits and similar facilities.
(d) Commercial riding stables, dog kennels and similar uses.
(e) Recreational, travel vehicle campsites, not including manufactured homes.
(f) Bed and breakfast inns.
(g) Living quarters for persons employed on the premises.
(h) Licensed day care facility located in the same building or parcel as a religious institution such as
churches, chapels, temples, and synagogues, provided the regulations of the Human Services
Licensing Act, Minn. Stats. ch. 245A, and the state building, fire and health regulations are
satisfactorily met.
(i) Multiple principal buildings on a lot of record for churches and schools provided the buildings are
under common ownership and the buildings are used for related uses.
(j) Residential planned unit development as regulated by section 66-788 et seq.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 83/215
(k) Plumbing in accessory structures subject to the following:
1. The accessory structure shall not be converted into living area. The conditional use is for
bathroom facilities only.
2. The property may be inspected at any time to assure compliance with the conditional use
permit.
3. If the accessory structure is converted into living area then all cost associated with
converting it back, including any legal fees, are the responsibility of the property owner.
(l) Buildings only owned and used by religious institutions for support or related functions or
activities of a religious institution.
(Code 1996, § 17.16.040; Ord. No. 102, § 1 (17.16.045), 10-24-2005; Ord. No. 135-09, § 1, 5-11-2009;
Ord. No. 139-09, § 1, 8-10-2009; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010; Ord. No. 224-15, § 6, 4-28-2015)
HISTORY
Amended by Ord. 266-17 on 9/12/2017
Sec 66-388 Design Standards
The following are minimum design standards for the AG-1 agricultural district:
(a) Dwelling units in this zoning district must meet the following minimum structural design
standards:
1. Minimum ground floor area shall be 800 square feet for a single story dwelling. A dwelling
unit with one and a half or more stories shall have a minimum of 800 square feet on main
floor.
2. Permanent full perimeter footings; with foundation walls of concrete, concrete block,
wood, or any other approved material or method. Decks and porches are allowed on pier
type footings.
3. Minimum width: 24 feet.
4. A minimum roof pitch of 4/12, 4" vertical rise for each 12" horizontal run.
5. Provisions for decks must be shown on original plans when a sliding glass door, patio
door, etc. are installed.
6. Compliance with the requirements of the State Building Code.
(b) Garages in this zoning district must meet the following minimum structural design standards:
1. Rear or side yard or attached garage required except when the garage is located in the
front yard on lots nominally five acres or larger.
2. Minimum size: 400 square feet.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 84/215
(c) Accessory building in this zoning district must meet the following minimum structural design
standards:
1. Shall not be erected within six feet of any lot boundary or alley. Corner side-yard setbacks
shall apply to all accessory structures. Accessory structures shall not be constructed in
the front yard except on lots nominally five acres or larger and shall be set back at least
50 feet from the front property line.
2. Additional standards and requirements for accessory buildings are contained in section
66-898.
(d) Accessory buildings in this zoning district must meet the following minimum structural design
standards:
1. Only those lots of ten acres or more and which receive green acres credits or are being
used for an agricultural use as described in section 66-170 et seq., may use the
provisions pertaining to agricultural accessory buildings.
2. There are no size or quantity limitations on agricultural accessory buildings.
3. A locate/site permit is required for all agricultural accessory buildings.
4. Agriculture accessory buildings shall not be erected within six feet of any lot boundary or
alley.
5. Accessory buildings on lots in the AG zoning district which are not ten acres or receive
green acres credits shall not be closer than six feet from the lot line. Size and height shall
be regulated by section 66-898.
(Code 1996, § 17.16.050; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010; Ord. No. 187-12, § 1, 4-9-2012)
Sec 66-389 Yard, Area, And Building Size Requirements
The following are yard, area and building size regulations for permitted dwellings units in the AG
agricultural district.
(a) Lot area: a minimum of ten acres.
(b) Lot width: minimum of 300 feet.
(c) Minimum lot depth: 500 feet.
(d) Yard dimensions:
1. Front yard setback: minimum 50 feet from the lot line or road right-of-way if applicable.
2. Side yard setback (each side): minimum 50 feet from the interior lot line(s).
3. Rear yard setback: minimum of 50 feet from the lot line.
(e) Maximum building height: 35 feet for principal residence or dwelling unit.
(f) Maximum impervious area: 50 percent.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 85/215
(g) Wetland setback:
1. A 20-foot natural buffer shall be maintained adjacent to all wetlands on lots created after
the adoption of this chapter.
2. A minimum 40-foot setback is required for all structures adjacent to all wetlands on lots
created after the adoption of this chapter.
(h) Floor elevation:
1. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be three feet above the highest
known groundwater level.
2. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be two feet above the 100-year
flood elevation.
(Code 1996, § 17.16.060; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)
Sec 66-390 Fencing, Screening, And Landscaping Requirements
The fencing, screening and landscaping requirements in section 66-970 et seq. shall apply to all
developments in the AG-1 agricultural district except for the following:
(a) Permits are not required for fences on bona fide farms in the AG-1 zone.
(Code 1996, § 17.16.070)
Sec 66-391 Signs
All signs within the AG-1 agricultural district shall comply with section 66-821 et seq.
(Code 1996, § 17.16.080)
Sec 66-392 Off-Street Parking And Loading
For permitted single-family dwellings, two off-street parking and loading spaces shall be provided and
maintained. All other uses must comply with section 66-848 et seq.
(Code 1996, § 17.16.090)
Sec 66-393 Animals In AG-1 Districts
Livestock, as defined under this division, can be kept on lots in AG-1 districts if they meet any of the
following criteria:
(a) Bona fide farm as defined under this division.
(b) Lots 40 acres or larger. There is no limit on the amount of animals that can be kept on the lot with
the exception that commercial feedlots are prohibited.
(c) For lots between ten and 40 acres, animals may be kept at the rate of one animal for every two
acres. Pens, roosts, barns, and other holding areas are considered accessory buildings and must
setback at least 75 feet from the side and/or rear lot lines.
(d) For lots between five and ten acres, animals may be kept at the rate of one animal for every one
accessible acre. To qualify as an accessible acre, the area must be fenced or enclosed. One
acre must be reserved for the house.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 86/215
(Code 1996, § 17.16.100; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)

Sec 66-415 Purpose
The purpose of the AG-2 agricultural district is to preserve, promote, maintain and enhance the use of
land for agricultural purposes and to protect such land from encroachment by nonagricultural uses.
(Code 1996, § 17.17.010)

(a) Agriculture, including farm dwellings and agricultural related buildings and structures subject to
state pollution control standards.
(b) Commercial agricultural uses.
(c) Public parks, recreational areas, historical sites, wildlife areas and game refuges.
(d) Single-family residences.
(e) Boarding (house) home, foster children. Restricted to serving six or fewer persons.
(f) Day care home. Restricted to a family dwelling in which foster care, supervision, and training for
children of school or pre-school age, out of their own home is provided during part of a day (less
than 24 hours) with no overnight accommodations or facilities and children are delivered and
removed daily. All such uses shall be licensed in accordance with state law and state department
of public welfare regulations and such facilities are restricted to serving ten or fewer persons.
(g) A state licensed residential facility serving from one to six mentally or physically disabled
persons.
(h) Solar farms as a principal use, in accordance with the provisions of article XI (solar energy
systems) of the zoning ordinance.
(Code 1996, § 17.17.020; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010; Ord. No. 211-14, § 2, 7-28-2014)

DIVISION 9 RR RURAL RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT
Sec 66-447 Purpose

Sec 66-447 Purpose
The purpose of the RR rural residential district is:
(a) To prevent scattered nonfarm uses from developing improperly.
(b) To allow suitable areas of the city to be retained and utilized in open space and/or agricultural
uses.
(c) To promote orderly development and secure economy in government expenditures for public
utilities and service.
(Code 1996, § 17.18.010)
Sec 66-448 Permitted Uses
The following are permitted uses in the RR rural residential district:
(a) Agriculture, including farm dwellings and agricultural related buildings and structures subject to
state pollution control standards, but not including commercial feedlots or other commercial
operations.
(b) Public parks, recreational areas, wildlife areas and game refuges.
(c) Single-family detached dwellings.
(d) Boarding (house) home, foster children. Restricted to serving six or fewer persons.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 93/215
(e) Day care home. Restricted to a family dwelling in which foster care, supervision, and training for
children of school or pre-school age, out of their own home is provided during part of a day (less
than 24 hours) with no overnight accommodations or facilities and children are delivered and
removed daily. All such uses shall be licensed in accordance with state law and state department
of public welfare regulations and such facilities are restricted to serving ten or fewer persons.
(f) A state licensed residential facility serving from one to six mentally or physically disabled
persons.
(g) Solar farms as a principal use, in accordance with the provisions of article XI (solar energy
systems) of the zoning ordinance.
(Code 1996, § 17.18.020; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010; Ord. No. 211-14, § 2, 7-28-2014)
Sec 66-449 Accessory Uses
The following are permitted accessory uses in the RR rural residential district:
1. Operation and storage of such vehicles, equipment and machinery which are incidental to
permitted or conditional uses allowed in this district.
2. Home occupations in accordance with section 66-942.
3. Fencing, screening and landscaping in compliance with section 66-453.
4. Boat houses, piers and docks.
5. Signs in compliance with section 66-821 et seq.
6. Essential services.
7. Essential service buildings of 1,000 square feet or less.
8. Rummage/garage sales (see definition).
9. Accessory Structures non-agricultural related
(Code 1996, § 17.18.030; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)

Sec 66-449.5 Interim Uses
The following uses are interim uses in the RR (rural residential) district that require city council approval
of an interim use permit and shall be in conformance with the standards specified in section 66-64 of this
chapter and the additional standards specified below:
(a) One temporary manufactured home for the property owners to occupy when rebuilding their
primary residence after a fire, flood, tornado, wind damage or other destructive event or for the
parents, grandparents or children of the property owners subject to:
1. The manufactured home would be located on a parcel of at least one-half acre (21,780
square feet) of buildable land with one permanent dwelling. The occupant(s) of either the
manufactured home or the permanent dwelling must be:
a. The parents(s) or grandparents of the occupant of the other residence on the
property; or
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 94/215
b. A child, sister, brother or grandchild who has full or total disability as classified by
Social Security, Worker's compensation or a doctor and who resides in or will
reside in one of the residences.
2. The applicant shall submit with the initial application and annually thereafter, a signed
statement certifying that the occupants of the manufactured home is a parent,
grandparent, child, sister or brother who suffers a full or total disability as classified by
Social Security, Worker's Compensation or a doctor. The statement shall describe the
need that makes it necessary for parents. Grandparents or relative of the first degree to
live on the same parcel with the children or children or a release that will allow the city
administrator or his/her designee to verify the disability.
3. The owner shall remove the manufactured home from the site within 120 days of such
time as it or the permanent residence ceases to be occupied by a parent, grandparent,
child, sister, brother or grandchild.
4. The owner shall not make the manufactured home a permanent residence.
5. The manufactured home shall not require the creation of a separate well.
6. An on-site sewage treatment system to serve the manufactured home can be installed on
the property in accordance to all city and state standards or if possible, the owners may
attach the sewage system for the manufactured home to an existing on-site sewage
system if the existing system has enough capacity for additional users.
7. The placement of the proposed manufactured home must meet all setback standards and
shall not cause drainage or stormwater run-off problems for adjacent properties.
8. The owner shall not place the manufactured home in a front yard.
9. The owner submitting to the city an escrow, issued in the name of the city and payable to
the city, for the sum of $5,000.00 that the city may draw down at its sole discretion for the
purposes including, but not limited to, the cost of capping and closing of any separate onsite
sewage treatment systems or wells, administrative and legal fees and the repayment
of delinquent personal property taxes on the manufactured home. The city shall hold the
escrow for as long as the manufactured home is on the property. The city shall hold the
escrow for as long as the manufactured home is on the property and shall return the
escrow within 90 days of the completion of all necessary site restoration.
(Ord. No. 210-14, § 6, 7-14-2014)
Sec 66-450 Conditional Uses
The following are conditional uses in the RR rural residential district which require a conditional use
permit based upon procedures, conditions and factors set forth in and regulated by section 66-62 et
seq.:
(a) Public- or semi-public recreational buildings and neighborhood or community centers; public and
private educational institutions; religious institutions; and ancillary structures, activities and
services that are operated in support of these conditionally approved uses. Multiple principal
buildings on a lot of record for churches and schools are allowed provided the buildings are
under common ownership and the buildings are used for related uses.
(b) Governmental and public utility buildings and structures necessary for the health, safety and
general welfare of the community.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 95/215
(c) Commercial outdoor recreational areas including golf courses and clubhouse country clubs,
swimming pools with the necessary city permits and similar facilities.
(d) Commercial riding stables, dog kennels and similar uses.
(e) Recreational, travel vehicle campsites, not including manufactured homes.
(f) Bed and breakfast inns.
(g) Living quarters of persons employed on the premises.
(h) Licensed day care facility located in the same building or parcel as a religious institution such as
churches, chapels, temples, and synagogues, provided the regulations of the Human Services
Licensing Act, Minn. Stats. ch. 245A, and the state building, fire and health regulations are
satisfactorily met.
(i) Residential planned unit developments as regulated by chapter 66-788 et seq.
(j) Plumbing in accessory structures subject to the following:
1. The accessory structure shall not be converted into living area. The conditional use is for
bathroom facilities only.
2. The property may be inspected at any time to assure compliance with the conditional use
permit.
3. If the accessory structure is converted into living area then all cost associated with
converting it back including any legal fees are the responsibility of the property owner.
(Code 1996, § 17.18.040; Ord. No. 135-09, § 1, 5-11-2009; Ord. No. 139-09, § 1, 8-10-2009; Ord. No.
153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010; Ord. No. 224-15, § 1, 4-28-2015)

Sec 66-451 Design Standards
The following are minimum design standards for the RR rural residential district:
(a) Dwelling units in this zoning district must meet the following minimum structural design
standards:
1. Minimum ground floor area shall be 800 square feet for a single story dwelling. A dwelling
unit with one and a half or more stories shall have a minimum of 800 square feet on main
floor.
2. Permanent full perimeter footings; with foundation walls of concrete, concrete block,
wood, or any other approved material or method. Decks and porches are allowed on pier
type footings.
3. Minimum width: 24 feet.
4. A minimum roof pitch of 4/12, 4" vertical rise for each 12" horizontal run.
5. Provisions for decks must be shown on original plans when a sliding glass door, patio
door, etc. are installed.
6. Compliance with the requirements of the State Building Code.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 96/215
(b) Garages in this zoning district must meet the following minimum structural design standards:
1. Rear or side yard or attached garage required except when the garage is located in the
front yard on lots nominally five acres or larger.
2. Minimum size: 400 square feet.
(c) Accessory buildings in this zoning district must meet the following minimum structural design
standards:
1. Shall not be erected within six feet of any lot boundary or alley.
2. Additional standards and requirements for accessory buildings are contained in section
66-898.
3. Accessory structures shall be not constructed in the front yard except on lots nominally
five acres or larger, set back at least 40 feet from the front property line.
(Code 1996, § 17.18.050; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010; Ord. No. 187-12, § 1, 4-9-2012)
Sec 66-452 Yard, Area, And Building Size Requirements
The following are yard, area and building size regulations for permitted dwelling units in the RR rural
residential district:
(a) For lots outside of the Urban Service Area, a minimum of 1.0 acre buildable.
(b) For lots within the Urban Service Area and connected to municipal utilities, 12000 ft2; provided
however, no new lots can be created within Urban Service Area that are not connected to
municipal services, unless they established according to the terms of an approved PUD under
Sections 66-788 through 66-798.
(c) Lots of record created prior to July 21, 2017 shall be deemed legal lots for purposes of this
section but subject to the requirements of Sec. 58-76
(d) Lot width at front yard setback line: minimum of 110 feet for property located within the 20-year
growth area. A minimum of 110 feet for property located outside the 20-year growth area.
(e) Minimum lot depth: 300 feet.
(f) Yard dimensions:
1. Front yard setback: 40 feet from the lot line or road right-of-way if applicable.
2. Side yard setback (each side): minimum ten feet from the interior lot lines.
3. Corner side yard setback: minimum of 30 feet from the lot line or road right-of-way if
applicable.
4. Rear yard setback for interior lots: minimum of 30 feet from the lot line.
5. Rear yard setback for corner lots: 15 feet from the lot line.
(g) Maximum building height: 35 feet.
(h) Maximum impervious area: 50 percent.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 97/215
(i) Wetland setback:
1. A 20-foot natural buffer shall be maintained adjacent to all wetlands on lots created after
the adoption of this chapter.
2. A minimum 40-foot setback is required for all structures adjacent to all wetlands on lots
created after the adoption of this chapter.
(j) Floor elevation:
1. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be three feet above the highest
known groundwater level.
2. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be two feet above the 100-year
flood elevation.
(k) Lot area:
1. Within the Urban Service Area
I acre lot of upland/buildable are with 9 or more acres within a lot that is restricted for
future development with a PUD. The location of the 1 acre lot will be in a location that will
minimize the impact on extending City services.
2. Outside of the Urban Service Area:
A minimum of 1.0 acre of upland/buildable for property located outside the Urban Service
Area.
(Code 1996, § 17.18.060; Ord. No. 108, § 1, 7-10-2006; Ord. No. 110A, § 1, 11-27-2006; Ord. No. 153-
10, § 1, 8-9-2010; Ord. No. 157-11, § 1, 1-10-2011; Ord. No. 199-13, §§ 1, 2, 5-28-2013)

Sec 66-456 Animals In RR District
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 98/215
Livestock, as defined under this division, can only be kept on lots in RR rural residential districts if they
meet any of the following criteria:
(a) Bona fide farm as defined under this division.
(b) Lots 40 acres or larger. There is no limit on the amount of animals that can be kept on the lot with
the exception that commercial feedlots are prohibited.
(c) For lots between ten and 40 acres, animals may be kept at the rate of one animal for every two
acres. Pens, roosts, barns, and other holding areas are considered accessory buildings and must
setback at least 75 feet from the side and/or rear lot lines.
(d) For lots between five and ten acres, animals may be kept at the rate of one animal for every one
accessible acre. To qualify as an accessible acre, the area must be fenced or enclosed. One
acre must be reserved for the house.
(Code 1996, § 17.18.100; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)

Sec 66-481 Purpose
Sec 66-482 Yard, Area And Building Size Requirements
Sec 66-481 Purpose
The purpose of this section is to identify subdivisions approved under an old ordinance and the
approved setbacks for those subdivisions. All uses, design standards, fencing, screening landscaping
and parking requirements shall be the same as the underlying zoning district. The following subdivisions
were approved under these regulations: Chain Lake Preserve, Chain Lake Preserve First Addition,
Chain Lake Preserve 2nd Addition, Country View Estates Plat 6, Eagles Nest Preserve, Edgewater
Commons, Northern Preserve, Sunny Meadows and Tall Timbers.
(Code 1996, § 17.20.010)
Sec 66-482 Yard, Area And Building Size Requirements
(a) Yard, area and building size requirements in the CS conservation subdivision district shall be as
follows:
1. Lot area: Minimum of ten acres in unsewered areas except for lots in conservation
subdivisions approved prior to January 1, 2001 where the minimum lot area is 15,000 sq.
feet.
2. Lot width at front yard setback line: minimum of 100 feet.
3. Minimum lot depth: 150 feet.
4. Yard dimensions:
a. Front yard setback: 30 feet from the lot line or road right-of-way if applicable.
b. Side yard setback (each side): minimum of ten feet from the interior lot line.
c. Corner side yard setback: minimum of 30 feet from lot line or road right-of-way if
applicable.
d. Rear yard setback for interior lots: minimum of 30 feet from the lot line.
e. Rear yard setback for corner lots: 15 feet from the lot line.
5. Maximum building height: 35 feet.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 99/215
6. Maximum impervious area: 50 percent.
7. Wetland setback:
a. A 20-foot natural buffer shall be maintained adjacent to all wetlands on lots
created after the adoption of this chapter.
b. A minimum 40-foot setback is required for all structures adjacent to all wetlands
on lots created after the adoption of this chapter.
8. Floor elevation:
a. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be three feet above the
highest known groundwater level.
b. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be two feet above the
100-year flood elevation.
(b) Designated open space must be restricted from further development to retain or protect natural,
scenic, or open-space areas and assure its availability for agricultural, forest, recreational, or
open-space use; protect natural resources, maintain or enhance air and water quality, preserve
the historical, architectural, archeological or cultural aspects of property.
(c) If the conservation subdivision in the future becomes located in the North Branch Urban Services
Area (NBUSA) and water and sewer utilities are extended to the conservation subdivision, the
fee holder may develop the open space under the applicable North Branch guidelines, if the
development's homeowners' association, upon a vote of its members, elects to develop the open
space.
(d) Recreational uses are prohibited above or within 50 feet of communal drainfields.
(e) No new lots may be created within these existing conservation subdivisions unless municipal
utilities are available.
(Code 1996, § 17.20.021; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)

Sec 66-503 Purpose
The purpose of the CBD commercial business district is:
(a) To provide for high intensity commercial activity within a compact central area stressing the
pedestrian function and interaction of people and businesses; and
(b) To provide a local retail, service and civic center for the community.
(Code 1996, § 17.22.010)

Sec 66-510 Required Parking
Plans for off-street parking and loading facilities within the CBD commercial business district shall be
reviewed by the planning commission. The planning commission may require such off-street parking and
loading spaces as deemed appropriate for the proposed use. Upon review, the planning commission
shall make a recommendation to the city council for final review and approval. The planning commission
may recommend and the city council may require a cash contribution in lieu of off-street parking
facilities.

commercial district (B-3) with land uses growing in intensity from west to east.

Sec 66-531.5 Interim Uses
The following uses are interim uses in the B-2 (limited business) district that require city council approval
of an interim use permit and shall be in conformance with the standards specified in section 66-64 of this
chapter and the additional standards specified below:
(a) Transient sales;
1. Must be located in a suitable off-street location and shall not extend into adjacent right-ofway
or other public property;
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 105/215
2. Must not interrupt vehicular circulation on the site or obstruct parking spaces needed by
permanent business established on the site;
3. Must have written authorization from property owner;
4. The business operator must secure all applicable licenses and approvals from the city,
Chisago County or other appropriate jurisdictions;
5. Sight visibility clearances at street intersections and access points must be provided in
accordance with the City Code or as determined by the city to protect public safety;
6. No portion of the use may take place within 100 feet of any developed property zoned for
residential use;
7. Signs are subject to all City Code standards and:
a. Incidental product or pricing signs must be placed directly next to the appropriate
product;
b. Product advertising is permitted, but must be included in the maximum allowed
sign area;
c. The signs must have a professional appearance and must be securely mounted or
erected in a safe location; and
d. These limitations apply to all signs associated with the use, including those affixed
to vehicles;
8. Any display of items must be limited to representative samples and be arranged in as
compact a manner as reasonably practicable;
9. The interim use permit will be issued in the name of the person requesting the permit and
will be for the purpose of selling a particular item or range of items at a specific location.
Any change in the person, location or items sold will render the permit invalid; and
10. Violation of the above standards or other conditions placed upon the interim use permit
will result in immediate revocation of the interim use permit;
(b) Churches or places of worship for a space in a multi-tenant building.
(Ord. No. 210-14, § 2, 7-14-2014)

Sec 66-533 Design Standards
All structures in this zoning district must meet the city design guidelines and be approved by the city
design committee.
(Code 1996, § 17.24.050; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)
Sec 66-534 Area And Bulk Regulations
Area and bulk regulations shall be as follows:
(a) Lot area:
1. Minimum of 5,000 square feet and connected to municipal utilities.
(b) Lot width at front yard setback line:
1. Minimum of 50 feet.
(c) Minimum lot depth:
1. 100 feet.
(d) Yard dimensions:
1. Front Yard Setback:
a. 15 feet from the property line or road right-of-way if applicable.
2. Interior side yard setback (each side):
a. Minimum of zero feet if attached to an adjacent building, or a minimum of ten feet
from the interior lot line(s).
3. Corner side yard setback:
a. Minimum of 15 feet from lot line or road right-of-way if applicable.
4. Rear yard:
a. Minimum of 15 feet from lot line.
(e) Maximum building height: 45 feet.
(f) Maximum impervious area: 90 percent.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 107/215
(g) Wetland setback:
1. A 20-foot natural buffer shall be maintained adjacent to all wetlands on lots created after
the adoption of this chapter.
2. A minimum 40-foot setback is required for all structures adjacent to all wetlands on lots
created after the adoption of this chapter.
(h) Floor elevation:
1. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be three feet above the highest
known groundwater level.
2. The lowest floor elevation for new or redevelopment will be two feet above the 100-year
flood elevation.
(Code 1996, § 17.24.060; Ord. No. 102, § 1 (17.24.065), 10-24-2005; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)

Sec 66-566 Purpose
The purpose of the B-3 regional business district is:
(a) To provide for the location of commercial activities that serve a primarily regional, nonlocal
market area.
(b) To provide for the location of retail and commercial activities that require very large buildings.
(c) To complement the retail activity in the CBD and B-2 Districts.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 108/215
(Code 1996, § 17.26.010)
Sec 66-567 Permitted Uses
The following are permitted uses in the B-3 regional commercial district:
(a) Automobile, motor home and recreational vehicle dealerships.
(b) Discount/outlet malls.
(c) Lumber yards.
(d) Warehouse retail businesses.
(e) Shopping centers.
(f) All permitted uses in the B-2 limited business district.
(Code 1996, § 17.26.020)
Sec 66-568 Accessory Uses
The following are permitted accessory uses in the B-3 regional commercial district:
(a) Commercial or business buildings and structures for a use accessory to the principal use but
shall not exceed 30 percent of the gross floor area of the principal use.
(b) Off-street parking as regulated by section 66-848 et seq.
(c) Off-street loading as regulated by section 66-848 et seq.
(d) Fencing, screening and landscaping as permitted and regulated by section 66-970 et seq.
(e) Signs as regulated by section 66-821 et seq.
(f) Essential services.
(g) Essential service buildings of 1,000 square feet or less.
(Code 1996, § 17.26.030)
Sec 66-568.5 Interim Uses
The following uses are interim uses in the B-3 (regional business) district that require city council
approval of an interim use permit and shall be in conformance with the standards specified in section 66-
64 of this chapter and the additional standards specified below:
(a) Transient sales;
1. Must be located in a suitable off-street location and shall not extend into adjacent right-ofway
or other public property;
2. Must not interrupt vehicular circulation on the site or obstruct parking spaces needed by
permanent business established on the site;
3. Must have written authorization from property owner;
4. The business operator must secure all applicable licenses and approvals from the city,
Chisago County or other appropriate jurisdictions;
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 109/215
5. Sight visibility clearances at street intersections and access points must be provided in
accordance with the City Code or as determined by the city to protect public safety;
6. No portion of the use may take place within 100 feet of any developed property zoned for
residential use;
7. Signs are subject to all City Code standards and:
a. Incidental product or pricing signs must be placed directly next to the appropriate
product;
b. Product advertising is permitted, but must be included in the maximum allowed
sign area;
c. The signs must have a professional appearance and must be securely mounted or
erected in a safe location; and
d. These limitations apply to all signs associated with the use, including those affixed
to vehicles;
8. Any display of items must be limited to representative samples and be arranged in as
compact a manner as reasonably practicable;
9. The interim use permit will be issued in the name of the person requesting the permit and
will be for the purpose of selling a particular item or range of items at a specific location.
Any change in the person, location or items sold will render the permit invalid; and
10. Violation of the above standards or other conditions placed upon the interim use permit
will result in immediate revocation of the interim use permit;
(b) Churches or places of worship for a space in a multi-tenant building.
(Ord. No. 210-14, § 3, 7-14-2014)
Sec 66-569 Conditional Uses
The following are conditional uses in the B-3 regional business district that require a conditional use
permit based upon procedures, conditions and factors set forth in and regulated by section 66-62 et
seq.:
(a) Open and outdoor storage as a principal or accessory use.
(b) Open or outdoor service, sale and rental as a principal or accessory use and including sales in or
from motorized vehicles, trailers or wagons.
(c) Religious institutions such as churches, chapels, temples and synagogues.
(d) Mortuaries.
(e) Cemeteries.
(f) Auto body shops and towing facilities, any outside storage to be appropriately screened by a
masonry wall of the same materials as the building. The maximum height of the wall and stored
items shall be eight feet.
(g) Commercial outdoor recreation for a period not to exceed three days.
(h) Public and private educational institutions, limited to elementary, junior high, senior high schools
and post secondary.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 110/215
(i) Multiple principal buildings on a lot of record for churches and schools provided the buildings are
under common ownership and the buildings are used for related uses.
(j) Nursing homes and assisted living facilities.
(k) Commercial planned unit developments as regulated by section 66-788 et seq.
(l) Mini-storage on properties larger than 5 acres.
(Code 1996, § 17.26.040; Ord. No. 102, § 1(17.26.045), 10-24-2005; Ord. No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010)

Sec 66-628 Conditional Uses
The following are conditional uses in the I-2 general industrial district that require a conditional use
permit approved by the city council based upon procedures set forth in and regulated by section 66-62 et
seq.:
(a) Multiple principle buildings on a lot of record.
(b) Adult use establishments.
(c) Antenna for radio or television broadcasting.
(d) Dry cleaning facilities.
(e) Contractors yard/shop.
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 118/215
(f) Meat market and meat processing business or facility (including slaughtering) where the owner
or operator meets the following requirements:
1. All animal-related and business activities shall be conducted indoors (no outdoor storage
including animals or trailers is allowed).
2. The city may allow meat processing facilities by conditional use permit only as an
accessory use to a meat market. The meat processing facility shall be located in the
same building as a meat market and the floor area of the meat processing facility shall not
exceed the floor area of the meat market. The conditional use permit will limit the size of
the facility and the number of animals for keeping or slaughtering.
3. The applicant shall submit to the city a plan showing all staging areas for the temporary
storage of carcasses and disposal of animal remains.
4. The owner or operator shall conduct all uses and activities in strict conformance with all
federal and state laws for the operation of such facilities.
5. The owner or operator shall conduct the slaughtering of animals inside a closed building
in a confined area to prevent the transmission of sound associated with the slaughter to
the outside.
6. The owner or operator shall dispose of all waste in accordance with all applicable laws
and regulations. This includes, but is not limited to, all sewage, processed and
unprocessed animal parts, manure, entrails, blood, hides and bones. At a minimum, the
owner or operator shall dispose of waste within 48 hours of being produced, shall store all
waste in airtight containers and shall keep all waste in fully enclosed structures. The
owner or operator shall remove from the site on a daily basis the manure from the holding
areas.
7. The owner or operator of the facility shall have all necessary federal, state and county
licenses and approvals and shall meet or exceed all state and federal health and safety
regulations and standards.
8. The hours of operation for the facility shall be subject to approval by the city council as
part of the conditional use permit.
9. The owner or operator shall not hold live animals on-site for more than 24 hours.
10. The owner or operator shall screen all loading and unloading areas from view from
adjacent properties and public streets.
(g) Radio and television, transmitting station.
(h) Cellular, telecommunication and digital and telephone towers or antennas.
(i) Outdoor storage shall be a conditional use permit. Paving and screening of this storage area
shall be addressed as part of the conditional use permit. Expansion of existing outdoor storage
areas shall require a conditional use permit.
(j) Recreational or sports facilities.
(k) Industrial planned unit developments as regulated in section 66-788 et seq.
(l) Auction houses that have outside sales, display or storage.
(m) Similar conditional uses as determined by the city.
(Code 1996, § 17.28.040; Ord. No. 102, § 1 (17.28.045), 10-24-2005; Ord. No. 114, § 1, 3-12-2007; Ord.
No. 153-10, § 1, 8-9-2010; Ord. No. 208-14, § 1, 3-24-2014)
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 119/215

Sec 66-664 Screening
(a) All outside storage requires a conditional use permit and, in addition to any other conditions
imposed by the governing authority, must be screened.
(b) All screening shall have gates or other means of blocking vision through access points. Gates
shall match screening and be properly maintained.
(c) All vehicles in excess of three-quarter ton capacity or equipment, shall be screened with an eight
foot high fence of 90 percent opacity. Storage shall not be allowed in trucks, trailers, or similar
containers.
(Code 1996, § 17.29.100)
Sec 66-665 Paved Surface
All vehicular driving and parking areas shall be paved and be surrounded with poured-in-place concrete
curb and gutter, except in special circumstances such as off-road heavy equipment storage areas or
contractor (nonretail) material storage areas with approval by the planning commission.
(Code 1996, § 17.29.110)
Sec 66-666 Waste
(a) All solid waste materials, debris, refuse, or garbage shall be kept within a completely enclosed
building or properly contained in closed containers and stored in racks designed for such
purposes. All liquid wastes containing any organic or toxic matter shall be discharged in a
manner prescribed by the governing authority.
(b) All waste shall be placed in containers or enclosures in a manner not constituting a nuisance by
reason of wind-litter, disorderly appearance, or abnormal fire hazard.
(c) All waste containers or racking not in an enclosed building shall be completely screened for its
full height but not less than eight feet.
(d) No outside incinerators or trash burners shall be installed, erected or utilized on any lot.
(Code 1996, § 17.29.120)
Sec 66-667 Nonpermitted Buildings And Temporary Buildings
(a) No trailer, basement, tent, shack, garage, barn or other out-building shall at any time be used for
7/17/2019 Print Preview
https://northbranch.municipalcodeonline.com/book/print?type=code&name=Chapter_66_ZONING 125/215
human habitation, temporarily or permanently; nor shall any structure of temporary character be
maintained upon a building site, except as temporarily incidental to building construction.
(b) Temporary construction trailers used in conjunction with a building project are not considered
temporary buildings and therefore are permitted during construction.
(c) No temporary buildings and structures for any purpose shall be erected on the site without
written approval from the city.
(d) Temporary structures will only be approved for extenuating circumstances. One year after
construction begins, all temporary buildings and their supporting systems shall be removed from
the site and the original site improvements returned to their original condition.
(Code 1996, § 17.29.130)
Sec 66-668 Maintenance Of Vacant Lots Or Tracts
All owners of vacant lots or tracts shall keep them clean, mowed, and maintained in a manner that will
not depreciate other property value.
(Code 1996, § 17.29.140)

Sec 66-671 Purpose
The purpose of the I-4 industrial district is to establish and preserve areas for industrial development
including manufacturing, fabrication, packaging, assembly, warehouse, and distribution, as well as
related uses of such a nature that they do not create serious problems of compatibility with other kinds of
land uses.
(Ord. No. 121-08, § 1, 3-10-2008)

manufacturing.

(d) Warehouse operations.

Sec 66-674 Required Parking

1.25 spaces for each employee per shift shall be provided and maintained.
If the applicant chooses the lesser number of parking spaces then a proof of parking plan will need to be
submitted and approved to assure the larger standard can be met if additional parking is needed later.

exterior surface if it meets the following standards:

DIVISION 18 FP FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT OVERLAY DISTRICT
